name: Aalborg Lufthavn
description: Located in the city of Nørresundby, Aalborg Airport is the third largest in Denmark and serves the city of *Aal*borg.

name: Aarhus Airport
description: Originally built in 1946, Aarhus Airport has since been the “temporary” primary airport for the city of *Aar*hus, despite being located in the city of Tirstrup nearly 50 kilometers away.

name: Abakan International Airport
description: Abakan International Airport is located in *Aba*kan, Republic of Khakassia, Russia.

name: Aeropuerto de Albacete
description: Opened in 1929, Albacete Airport is located on Los Llanos Air Base and serves the city of *A*l*b*a*c*ete.

name: Lehigh Valley International Airport
description: Opened in 1929 and still operating from its original location, Lehigh Valley International gets its airport code from its former name: *A*llentown–*B*ethlehem–*E*aston International.

name: Abilene Regional Airport
description: Abilene Regional dates back to the 1930s and gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *Abi*lene.

name: Aéroport International Félix Houphouët-Boigny
description: Félix Houphouët-Boigny International is named after the first President of Côte d’Ivoire, or Ivory Coast. While located in the town of Port-Bouët, it serves the city of *Ab*id*j*an.

name: Albuquerque International Sunport
description: Opened in 1939, New Mexico’s largest airport gets its name and airport code from its home in *A*l*b*u*q*uerque.

name: Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport
description: Nnamdi Azikiwe International is named after the first Nigerian President. Its airport code comes from the city of *Ab*uja, but unable to use ABU, they replaced the ‘U’ with the letter ‘*V*’.

name: Aberdeen International Airport
description: Opened in 1934, Aberdeen International is located in the suburb of Dyce and serves the city of *Ab*erdeen. Its three-letter code is completed with a filler letter ‘*Z*’.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional General Juan N. Álvarez
nameEnglish: General Juan N. Álvarez International Airport
description: Named after Juan Álvarez, military general and interim President of Mexico, Acapulco International is an important tourist gateway for the resorts and beaches of *Aca*pulco.

name: Kotoka International Airport
description: Kotoka International is named after Lieutenant General Emmanuel Kwasi Kotoka and is the only international airport in Ghana. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, *Acc*ra.

name: Aeropuerto de Lanzarote
description: Lanzarote Airport began accepting civil traffic in 1946. It serves the island of Lanzarote and gets its airport code from the nearby city of *A*rre*c*if*e*.

name: Nantucket Memorial Airport
description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. N*a*ntu*ck*et Memorial, then, used other letters in its name to get ACK.

name: Atlantic City International Airport
description: Originally built in 1942 as a naval air station, *A*tlantic *C*it*y* International is now a joint civilian and military airfield and home to the Atlantic City Air National Guard Base.

name: Adana Havalimanı
description: Adana Şakirpaşa Airport, located in *Ada*na, Turkey, is the sixth-busiest airport in the country, serving 5.6 million passengers in 2016.

name: Addis Ababa Bole International Airport
description: Formerly Haile Selassie I Airport, Addis Ababa Bole International is located in the subcity of Bole and serves the capital city of *Add*is Ababa.

name: Adelaide Airport
description: First established in 1955, the main airport for Adelaide, Australia gets its airport code from its home in *AD*e*L*aide.

name: Aeroparque Jorge Newbery
description: Jorge Newbery Airfield serves as the main airport for the city of Buenos Aires and is named after an Argentine aviator. Its airport code comes from its Spanish name *Ae*ro*p*arque Jorge Newbery.

name: Sochi International Airport
description: Sochi International served as the main airport for the 22nd Winter Olympics held in Sochi in 2014. Its airport code comes from its home in the *A*dl*er*sky District.

name: Ålesund lufthavn, Vigra
description: Officially opened in 1958, Ålesund Airport is located on the island of Vigra and serves the city of *Å*l*es*und.

name: Alexandria International Airport
description: Previously known as England Air Force Base, Alexandria International gets its three-letter code from its home in *A*l*ex*andria.

name: Akureyrarflugvöllur
description: A single-runway international airport in *A*kur*ey*ri, nothern Iceland.

name: Agadir–Al Massira Airport
description: With a capacity of 3 million travelers per year, Agadir – Al Massira Airport gets its airport code from the city of *Aga*dir.

name: Flughafen Augsburg
description: Originally opened in 1968, Augsburg Airport is located in Affing and serves the city of *A*u*g*s*b*urg.

name: Allegheny County Airport
description: Dedicated in 1931, Allegheny County Airport was originally designed to be Pittsburgh’s primary airport. Located in West Mifflin, it serves *A*lle*g*heny *C*ounty.

name: Aeropuerto de Málaga-Costa del Sol
description: Located in Málaga, Costa del Sol Airport didn’t think MAL was a good option as “mal” means “bad” in Spanish. Instead, it opted to use letters from Mál*ag*a and a filler letter ‘*P*’.

name: Augusta Regional Airport
description: First established as a flight school for the U.S. military, Augusta Regional has become a significant hub for the Central Savannah River Area (CSRA). Its airport code comes from the city of *A*u*g*u*s*ta.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Lic. Jesús Terán Peredo
nameEnglish: Lic. Jesús Terán Peredo International Airport
description: Jesús Terán Peredo International is named after a former governor of *Agu*ascalientes, the city and state from which its airport code derives.

name: Abha Regional Airport
description: Opened in 1977, Abha Regional gets its three-letter airport code from rearranged letters in the city name of *Abh*a.

name: Aéroport d’Ajaccio-Napoléon-Bonaparte
description: *Aja*ccio Napoleon Bonaparte Airport serves as the main gateway to the island of Corsica in the Mediterranean Sea. It is located directly at sea level close to the city of Ajaccio, which is also the birthplace of Napoleon Bonaparte.

name: Al-Jawf Domestic Airport
description: Featuring a single runway, Al-Jawf Domestic Airport serves the city of Sakakah and gets its name and airport code from the city’s alternate name, *A*l-*J*aw*f*.

name: Lengpui Airport
description: Lengpui Airport gets its name from the nearby Lengpui Village. Its airport code comes from an alternate spelling of its home city of Aizawl: *A*i*j*a*l*.

name: Aeroporto Aracaju–Santa Maria
description: Officially inaugurated in 1958, Aracaju–Santa Maria Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *A*raca*ju*.

name: Akron Fulton International Airport
description: Opened in 1929, Akron Fulton International is named after longtime manager Bain Ecarius “Shorty” Fulton. The code AKR was given to Akure Airport in Nigeria, so Akron uses AKC for *Ak*ron *C*ity.

name: Auckland Airport
description: Once the site for the Mangere Aerodrome, New Zealand’s busiest airport is located in Mangere, a suburb of *A*uc*kl*and.

name: Aktobe Airport
description: Aktobe Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of *Ak*tobe. It is completed with a letter ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Almaty International Airport
description: Almaty International is Kazakhstan’s largest international airport. It is located 15km northeast from the city of Almaty and was formerly known as *Al*ma-*A*ta Airport.

name: Albany International Airport
description: *Alb*any International was the first municipal airport in the United States. It is the major air center for the Capital Region, northeastern New York, and western New England.

name: Aeropuerto de Alicante-Elche
description: Originally named El Altet, Alicante–Elche Airport is the sixth busiest airport in Spain. Located in Elche, it serves the cities of Valencia, Murcia, and *Al*i*c*ante.

name: Houari Boumediene Airport
description: Opened in 1924 as Maison Blanche Airport, Houari Boumediene Airport is now named after a former President of Algeria. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Alg*iers.

name: San Luis Valley Regional Airport
description: Opened in early 1941, it is owned by the City and County of *Al*amo*s*a and is named for Carl A. Bergman, a local businessman and initial supporter of the airport.

name: Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport
description: Opened in 1929 as English Field, Amarillo Airport was renamed in 2003 to honor Rick Husband, NASA astronaut who died in the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster. Its code honors the city of *Ama*rillo.

name: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International Airport
description: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International is named after India’s first Deputy Prime Minister. Its airport code honors its home in the beautiful city of *A*h*m*e*d*abad.

name: Queen Alia International Airport
description: Named after Queen Alia, third wife to the late King Hussein, Jordan’s largest airport is located in Zizya, 30 km (20 mi) south of the capital city of *Amm*an.

name: Bandar Udara Pattimura
description: Pattimura Airport is named after Thomas Matulessy, also known as Kapitan Pattimura, Indonesian soldier and national hero. Its airport code comes from the city of *Am*bon plus a ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Luchthaven Schiphol
description: The name “Schiphol” came from the nearby Fort Schiphol, which translates to “ship grave” in English. Its airport code honors the city of *Ams*terdam.

name: Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport
description: In 2009, Anchorage International was renamed to honor U.S. Senator Ted Stevens, but its airport code still honors its home in *Anc*horage.

name: Aéroport international d'Angoulême-Cognac
description: Angoulême – Cognac International is located between Brie and Champniers and serves the city of *Ang*oulême.

name: Internationale Luchthaven Antwerpen
description: Antwerp International is a small scale airport serving Belgium’s second biggest city. Its airport code refers directly to the city of *An*twe*r*p.

name: Aeropuerto Andahuaylas
description: Andahuaylas Airport is the only airport in the Apurímac Region that serves commercial flights. Its three-letter code comes from the city of *An*dahuayla*s*.

name: V. C. Bird International Airport
description: Built in 1942 by the U.S. Army as Coolidge Airfield, V. C. Bird International was renamed in 1985 in honor of the country’s first Prime Minister, Vere Cornwall Bird Sr. Its airport code comes from the island’s name, *An*tig*u*a.

name: Aeroporto Raffaello Sanzio di Ancona-Falconara
description: Raffaello Sanzio Airport is named after the famous Renaissance artist, internationally known as Raphael. Located in Falconara Marittima, it serves the city of *A*nc*o*na, *I*taly.

name: Centennial Airport
description: Centennial Airport serves the Denver-Aurora metro area in Colorado. It is located in the town of Dove Valley and was previously known *A*ra*pa*hoe County Airport.

name: Faleolo International Airport
description: Faleolo Airport was built during World War II by the U.S. Navy. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *Ap*ia and the country’s name at the time of its designation, *W*estern Samoa.

name: King Hussein International Airport
description: King Hussein International is located within a 15-mile radius of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and Israel. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Aq*aba, *J*ordan.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alférez Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón
nameEnglish: Alférez Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón International Airport
description: Alfredo Rodríguez Ballón International shares its name with the Peruvian aviator. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *A*re*q*ui*p*a.

name: Stockholm-Arlanda flygplats
description: Stockholm’s airport is named *Ar*la*n*da, a made-up word combining “Arland”, another name for the nearby parish of Ärlinghundra, and “landa”, Swedish verb meaning “to land.”

name: Watertown International Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Watertown International opted, then, to use other letters from W*a*te*rt*own.

name: Ashgabat International Airport
description: Opened in 1994 and formerly named after Saparmyrat Niyazov, Turkmenistan’s first President, Ashgabat International gets its airport code from the capital city of *As*hga*b*at.

name: Aspen–Pitkin County Airport
description: Officially dedicated in 1958, Aspen–Pitkin County Airport is also called Sardy Field, named after Commissioner Thomas J. Sardy. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *As*p*e*n.

name: Asmara International Airport
description: Formerly known as Yohannes IV Airport, Asmara International was nearly destroyed during World War II and was rebuilt in the 1950s. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *Asm*ara.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Silvio Pettirossi
description: Silvio Pettirossi International is named after Silvio Pettirossi, local aviator and pioneer. Located in the city of Luque, its aiport code comes from the city it serves, *Asu*nción.

name: Aeropuerto Comandante FAP Germán Arias Graziani
nameEnglish: Comandante FAP Germán Arias Graziani Airport
description: Germán Arias Graziani Airport serves the city of Huaraz, but gets its three-letter code from the nearby village of *A*n*ta*.

name: Athens International Airport, Eleftherios Venizelos
description: Eleftherios Venizelos Airport is named after the Cretan political leader and Prime Minister of Greece who pushed the development of Greek aviation. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *Ath*ens.

name: Hartsfield–Jackson International Airport
description: The Hartsfield-Jackson Airport honors former mayors Maynard Jackson and William B. Hartsfield. The airport code honors *Atl*anta and has become the city’s beloved nickname.

name: Sri Guru Ram Das Jee International Airport
description: Sri Guru Ram Das Jee International is named after Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru and founder of the city of *A*mri*t*sar. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Appleton International Airport
description: Dedicated in 1965 and previously named Outagamie County Regional, Appleton International is located in the town of Greenville and serves the city of *A*pple*t*on, *W*isconsin.

name: Internationale luchthaven Koningin Beatrix
description: Queen Beatrix International is named after Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands, former Queen and head of state. Located in the capital city of Oranjestad, it serves the island of *A*r*u*b*a*.

name: Abu Dhabi International Airport
description: In 1982, Abu Dhabi International replaced Al Bateen Airport as the primary airport for the city of *A*b*u* D*h*abi.

name: Austin–Bergstrom International Airport
description: Once the location for Bergstrom Air Force Base (BSM), *Aus*tin-Bergstrom Airport opened in 1999 and took the airport code AUS from Mueller Airport which closed that same year.

name: Asheville Regional Airport
description: Opened in 1961, Asheville Regional is located near the town of Fletcher and serves the city of *A*she*v*il*l*e.

name: Wilkes-Barre/Scranton International Airport
description: Granted “international” status in 1975, Wilkes-Barre/Scranton International serves the cities of Wilkes-Barre and Scranton, but is located in the city of *Av*oca, *P*ennsylvania.

name: Ahvaz International Airport
description: Ahvaz International gets its three-letter code from its home in Ahvaz, alternately spelled *A*h*w*a*z*.

name: Aeropuerto Coronel FAP Alfredo Mendívil Duarte
nameEnglish: Coronel FAP Alfredo Mendívil Duarte Airport
description: Alfredo Mendívil Duarte Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *Ay*acucho, *P*eru.

name: Antalya Havalimanı
description: Antalya Airport primarily serves tourists visiting Turkey’s Mediterranean beaches. Its three-letter code is completed by rearranged letters from its home city of *A*n*t*al*y*a.

name: Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport
description: Formerly named after 1st Lt. Charles Williams of the U.S. Army Air Corps, Phoenix-Mesa Gateway is the lucky airport whose airport code honors its home state of *A*ri*z*on*a*.

name: Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Kalamazoo/Battle Creek International opted, then, to use other letters from K*a*lama*zo*o.

name: Bahrain International Airport
description: Located on Muharraq Island, Bahrain Airport became the first international airport in the Persian Gulf in 1932. It serves the entire country of *Bah*rain.

name: Batman Havaalanı
description: Batman Airport is a civil-military airport serving the city of Batman in *Ba*tman i*l*i, Turkey.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Ernesto Cortissoz
description: Dedicated in 1981, Ernesto Cortissoz International is named after Ernesto Cortissoz, Colombian aviation pioneer. It is located in the suburb of Soledad and serves the city of *Ba*rran*q*uilla.

name: Aeroporto Chafei Amsei
description: Chafei Amsei Airport is used for general aviation and gets its three-letter code from the city of *Ba*rre*t*os.

name: Virginia Tech Montgomery Executive Airport
description: This small but scenic airport is located in the university town of *B*la*c*ks*b*urg, Virginia.

name: Aeropuerto de Barcelona-El Prat
description: Barcelona’s first airfield was built in 1916, but a new location in El Prat was chosen in 1918. The airport now uses the code BCN which stands for *B*ar*c*elo*n*a.

name: L.F. Wade International Airport
description: Started as Kindley Field, a joint U.S. Army Air Force and Royal Air Force base, L.F. Wade International was renamed in 2007 after the Progressive Labour Party leader. Its airport code honors its home in *B*ermu*da*.

name: Bird Island Airport
description: Bird Island Airport has a grass runway and serves travelers jumping between islands in the Seychelles. Its airport code comes from its home on *B*ir*d* *I*sland.

name: Bradley International Airport
description: Originally a National Guard air base during World War II, Bradley International is named after U.S. Air Force Lieutenant Eugene M. *B*ra*dl*ey.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Husein Sastranegara
description: Husein Sastranegara International was built by Dutch settlers and named after Husein Sastranegara, aviator from West Java. Its airport code comes from an old spelling of the city of Bandung: *B*an*DO*eng.

name: Brindisi - Aeroporto del Salento
description: Formerly known as Papola Casale Airport, Brindisi - Salento Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *B*rin*d*i*s*i.

name: Port-adhair Beinn na Faoghla
description: Located in the village of Balivanich, Benbecula Airport serves the islands of *Be*n*b*ecula, North Uist, and South Uist off the coast of Scotland.

name: Laurence G. Hanscom Field
description: Laurence G. Hanscom Field is named after a local aviator who was killed in a plane crash in 1941. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Bed*ford.

name: Aerodrom Beograd - Nikola Tesla
description: Previously known as *Be*l*g*rade Airport or Surčin Airport, it was renamed in 2006 in honor of Serbian scientist and inventor Nikola Tesla. It is the busiest airport in the former Yugoslavia.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Júlio Cezar Ribeiro
description: Júlio Cezar Ribeiro International is named after Júlio Cezar Ribeiro de Sousa, Brazilian inventor of the glider balloon. Its airport code comes from the city of *Bel*ém.

name: Flughafen Berlin Brandenburg
description: Finally opening in fall of 2020 (nine years late), Berlin Brandenburg Airport’s three-letter code honors the city of *Ber*lin.

name: Brest Bretagne Airport
description: The *B*r*es*t Bretagne Airport originated as two airship hangars in Guipavas in 1917 and was formerly known as the Brest Guipavas Airport.

name: Beirut–Rafic Hariri International Airport
description: Located in the suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon’s only commercial airport gets its three-letter airport code from the French spelling of Beirut: *Bey*routh.

name: Western Nebraska Regional Airport
description: Western Nebraska Regional is also referred to as William B. Heilig Field, named after a World War II flight instructor and former airport manager. Its airport code comes from its home city and former name of Scotts*b*lu*ff* Army Airfield.

name: King County International Airport / Boeing Field
description: King County International is located in Seattle, Washington and is also known as *B*oeing *Fi*eld, named after William E. Boeing, founder of The Boeing Company.

name: Meadows Field Airport
description: In 1957, Meadows Field Airport was named after Cecil Meadows, former Army pilot and Kern County Director of Airports from 1935–1957. Located in Oildale, it serves the city of *B*akers*f*ie*l*d.

name: Belfast International Airport
description: Formerly named and commonly still called Aldergrove Airport, *B*el*f*a*s*t International is located between the villages of Killead and Aldergrove. It is the busiest airport in Northern Ireland.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Palonegro
description: Palonegro International is named for the nearby area where the Battle of Palonegro took place during the Thousand Days War. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, *B*ucaraman*ga*.

name: Grantley Adams International Airport
description: Grantley Adams International is named after the founder of the Barbados Labour Party. Located in the Seawell area of Bridgetown, its airport code stands for *B*rid*g*etown *I*nternational.

name: Bergen lufthavn, Flesland
description: Opened in 1955, Bergen Airport is located in the village of Flesland and is the second busiest airport in Norway. Its airport code comes from *B*er*g*en and the ‘O’ could come from N*o*rway, but is likely a filler letter.

name: Bangor International Airport
description: Originally known as Godfrey Field, Bangor International was an army air field during and after World War II. Its airport code comes from its home in *B*an*g*o*r*.

name: Baghdad International Airport
description: Baghdad Airport was formerly named after Saddam Hussein and used the code SDA. When the named changed, its airport code changed to BGW, which previously referred to all *B*a*g*hdad airports. The ‘*W*’ is a filler letter.

name: Aeroporto di Bergamo-Orio al Serio Il Caravaggio
description: Il Caravaggio International is named after the famous Baroque painter. It is located in the comune of Orio al Serio, near the city of *B*er*g*amo. The ‘*Y*’ in BGY likely comes from Lombard*y* or Ital*y*.

name: George Best Belfast City Airport
description: Opened in 1983, George Best Belfast City Airport was renamed in 2006 in honor of the Northern Irish footballer George Best. It was originally known as *B*elfast *H*arbour Airport, located in County *D*own.

name: Birmingham–Shuttlesworth International Airport
description: Birmingham-Shuttlesworth International shares its name with Alabama civil rights activist Fred Shuttlesworth, but it gets its airport code from its home in *B*irming*h*a*m*.

name: Birmingham Airport
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Previously Elmdon Airport, *B*irming*h*am Airport’s name gives us the first two letters plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Billings Logan International Airport
description: Opened in 1928, *Bil*lings Municipal was renamed to Billings Logan Field in 1957 after Dick Logan, former airport manager. In 1971 it became Billings Logan International.

name: Aeropuerto de Bilbao
description: Opened for passenger travel in 1948, Bilbao Airport serves the Basque Country and northern Spain from the city of *Bi*lba*o*.

name: Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport
description: Renamed in 2006, Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport serves the Denver area and gets its airport code from the nearby town of *B*roomfield in *J*efferson *C*ounty.

name: Banjul International Airport
description: The only airport in The Gambia, Banjul International is sometimes called Yundum Airport. Its three-letter code comes from the city of *B*an*j*u*l*.

name: Aéroport international de Bujumbura
description: Bujumbura International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in *B*u*j*u*m*bura, the capital city of Burundi.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Guanajuato
description: Guanajuato International is located in the city of Guanajuato and gets its airport code from the region of *B*a*j*ío, Me*x*ico.

name: Lake Brooks Seaplane Base
description: Lake Brooks Seaplane Base is a seaplane landing area on Naknek Lake in Katmai National Park. Its airport code comes from the nearby *B*roo*k*s *F*alls.

name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Kota Kinabalu
description: Kota Kinabalu International is Malaysia’s second-busiest airport. Its airport code comes from its location on *B*orneo and in the city of Kota *Ki*nabalu.

name: Suvarnabhumi Airport
description: Suvarnabhumi Airport was named by King Bhumibol Adulyadej after the mythical golden kingdom said to be located in Southeast Asia. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *B*ang*k*o*k*.

name: Burke Lakefront Airport
description: Home to the Cleveland National Air Show, *B*ur*k*e *L*akefront was opened in 1947 on the shore of Lake Erie and is named after then mayor Thomas A. Burke.

name: Aéroport international de Bamako–Sénou
description: Opened in 1974, Sénou International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital city of *B*ama*ko*.

name: Bellingham International Airport
description: Bellingham International was used by the Fourth Air Force during World War II. Commercial service to *B*e*l*l*i*ngham began in the mid 1980s.

name: Blackpool Airport
description: Located on the coast of Lancashire, Blackpool Airport was formerly known as Squires Gate Airport. Its airport code comes from the city of *Bl*ac*k*pool.

name: Billund Lufthavn
description: Billund Airport was once a private runway owned by Godtfred Kirk Christiansen, son to LEGO founder Ole Kirk Christiansen. Located in *B*i*ll*und, it served the LEGO factory and now serves nearby Legoland.

name: Aeroporto di Bologna-Guglielmo Marconi
description: Named after Guglielmo Marconi, Italian inventor and Nobel laureate, Bologna Airport serves the city of *B*o*l*ogna. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Kempegowda International Airport
description: Kempegowda International was renamed in 2013 to honor the city’s founder, Kempe Gowda I. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Bengaluru: *B*anga*l*o*r*e.

name: Stockholm-Bromma flygplats
description: Opened in 1936, Stockholm Bromma Airport serves the city of Stockholm and is located in the borough of *B*rom*ma*.

name: Central Illinois Regional Airport
description: Previously know as Bloomington/Normal Airport, Central Illinois Regional was renamed in 1996 to reflect its central location. Its airport code honors its home in *B*loo*mi*ngton.

name: Sân bay Buôn Ma Thuột
description: With a single functional runway, Buon Ma Thuot Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *B*uon *M*a Thuot, *V*ietnam.

name: Nashville International Airport
description: Nashville International was originally named after Colonel Harry S. Berry. Codes with first letter ‘N’ were reserved for the U.S. Navy, so it used *B*erry Field *Na*shville to get BNA.

name: Bandar Abbas International Airport
description: Bandar Abbas International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *B*a*nd*ar Abbas.

name: Brisbane Airport
description: Opened in 1988, Brisbane Airport replaced Eagle Farm Airport as the primary airport serving the city of *B*risba*ne* in Queensland.

name: Banja Luka International Airport
description: Originally built in 1976, Banja Luka International is located in the village of Mahovljani, but serves the ctiy of *B*a*n*ja Luka. Its three-letter code is completed by an ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Bora Bora Airport
description: Opened during World War II and located on the islet of Motu Mute, Bora Bora Airport gets its three-letter code from the island it serves, *Bo*ra *B*ora.

name: Aéroport de Bordeaux-Mérignac
description: Started as an airfield in 1917, Bordeaux-Mérignac Airport gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, *Bo*r*d*eaux.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional El Dorado
description: El Dorado International may be named after the mythical city of gold, but its airport code comes from its home in *Bog*otá.

name: Bournemouth Airport
description: Started during World War II, RAF Hurn was renamed in 1969 to *Bo*urnemout*h* Airport after the nearby town in southern England.

name: Boise Airport
description: Originally named (and often still called) Gowen Field, Boise Airport honored U.S. Army 1st Lieutenant Paul R. Gowen. Its airport code honors its home in *Boi*se.

name: Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport
description: The Mumbai airport was previously named Sahar International, but it gets its three-letter code from the city’s former English name, *Bom*bay, changed in 1995.

name: Luchthaven Flamingo
description: Opened in 1945, Flamingo International is located in the city of Kralendijk and serves the island of *Bon*aire.

name: Logan International Airport
description: Formerly Jeffery Field, Logan Airport was renamed in 1943 to honor Edward Lawrence Logan, U.S. Army Lt. General and MA state representative. Its airport code honors its home in *Bos*ton.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Aji Muhammad Sulaiman
description: Sultan Aji Muhammad Sulaiman International, formerly Sepinggan Airport, is the busiest airport in Kalimantan. It serves the nearby city of *B*alik*p*apa*n*.

name: Jack Brooks Regional Airport
description: Formerly Southeast Texas Regional, Jack Brooks Regional was renamed to honor former U.S. Representative Jack Brooks. It serves the cities of *B*eaumont and *P*ort Arthur, *T*exas

name: Biggin Hill Airport
description: Biggin Hill Airport was originally opened by the Royal Flying Corps during World War I. It gets its three-letter code from the town of *B*iggin *H*ill plus a ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Aeroporto de Barreiras
description: Opened in 1940, Barreiras Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *B*arrei*ra*s.

name: Flughafen Bremen
description: Opened in 1920 and originally called Neuenlander Feld, *Bre*men Airport serves as a starting point for commercial pilot careers at Lufthansa.

name: Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport
description: Formerly Brownsville Army Airfield, Brownsville/South Padre Island International gets its three-letter code from its home in *Bro*wnsville, Texas.

name: Letiště Brno–Tuřany
description: Built in the 1950s, Brno–Tuřany Airport gets its airport code from the city of *Br*no, plus a helpful ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Port-adhair Bharraigh
description: Opened in 1936, Barra Airport is located at the north tip of the island of *B*a*rr*a in the Outer Hebrides, Scotland. It is the only airport in the world using a beach as its runway.

name: Bristol Airport
description: Used as RAF Lulsgate Bottom during World War II, Bristol Airport is located at Lulsgate Bottom in North Somerset and serves the city of *Br*i*s*tol.

name: Luchthaven Brussel-Nationaal
description: Built during World War II and originally called Fliegerhorst Melsbroek, Belgium’s largest airport is located between Zaventem and Machelen, northeast of *Bru*ssels.

name: Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport
description: Wiley Post–Will Rogers Memorial Airport honors the late entertainer Will Rogers and aviator Wiley Post whose plane crashed nearby in 1935. Its airport code honors its home in *B*a*r*ro*w*.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Brasília–Pres. Juscelino Kubitschek
description: Renamed in 1999 to honor former President Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira, Brasília International gets its airport code from its home in the capital city of *B*ra*s*ília, *B*razil.

name: EuroAirport Basel–Mulhouse–Freiburg
description: EuroAirport *B*a*s*e*l*-Mulhouse-Freiburg has two IATA codes (MLH is the other one). It is actually located in Saint-Louis, France but is one of only a few airports in the world operated jointly by two countries, in this case France and Switzerland.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Iskandar Muda
description: The Sultan Iskander Muda International serves the area near Banda Aceh. Its airport code refers to the nearby subdistricts of *B*lang Bin*t*ang and *J*antho.

name: Bert Mooney Airport
description: Bert Mooney Airport in Butte, Montana is named for the first pilot to fly mail into Yellowstone National Park. It opened in 1926 as *B*u*t*te *M*unicipal Airport.

name: Baton Rouge Metropolitan Airport
description: Also known as Ryan Field, Baton Rouge Metropolitan gets its three-letter code from its home in *B*a*t*on *R*ouge.

name: Letisko M. R. Štefánika
description: M. R. Štefánik Airport, also called *B*ra*t*i*s*lava Airport, was renamed in 1993 after General Milan Rastislav Štefánik, whose aircraft crashed near Bratislava in 1919.

name: Burlington International Airport
description: In 1920, Burlington Municipal Airport opened, honoring and serving the city of *B*urling*t*on, *V*ermont.

name: Budapest Liszt Ferenc Nemzetközi Repülőtér
description: Still called “Ferihegy” for the surrounding neighborhood, *Bud*apest’s airport was renamed in 2011 to honor Hungarian composer Ferenc Liszt.

name: Buffalo Niagara International Airport
description: Opened in 1926 as Buffalo Municipal, *Buf*falo Niagara International was rebuilt and renamed in 1997 to honor the oft-visited Niagara Falls.

name: Bob Hope Airport
description: Bob Hope Airport has gone by six names since its opening in 1930. It was renamed most recently in 2003 to honor entertainer Bob Hope. Like two of its former names, its code refers to its location in the Los Angeles suburb of *BUR*bank.

name: Bathpalathang Airport
description: Bathpalathang Airport is located in the city of Jakar. Its three-letter airport code comes from the *Bu*m*t*hang District.

name: Aéroport de Beauvais-Tillé
description: Built during the 1930s, Beauvais-Tillé Airport is located in Tillé and serves *B*eau*va*is. It is often referred to as Paris-Beauvais Airport.

name: Aeroporto International Atlas Brasil Cantanhede
description: Opened in 1973, Atlas Brasil Cantanhede International is named after Atlas Brasil Cantanhede, Brazilian aviation pioneer. Its three-letter code comes from its home in *B*oa *V*ista, *B*razil.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Aristides Pereira
description: Originally Rabil Airport, it was renamed in 2011 to honor Cape Verde’s first president, Aristides Pereira. Its code comes from its home on the island of *B*oa *V*ista, *C*ape Verde.

name: Flughafen Braunschweig-Wolfsburg
description: Located directly at the German Federal Aviation Office and the German Aerospace Center, the *B*raunsch*we*ig Airport mainly serves research flights as well as private business flights for the Volkswagen group, which is a major shareholder.

name: Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport
description: Originally Friendship International (perhaps the best airport name ever), *B*altimore/*W*ashington *I*nternational was renamed in 1973 and again in 2005 to honor Thurgood Marshall, former U.S. Supreme Court justice.

name: Brunei International Airport
description: Opened in 1974, Brunei International serves the country of Brunei and its capital city of Bandar Seri *B*ega*w*a*n*.

name: Aeroporto de Beja
description: Originally built in 1964 as a military training center, Beja Airport began serving civilian traffic to *B*e*j*a in 2011. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Y*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Philip S. W. Goldson International Airport
description: Philip S. W. Goldson International is named after Philip Stanley Wilberforce Goldson, former Belizean politician. Its airport code comes from its home in *B*eli*ze* City.

name: Bozeman Yellowstone International Airport
description: In 2005, Gallatin Field was renamed to *B*o*z*ema*n* Yellowstone International in honor of the famous national park.

name: Maya-Maya Airport
description: Maya-Maya Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *B*ra*z*za*v*ille, the capital city of Republic of Congo.

name: Columbia Metropolitan Airport
description: Built in 1940 and originally named Lexington County Airport, Columbia Metropolitan gets its airport code from the nearby city of *Ca*yc*e*.

name: Sân bay Cà Mau
description: Originally built in 1962, *Ca* Mau Airport serves the city of Cà Mau, Vietnam. The ‘H’ comes from *H*o Chi Minh City, the only destination the airport serves.

name: Cairo International Airport
description: Originally built during World War II and known as Payne Airfield, Egypt’s busiest airport serves the capital city of *Cai*ro.

name: Akron–Canton Airport
description: Dedicated in 1946, Akron–Canton Airport is actually located in the city of Green, Ohio. Its airport code comes from the nearby cities of *C*anton and *Ak*ron.

name: Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport
description: Guangzhou Baiyun International opened in 2004 as a replacement for the 72-year-old airport with the same name. Its airport code comes from Guangzhou’s former English name: *Can*ton.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Jorge Wilstermann
description: Jorge Wilstermann International is named after a famous Bolivian aviator. Its aiport code honors the city of *C*ocha*b*am*b*a.

name: Cambridge Airport
description: Cambridge Airport, briefly known as Marshall Airport Cambridge UK, originally opened in 1938. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *C*am*b*rid*g*e.

name: Canberra International Airport
description: Originally an airstrip built in the 1920s, Canberra International now serves the cities of *C*an*b*e*r*ra and Queanbeyan in New South Wales.

name: Aéroport de Carcassonne
description: Sometimes called Salvaza Airport, Carcassonne Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *C*ar*c*assonne, *F*rance.

name: Calicut International Airport
description: Calicut International is named after the city of Kozhikode, *C*ali*c*ut in English. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*J*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Cocos (Keeling) Islands Airport
description: Built during World War II, Cocos (Keeling) Islands Airport is located near Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean and serves the Territory of *C*o*c*os (*K*eeling) Islands.

name: Aeropuerto Carriel Sur
description: Opened in 1968, Carriel Sur International is located in the city of *C*on*c*e*p*ción, Chile.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Maiquetia “Simón Bolívar”
description: Often called just “Maiquetía” by locals, Simón Bolívar International is named after the former Venezuelan president. Its airport code stands for *C*ara*c*a*s*.

name: Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport
description: Previously Dum Dum Aiport, Netjai Subhas Chandra Bose International was renamed in 1995 to honor the Indian freedom fighter. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Kolkata: *C*al*cu*tta.

name: Cedar City Regional Airport
description: Cedar City Regional gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *C*e*d*ar *C*ity, Utah.

name: Aéroport de Paris-Charles-de-Gaulle
description: Renamed and officially opened in 1974, France’s largest airport is named after *C*harles *d*e *G*aulle, former President and founder of the French Fifth Republic.

name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Mactan–Cebu
description: First opened in 1956, Mactan–Cebu International is located in Lapu-Lapu City and serves greater Metro *Ceb*u.

name: Chelyabinsk Airport
description: With a history dating back to the 1930s, Chelyabinsk Airport began serving international passengers in 1994. Its airport code comes from the city of *C*h*e*lyabins*k*.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Cabo Frio
description: Inaugurated in 1998, Cabo Frio International is privately operated and serves the city of *C*abo *F*rio, *B*razil.

name: Coulter Field
description: Located in the city of Bryan, *C*oulter *F*iel*d* has a long history of sport parachuting. Many have skydived at Coulter Field, include Texas Governor Rick Perry and former U.S. President George H.W. Bush.

name: Aeroporto de São Paulo/Congonhas
description: São Paulo/Congonhas Airport opened in 1936 and is named after the neighborhood where it’s located, Vila *C*on*g*on*h*as.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Soekarno–Hatta
description: Soekarno–Hatta International serves the capital city of Jakarta and honors Indonesia’s first president and vice-president. It receives its code from the *C*en*gk*areng district in the city of Tangerang, where it’s located.

name: Flughafen Köln/Bonn
description: Cologne Bonn Airport is christened after Konrad Adenauer, Germany’s first Chancellor following World War II, but its airport code comes from its home in *C*olo*gn*e.

name: Zhengzhou Xinzheng International Airport
description: Zhengzhou Xinzheng International is the principal airport serving Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan province, China. Its IATA code ‘CGO’ is derived from Zhengzhou’s former Romanization, *C*hen*g*ch*o*w.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Campo Grande
description: Opened in 1953, Campo Grande International is located in the municipality of Antônio João and is often called Antônio João Airport. It serves the city of *C*ampo *Gr*ande.

name: Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport
description: Opened in 1930 as Lovell Field, Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Cha*ttanooga.

name: Christchurch International Airport
description: Opened in 1940, Christchurch International became New Zealand’s first international airport in 1950. Located in the suburb of Harewood, its airport code comes from the city of *Ch*rist*c*hurch.

name: Aeropuerto Teniente FAP Jaime Montreuil Morales
nameEnglish: Teniente FAP Jaime Montreuil Morales Airport
description: Jaime Montreuil Morales Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Ch*i*m*bote.

name: Aéroport de Châteauroux-Centre
description: Formerly an air base, the airport is now an airline training and maintenance facility located near the town of *Ch*âteau*r*oux in central France.

name: Charleston International Airport
description: Used as a military airfield during World War II and the Korean War, Charleston International’s airport code comes from its home in *Ch*arle*s*ton, South Carolina.

name: Ciampino–Aeroporto Internazionale G. B. Pastine
description: Often called just Rome Ciampino Airport, G.B. Pastine International is named after World War I aviator, Giovan Battista Pastine. It serves the city of Rome and is located in *Cia*mpino.

name: The Eastern Iowa Airport
description: Before being renamed in 1997, The Eastern Iowa Airport was known as *C*edar Rap*id*s Municipal.

name: Shymkent International Airport
description: In its current location since 1963, Shymkent International gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name of *C*h*i*mken*t*.

name: Chippewa County International Airport
description: Formerly the Kincheloe Air Force Base, *C*h*i*ppewa Co*u*nty International is located 15 miles south of the central business district of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP José Abelardo Quiñones Gonzáles
description: José Abelardo Quiñones Gonzáles International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *C*h*i*clayo. The code is completed by an ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Aeropuerto Mayor General FAP Armando Revoredo Iglesias
nameEnglish: Mayor General FAP Armando Revoredo Iglesias Airport
description: Armando Revoredo Iglesias Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *C*a*j*amarc*a*.

name: Jeju International Airport
description: Jeju International is South Korea’s second largest airport. Its three-letter code comes from the McCune-Reischauer romanization of Jeju: *C*he*ju*.

name: North Central West Virginia Airport
description: Originally opened in 1935 as Tri-County Airport, North Central West Virginia Airport is actually located in the the city of Bridgeport, but is most associated with the city it serves: *C*lar*k*s*b*urg.

name: Chongqing Jiangbei International Airport
description: Opened in 1990, Chongqing Jiangbei International replaced the older Baishiyi Airport. Its three-letter code comes from the city’s former English name: *C*hung*k*in*g*.

name: Conakry International Airport
description: Formerly Gbessia Airport, Conakry International is the primary airport in Guinea. Its three-letter code comes from the capital city of *C*ona*k*r*y*.

name: McClellan-Palomar Airport
description: McClellan-Palomar Airport is located in northwest San Diego county and is named after George McClellan, local aviator and civic leader.  Its airport code comes from its city of *C*ar*L*sba*D*.

name: Hopkins International Airport
description: Hopkins International is named after former mayor William R. Hopkins. Its airport code honors its home in *Cle*veland.

name: Aeroportul International “Avram Iancu” Cluj
description: Founded in 1932, Cluj Avram Iancu International is named after Romanian revolutionary Avram Iancu. Its airport code comes from its home city of *Cl*u*j*-Napoca.

name: Easterwood Airport
description: Opened in 1940, Easterwood Airport is named after U.S. Navy Lt. Jesse L. Easterwood. It is owned by Texas A&M University and is located in the city of *C*o*ll*ege Station.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alfonso Bonilla Aragón
description: Formerly Palmaseca International, Cali’s airport is named after Alfonso Bonilla Aragón, local civic leader and journalist. Its airport code comes from an early nickname: *C*a*l*ipuert*o*.

name: Douglas International Airport
description: Formerly Morris Field Air Base, Douglas Airport was renamed in 1954 to honor former mayor Ben Elbert Douglas, Sr., but its airport code honors its home in *C*har*l*o*t*te.

name: Bandaranaike International Airport
description: Bandaranaike International is named after former Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike and is one of the busiest hub airports in South Asia. Its airport code honors the city it serves, *C*olo*mb*o.

name: Port Columbus International Airport
description: Opened in 1929, Port Columbus is now the second busiest airport in Ohio. Its three-letter airport code comes from its original name *C*olumbus *M*unicipal *H*angar.

name: University of Illinois Willard Airport
description: Dedicated in 1945, Willard Airport is named after former University of Illinois president, Arthur Cutts Willard. Its airport code comes from the area it serves, *C*ha*m*pa*i*gn-Urbana.

name: Mohammed V International Airport
description: Originally known as Berrechid Airfield, Mohammed V International’s airport code comes from its full name and location: *C*asablanca *M*ohammed V International Airport, *N*ouaceur.

name: Houghton County Memorial Airport
description: Houghton Country Memorial gets its airport code from the *C*anadian *M*ichigan E*x*change, an agreement between Canada, the U.S., Michigan, and Houghton County, through which the airport was constructed.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Tancredo Neves - Confins
description: Named after former Brazilian President-elect Tancredo Neves, the airport that serves the Belo Horizonte metro area is located in the municipality of *C*o*nf*ins.

name: Base aérienne 709 Cognac-Châteaubernard
description: Cognac – Châteaubernard Air Base is home to the pilot training school, Ecole de Pilotage de l'Armee de l'Air. Its three-letter code is rearranged letters from *C*o*gn*ac.

name: Kannur International Airport
description: Kannur International, located in Mattannur, serves the city of Kannur (anglicized *C*a*nn*anore) in Kerala, India.

name: Chiang Mai International Airport
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. *C*hia*n*g Mai International, a major gateway to the north of Thailand, uses that helpful ‘*X*’ in its airport code.

name: Cochin International Airport
description: Cochin International is located in the city of Kochi, previously known as Cochin. Its airport code pulls letters from the new name, *Koc*hi, but reverses them.

name: Aéroport International de Cotonou
description: Cotonou International is officially named after Beninese Cardinal Bernardin Gantin. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of *Co*t*o*nou.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Córdoba
description: The third largest airport in Argentina, Córdoba International is also called Ingeniero Aeronáutico Ambrosio L.V. Taravella Airport. It gets its three-letter code from the city of *Cór*doba.

name: Colorado Springs Airport
description: In operation since 1927, the *CO*lorado *S*prings Airport is the second busiest airport in Colorado.

name: Københavns Lufthavn, Kastrup
description: Located in the small town of Kastrup and founded in 1925, *C*o*p*en*h*agen Airport is one of the oldest civil airports in the world.

name: Cape Town International Airport
description: Opened in 1954 to replace Wingfield Aerodrome, Africa’s third busiest airport is located in the city of *C*a*p*e *T*own, South Africa.

name: Aeroporto Presidente João Suassuna
description: Presidente João Suassuna Airport gets its three-letter code from *C*am*p*ina Grande. The ‘*V*’ could come from *V*ila Nova da Rainha, the city’s former name, but is likely a filler letter.

name: Aeropuerto Central Ciudad Real
description: Built at great expense, *C*iudad Real Central Airport was previously known as Don *Q*uijote Airport and South *M*adrid Airport, but now sits unused.

name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Clark
description: Originally established as Clark Air Base by the U.S. Army in 1903, *C*la*rk* International is named after Major Harold M. Clark. It was known as Diosdado Macapagal International from 2003 until 2012.

name: Aéroport de Charleroi Bruxelles Sud
description: Brussels South Charleroi International started as a flying school in 1919. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *C*ha*rl*eroi.

name: Corpus Christi International Airport
description: Corpus Christi International opened a new six-gate terminal named Hayden W. Head Terminal in 2002. It is city-owned and available for public-use just west of *C*o*rp*us Christi, in Nueces County, Texas.

name: Yeager Airport
description: Yeager Airport is named after U.S. Army Brigadier General Chuck Yeager, but its airport code honors its home in *C*ha*r*leston, *W*est Virginia.

name: Aeroporto di Catania-Fontanarossa
description: Also known as Vincenzo Bellini Airport after the famous opera composer, *C*a*t*ani*a*–Fontanarossa Airport was the region’s first airport, built in 1924.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Rafael Núñez
description: Rafael Núñez International is named after the former Colombian president who wrote the verses for the country’s national anthem. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *C*ar*t*a*g*ena.

name: New Chitose Airport
description: Opened in 1991, New Chitose Airport replaced the original Chitose Airport. It serves the Sapporo area and at first had the three-letter code of SPK. Its current code comes from its name and the nearby city of *C*hi*t*o*s*e.

name: Chengdu Shuangliu International Airport
description: Shuangliu Airport opened in 1938 as a supplementary airfield during World War II and is now one of the busiest airports in China. Its airport code is derived from the city’s former English name: *C*heng*tu*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Federal de Bachigualato
description: Often called Culiacán Airport, Bachigualato Federal International is named after Bachigualato, the neighborhood where it’s located. Its airport code comes from *Cul*iacán, the city it serves.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Cancún
description: Cancún International is Mexico’s second busiest airport, but serves the most international traffic. Its three-letter code comes from the city of Can*cún*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Alejandro Velasco Astete
description: Alejandro Velasco Astete International is named after the Peruvian pilot first to cross the Andes in 1925. It serves the city of Cusco, often spelled *Cuz*co.

name: Altiport de Courchevel
description: Courchevel Altiport (a term used to describe mountainous aerodomes in the French Alps) serves Courchevel ski resort. Its three-letter code comes from *C*ourche*v*el, *F*rance.

name: Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport
description: Serving the greater Cincinnati metro area, Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky’s airport code comes from the nearby city of *C*o*v*in*g*ton.

name: Aeródromo de Corvo
description: Opened in 2005, Corvo Airport is located in Vila do Corvo on the island of *C*or*v*o. The letter ‘*U*’ is a phonetic replacement for the ‘O’ in Corvo.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Curitiba - Afonso Pena
description: Built in 1944 for the Brazilian Air Force, Afonso Pena International is named after Brazil’s 6th president. With the codes CUR and CUB already taken, *C*uriti*b*a subbed a ‘*W*’ for the ‘U’.

name: Maes Awyr Caerdydd
description: Started as a satellite aerodrome during World War II, Cardiff Airport gets its airport code from its home in *C*ardiff, *W*a*l*es.

name: Sân bay Quốc tế Cam Ranh
description: Originally built by the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War, Cam Ranh International serves Khanh Hoa but is located on *C*am *R*anh Bay. Its code is completed by an ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Daytona Beach International Airport
description: Started in 1930 as Sholtz Field, Daytona Beach International evolved from an uncommonly successful beach airport. Located next to Daytona International Speedway, it serves the city of *D*ayton*a* *B*each.

name: Hazrat Shahjalal International Airport
description: In 2010, Hazrat Shahjalal International was renamed to honor the Sufi saint Shah Jalal. Its airport code comes from a former spelling for the city of Dhaka: *Dac*ca.

name: Sân bay Quốc tế Đà Nẵng
description: Da Nang International is located in *Da* Nang, the largest city in central Vietnam. Its code’s last letter likely comes from Quang Nam-*Đ*a Nang, the province Da Nang belonged to before becoming an independent municipality in 1997.

name: Dallas Love Field
description: Founded and named in 1917, Love Field honors U.S. Army pilot Moss L. Love. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Dal*las.

name: Damascus International Airport
description: Inaugurated in the 1970s, Damascus International get its airport code from its home in the capital city of *Dam*ascus.

name: Julius Nyerere International Airport
description: Renamed in 2006, Julius Nyerere International honors Tanzania’s first president. It was previously named *Dar* es Salaam International after its home city.

name: James M. Cox Dayton International Airport
description: In 1952, Dayton Municipal was renamed to honor James M. Cox, former governor of Ohio. Its airport code honors its home in *Day*ton.

name: Dubuque Regional Airport
description: Dubuque Regional features two runways and serves as a general aviation and commercial airport. Its three-letter code comes from its home city of *D*u*b*u*q*ue.

name: Zračna luka Dubrovnik/Čilipi
description: Opened in 1962, Dubrovnik Airport is located in the village of Čilipi and serves the city of *D*u*b*ro*v*nik.

name: Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport
description: In 1998, Washington National Airport was renamed to honor former U.S. President Ronald Reagan. Its airport code honors its home in *D*istrict of *C*olumbi*a*.

name: Debreceni Nemzetközi Repülőtér
description: Originally opened in the 1930s, Debrecen International gets its airport code from its home in the city of *Deb*recen.

name: Jolly Grant International Airport
description: Dehradun International is located 25km from *De*hra*d*un. It’s also known as the Air Gateway of Garhwal and is important for tourism in Uttarakhand.

name: Indira Gandhi International Airport
description: Previously known as Palam Aiport, Indira Gandhi International was renamed in 1986 to honor the former Indian prime minister. Its airport code honors its home in *Del*hi.

name: Denver International Airport
description: Until 1995, Stapleton International Airport served the *Den*ver area with airport code DEN. When Stapleton closed, the new airport switched from DVX to DEN.

name: Coleman A. Young International Airport
description: Formerly Detroit City Airport, Coleman A. Young International is named after Coleman Young who served as mayor from 1974 to 1994. Its three-letter code honors the city of *Det*roit.

name: Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport
description: For decades Dallas and Fort Worth ran competing airports, but in 1969 construction finally began on a joint airport to serve the *D*allas-*F*ort *W*orth area.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Presidente Nicolau Lobato
description: Presidente Nicolau Lobato International is named after East-Timorese national hero Nicolau dos Reis Lobato. Its three-letter airport code comes from the capital city of *Dil*i.

name: Sân bay Điện Biên Phủ
description: Dien Bien Phu Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Di*e*n* Bien Phu, Vietnam.

name: Léopold Sédar Senghor International Airport
description: Formerly known as Dakar Yoff Airport, Léopold Sédar Senghor International is now named after the first President of Senegal. Located in Yoff, it serves the capital city of *D*a*k*a*r*.

name: Aéroport International de Douala
description: Douala International is the busiest airport in Cameroon. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of *D*oua*la*.

name: Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport
description: Dalian Zhoushuizi International is located in Liaoning Province and serves the city of *D*a*l*ian, *C*hina.

name: Duluth International Airport
description: Opened in 1930 as Williamson–Johnson Municipal, Duluth International was renamed in 1961. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *D*u*l*ut*h*.

name: Lien Khuong Airport
description: Located in Đức Trọng District, Lien Khuong Airport is the largest of four airports in the Central Highlands region. Its code comes from *D*a*l*at *I*nternational.

name: Domodedovo International Airport
description: Officially opened in 1965, Russia’s busiest airport serves the capital city of Moscow. It is actually located in the nearby town of *D*o*m*od*e*dovo.

name: Don Mueang International Airport
description: Originally Bangkok International, Don Mueang Airport was renamed when Suvarnabhumi Airport opened in 2006. It gave up its BKK code and received a new one derived from *D*on *M*ueang and carrying over the ‘*K*’ from the old code.

name: King Fahd International Airport
description: Opened in 1999, King Fahd International is the world’s largest airport by land area. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *D*a*mm*am.

name: Port-adhair Dhùn Dèagh
description: Opened in 1963, Dundee Airport gets its airport code from *D*u*nd*ee, Scotland’s fourth largest city.

name: Dnipropetrovsk International Airport
description: Opened in 1943, Dnipropetrovsk International Airport is located 15 km southeast from the center of the city which gave it the name and the code - *Dn*ipropetrovs*k*.

name: Aéroport de Dinard–Pleurtuit–Saint-Malo
description: Dinard–Pleurtuit–Saint-Malo Airport serves the city of Saint-Malo, but gets its three-letter airport code from the nearby commune of *D*i*n*a*r*d.

name: Hamad International Airport
description: Often called “New Doha Airport,” Hamad International opened in May of 2014, replacing *Doh*a International Airport as the primary airport for Qatar’s capital city.

name: Douglas–Charles Airport
description: Formerly named Melville Hall, Douglas–Charles Airport was renamed in 2014 to honor former Prime Ministers Rosie Douglas and Pierre Charles. It is the primary airport in *Dom*inica.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Ngurah Rai
description: Ngurah Rai International serves the tourist destination of Bali and is named for I Gusti Ngurah Rai, national hero of Indonesia. Its airport code comes from *D*en*p*a*s*ar, the capital of the island.

name: Darwin International Airport
description: In 1945, *D*a*rw*in Airport began serving non-military passengers and currently still shares a runway with RAAF Base Darwin. The airport is named after its city which honors famous naturalist Charles Darwin.

name: Robin Hood Airport Doncaster Sheffield
description: Robin Hood Airport is named after the legendary outlaw of English folklore. Its airport code comes from the rest of its name, *D*oncaster *S*heffield *A*irport.

name: Des Moines International Airport
description: Des Moines Airport was renamed “International” in 1986 to promote the presence of the U.S. Customs Service at the airport. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *D*e*s* *M*oines.

name: Flughafen Dortmund
description: Initially located in the suburb of Brackel, the airport serving the eastern Rhine-Ruhr area was moved to the city of *D*or*tm*und after World War II.

name: Shreveport Downtown Airport
description: Shreveport Downtown Airport serves the city of Shreveport along with Shreveport Regional (SHV). Its airport code comes from its close proximty to the city’s *d*own*t*ow*n*.

name: Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport
description: During World War II Detroit’s airport was known as Romulus Field, but in 1947 it was renamed to *D*etroi*t*-*W*ayne Major Airport.

name: Aerfort Bhaile Átha Cliath
description: Opened in 1940, Ireland’s busiest airport is located in its capital city of *Dub*lin.

name: Dunedin International Airport
description: Built in 1962, *Du*ne*d*in International is colloquially known as Momona Airport. It is known for its “Southern Man” sculpture, reputed to bring good luck to travelers.

name: Flughafen Düsseldorf
description: In 1998, Rhine Ruhr Airport was renamed to *Düs*seldorf International, but dropped the ‘International’ in 2013.

name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Francisco Bangoy
description: Francisco Bangoy International is named after Francisco Bangoy who donated the land on which the airport sits. Its airport code comes from its home in *D*a*v*a*o* City.

name: Al Maktoum International Airport
description: Opened in 2010, Al Maktoum International is named after Sheikh Maktoum, former Prime Minister of the UAE. It is part of *D*ubai *W*orld *C*entral, a residential and commercial complex.

name: Dubai International Airport
description: When Dubai International opened in 1960, the airport code DUB was already in use by Dublin, Ireland. *D*u*b*ai subbed an ‘X’ for the U, making its unique airport code of DXB.

name: Danbury Municipal Airport
description: Opened in 1930, Danbury Municipal is a two-runway airport in Connecticut. Its airport code comes from *D*anbu*r*y, with an added ‘*X*’ as a filler letter once codes switched from two letters to three.

name: Dushanbe International Airport
description: Built in 1924, Dushanbe International was the first airport in Tajikistan. Until 1929, the city of Dushanbe was known in Russian as *Dyu*shambe, explaining its three-letter code of DYU.

name: Aéroport de Dzaoudzi-Pamandzi
description: Dzaoudzi-Pamandzi International is the only airport in Mayotte, located on the island of Pamanzi and serving the commune of *Dza*oudzi.

name: Aeropuerto de San Sebastián
description: San Sebastián Airport is actually located in the municipality of Hondarribia, but gets its three-letter code from the city of San S*e*b*as*tián.

name: Pangborn Memorial Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Pangborn Memorial, located in the city of W*e*n*at*chee, opted for other letters to form EAT.

name: Entebbe International Airport
description: Constructed in the late 1920s, Entebbe International is the primary international airport in Uganda. It serves the cities of *E*nte*bb*e and Kampala.

name: Erbil International Airport
description: Featuring the tenth longest runway in the world, *E*r*b*i*l* International opened its doors in 2010 next door to the original Erbil airport, built during the 1970s.

name: Northwest Florida Beaches International Airport
description: Originally the airport wanted the three-letter code TFB for “The Florida Beaches”, but it was already taken. When going through a list of available codes, the selection group joked ECP could stand for “*E*veryone *C*an *P*arty” and it stuck.

name: Port-adhair Dhùn Èideann
description: Previously the location for Turnhouse Aerodrome and RAF Turnhouse airfield, Scotland’s busiest airport is located in the city of *Edi*nburgh.

name: Aéroport de Bergerac Dordogne Périgord
description: EGC is located south-southeast of B*e*r*g*era*c*, a commune of the Dordogne department (formerly the Périgord province) in the Aquitaine region of France.

name: Eagle County Regional Airport
description: Eagle County Regional is sometimes called Vail/Eagle Airport, serving the ski resorts in Vail and Beaver Creek. Its airport code comes from its home in *E*a*g*l*e* County.

name: Vliegbasis Eindhoven
description: Eindhoven Airport is also a military airbase, hosting the European Air Transport Command and the Movement Coordination Centre Europe. Its airport code comes from its home in *Ein*dhoven.

name: El Paso International Airport
description: Built in 1929 as Standard Airport, El Paso International gets its three-letter code from its home city of *El* *P*aso.

name: East Midlands Airport
description: Originally a Royal Air Force station, *E*ast *M*idlands *A*irport is located in Castle Donington in the East Midlands of England.

name: Enschede Vliegbasis Twente
description: Originally opened in 1931, *Ens*chede Airport Twente no longer serves military or passenger flights. Traffic is limited to regional flying clubs for recreational use.

name: Akanu Ibiam International Airport
description: The airport is named after the late Akanu Ibiam (1906-1995), a medical doctor and statesman who hailed from Afikpo in Ebonyi State. Its code honors its home in *Enu*gu.

name: Aeropuerto Olaya Herrera
description: Originally opened in 1932, Olaya Herrera Airport is named after and gets its three-letter code from former Colombian president, *E*nrique *O*laya *H*errera.

name: Erie International Airport
description: Also known as Tom Ridge Field, Erie International is a public airport serving the city of *Eri*e, Pennsylvania.

name: Esenboğa Uluslararası Havalimanı
description: Esenboğa International serves the city of Ankara, but gets its name and three-letter code from the nearby village of *Es*en*b*oğa which means “Windflowing Bull.”

name: Eugene Airport
description: Eugene Airport is also known as Mahlon Sweet Field, named after Mahlon Sweet, an early supporter of the airport’s construction. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of *Eug*ene.

name: F. D. Roosevelt Airport
description: Originally Golden Rock Airport, F. D. Roosevelt Airport was renamed in 1946. It serves tourists to the dormant volcano “The Quill” and gets its code from Sint *Eu*statius, completed with an ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Zvart'nots' Mijazgayin Odanavakayan
description: Armenia’s busiest airport get its name from its home in Zvartnots, but its airport code comes from the nearby capital city of Yer*ev*a*n*.

name: Liberty International Airport
description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. N*ew*a*r*k, then, used the other letters in its name to make EWR.

name: Exeter International Airport
description: Opened in 1937, Exeter International is located at Clyst Honiton and serves the city of *Ex*e*t*er in Devon.

name: Key West International Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. K*ey* *W*est International, featuring one of the shortest runways in the U.S., opted for EYW.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Ministro Pistarini
description: Named after former Minister of Public Works, Juan Pistarini, the Buenos Aires airport’s code comes from *Eze*iza Partido where the airport is located.

name: Vága Floghavn
description: Built on the island of Vágar by the British Army during WWII, Vágar Airport is the only airport in the *Fa*ro*e* Islands.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Faro
description: Also known as Algarve Airport, Faro International opened in 1966. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Fa*r*o*.

name: Hector International Airport
description: Hector International is named after Martin Hector, local businessman who donated the land on which the aiport now sits. It serves the nearby cities of *Far*go and Moorhead.

name: Fresno Yosemite International Airport
description: Located about 60 miles south of its namesake national park, Fresno Yosemite International Airport was renamed in 1947 from *F*resno *A*ir *T*erminal.

name: Glacier Park International Airport
description: Before being renamed to honor Montana’s natural beauty, Glacier Park International was known as *F*lathead *C*ounty *A*irport.

name: Fiumicino – Aeroporto Internazionale Leonardo da Vinci
description: Rome’s international airport honors the original Renaissance man, Leonardo da Vinci. It is often referred to as just *F*iumi*c*in*o* Airport, explaining its airport code of FCO.

name: Aéroport International Martinique Aimé Césaire
description: Martinique International is named after Aimé Césaire, French author and politician. Located in the suburb of Le Lamentin, it serves the capital city of *F*ort-*d*e-*F*rance.

name: Flughafen Friedrichshafen
description: Established in 1915, Friedrichshafen Airport was the site of the very first Zeppelin passenger flights. Its three-letter code honors the city of *F*rie*d*richs*h*afen.

name: Fes–Saïss Airport
description: Fes–Saïss Airport, or just Saïss Airport, serves the second-largest city in Morocco, Fes. It gets its airport code from the city’s alternate spelling: *Fez*.

name: First Flight Airport
description: As its name suggests, *F*irst *F*light *A*irport is the location where in 1903 the Wright Brothers first achieved heavier-than-air flight. It is also the location of the Wright Brothers National Memorial.

name: Fair Isle Airport
description: *F*air *I*sl*e* Airport features a single runway and no hangars and is often used for flight instruction.

name: N'Djili International Airport
description: N’Djili International is named after the nearby Ndjili River. The airport was built while the Congo was under Belgian rule, so it is said its airport code comes from the word *F*lem*i*s*h*.

name: Flughafen Karlsruhe/Baden-Baden
description: Originally used as a military airfield, *F*lughafen *K*arlsruhe/*B*aden-Baden is located in the town of Rheinmünster and is a part of Baden Airpark.

name: Venango Regional Airport
description: Venango Regional is also known as Chess Lamberton Field, named after the grandson of Judge Robert Lamberton, founder of the first bank in Venango County. Its airport code comes from the nearby town of *F*ran*kl*in.

name: Flagstaff Pulliam Airport
description: Flagstaff Pulliam Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the Arizona city of *Fl*a*g*staff.

name: Fort Lauderdale–Hollywood International Airport
description: Formerly Broward County Airport, Fort Lauderdale–Hollywood International serves the greater Miami area, situated between the cities of *F*ort *L*auderda*l*e and Hollywood, Florida.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Florianópolis–Hercílio Luz
description: Florianópolis Airport’s name honors former governor Hercílio Luz, but its airport code honors its home in *Fl*oria*n*ópolis.

name: Aeroporto di Firenze-Peretola
description: Formally known as Amerigo Vespucci Airport after the Italian cartographer, *Fl*o*r*ence Airport is located in the suburb of Peretola.

name: Aeroporto das Flores
description: Inaugurated in 1972, Flores Airport is located on the island of Flores, Portuguese for “*Fl*o*w*ers.”

name: Allgäu-Airport Memmingen
description: Originally a military airfield built in 1935, Memmingen Airport gets its three-letter code from its German translation: *F*lughafen *M*e*m*mingen.

name: Flughafen Münster/Osnabrück
description: Located in the town of Greven, *F*lughafen *M*ünster *O*snabrück is a minor airport that serves the northern part of North Rhine-Westphalia and the surrounding areas since 1974.

name: Lungi International Airport
description: Lungi International is located across the Sierra Leone River from Freetown in the town of Lungi. Its airport code stands for *F*reetow*n* *A*irport.

name: Aeroporto da Madeira Cristiano Ronaldo
description: Opened in 1964, Madeira Airport is the only airport in the Portuguese archipelago Madeira in the Atlantic Ocean. It serves the capital city of *F*u*nc*hal.

name: Bishop International Airport
description: Bishop International is named after former General Motors board member, Arthur Bishop, whose farmland later became the airport grounds. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *F*li*nt*.

name: Fort Dodge Regional Airport
description: Fort Dodge Regional gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *Fo*rt *D*odge, Iowa.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Pinto Martins
description: Formerly Cocorote Aiport, Pinto Martins International was renamed in 1952 to honor Euclides Pinto Martins, Brazilian aviation pioneer. Its airport code honors its home in *For*taleza.

name: Flughafen Frankfurt am Main
description: Opened commercially in 1936, Germany’s busiest airport is located in the city of *Fra*nkfurt.

name: Manas International Airport
description: Opened in 1974, Manas International is named after Manas, the epic hero of the Kyrgyz people. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Bishkek’s former name: *Fru*nze.

name: Aéroport Figari-Sud Corse
description: Opened in 1975, Figari–Sud Corse Airport is located on the island of Corsica near the commune of Porto-Vecchio. It is also referred to as *F*igari *S*outh *C*orsica Airport.

name: Sioux Falls Regional Airport
description: Sioux Falls Regional is also known as Joe *F*o*s*s Fiel*d*, named after aviator and Medal of Honor recipient Joe Foss.

name: Aéroport de Saint-Pierre
description: Opened in 1999, Saint-Pierre Airport serves the city of Saint-Pierre, capital of the overseas collectivity of *F*rance, *S*aint *P*ierre and Miquelon.

name: Shizuoka Airport
description: Located in Makinohara and Shimada, Shizuoka Airport is often called Mt. *F*uji *S*hi*z*uoka Airport.

name: Aeropuerto de Fuerteventura
description: Opened in 1969 and often referred to as El Matorral Airport, Fuerteventura Airport serves the city of Puerto del Rosario and the island of *Fue*rteventura.

name: Fukuoka Airport
description: Originally built in 1943 and formerly known as Mushiroda Airfield and Itazuke Air Base, Fukuoka Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of *Fuk*uoka.

name: Funafuti International Airport
description: Originally built by the U.S. Navy during World War II, Funafuti International now serves the capital city of *Fun*afuti with three flights per week.

name: Fort Wayne International Airport
description: Renamed in 1991, Fort Wayne International was previously named Baer Field, after Lieutenant Paul Baer, the first flying ace in U.S. military history. Its airport code honors the city of *F*ort *Wa*yne.

name: Gan International Airport
description: Used as a military air base until 1976, Gan International gets its airport code from its home on the island of *Gan* in Addu Atoll.

name: Lokpriya Gopinath Bordoloi International Airport
description: Lokpriya Gopinath Bordoloi International is named after the freedom fighter and former first Chief Minister of its home state, Assam. Its airport code comes from a former spelling of Guwahati: *Gau*hati.

name: Sir Seretse Khama International Airport
description: Opened in 1984, Sir Seretse Khama International is named after the first President of Botswana. Its three-letter airport code comes from the capital city of *G*a*b*oron*e*.

name: Guernsey Airport
description: With services started in 1946, Guernsey Airport is located in the parish of Forest. It is the only airport in *G*uernsey in the *C*hannel *I*slands.

name: Owen Roberts International Airport
description: Owen Roberts International is named after “The Commander” Owen Roberts, aviator and founder of Caribbean International Airways. Its airport code comes from its location on the island of *G*rand *C*ay*m*an.

name: Grand Canyon West Airport
description: Located 60 miles from Peach Springs on the Hualapai Indian Reservation, *G*rand *C*anyon *W*est Airport serves visitors to the canyon and the famous Grand Canyon Skywalk.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Guadalajara
description: Guadalajara International’s ceremonial name honors Miguel Hidalgo, leader of the Mexican War of Independence. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *G*ua*d*a*l*ajara.

name: Port Lotniczy Gdańsk im. Lecha Wałęsy
description: Opened in 1974, Gdańsk Lech Walesa Airport is named after Lech Walesa, former Polish president. Its airport code honors its home city of *Gd*a*n*sk.

name: Spokane International Airport
description: Before being renamed in 1960, Spokane International was known as *Ge*i*g*er Field, honoring U.S. Army aviator, Major Harold Geiger.

name: Cheddi Jagan International Airport
description: Opened in 1941 by the U.S. Army as Atkinson Field, Cheddi Jagan International was renamed in 1997 in honor of the former President. Located in the town of Timehri, it serves the capital city of *Geo*rgetown.

name: East Texas Regional Airport
description: Host to the annual Great Texas Balloon Race, East Texas Regional gets its code from its location and previous name: *G*re*gg* County Airport.

name: Exuma International Airport
description: Exuma International is located on the island of Great Exuma near the city of Moss Town. Its airport code comes from the Exuma capital city of *G*eor*g*e *T*own.

name: Gibraltar International Airport
description: Gibraltar International is one of the “Most Extreme Airports” due to Winston Churchill Avenue directly intersecting the runway. Its airport code comes from its location in *Gib*raltar.

name: Aeroporto Internacional do Galeão–Antonio Carlos Jobim
description: Formerly known as Galeão Air Force Base, Galeão International was created in 1941 on *G*overnador *I*sland’s *G*aleão Beach in Rio de Janeiro.

name: King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Airport
description: Named after the former King of Saudi Arabia, King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz is located in the city of Jizan, alternately spelled *Giz*an.

name: Grand Junction Regional Airport
description: *G*rand *J*unc*t*ion Regional is also called Walker Field, named after Walter Walker, a local publisher who helped raise funding and support for the airport’s development.

name: Port-adhair Eadar-nàiseanta Ghlaschu
