description: Known as HMS Sanderling during World War II and later as Glasgow Abbotsinch Airport, Scotland’s second busiest airport honors its home in *Gla*sgow.

name: Gloucestershire Airport
description: Previously named Staverton Airport, Gloucestershire Airport originally opened in 1931 and serves the city of *Glo*ucester.

name: Gelephu Airport
description: Inaugurated in 2012, Gelephu Airport has been closed until a new terminal and control tower can be built. Its airport code comes from its home near the town of *G*e*l*eph*u* in Sarpang District.

name: Gimpo International Airport
description: *G*i*mp*o International Airport, located in Gangseo-gu of Seoul, was the main airport for Seoul and South Korea until being replaced by Incheon International Airport in 2011.

name: Greenville Downtown Airport
description: Originally built in 1928 it was known as *G*reenville *Mu*nicipal Airport, and was the origination of Lynyrd Skynyrd’s fatal flight in 1977.

name: Aeropuerto de La Gomera
description: La Gomera airport is located near the town of Playa Santiago on the island of La *G*o*m*era. The ‘Z‘ in its code could come from the province of Santa Cru*z* de Tenerife, but is likely a filler letter.

name: Maurice Bishop International Airport
description: Formerly Point Salines Airport, Maurice Bishop International was renamed in 2009 in honor of Maurice Bishop, former Prime Minister of *G*re*n*a*d*a.

name: Gainesville Regional Airport
description: Gainesville Regional, renamed in 1977, was previously known as John R. Alison Airport. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *G*ai*n*es*v*ille, Florida.

name: Aeroporto di Genova
description: Also called Cristoforo Colombo Airport, Genoa Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of *G*en*oa*.

name: Goa International Airport
description: Goa Airport is located in the city of Dabolim and is the only airport in the state. Its airport code comes from its name, *Go*a *I*nternational.

name: Strigino Nizhny Novgorod International Airport
description: Colloquially called Nizhny Airport, Strigino International gets its code from Nizhny Novgorod’s former name of *Go*rky. The ‘*J*’ isn’t as clear and is likely a filler letter.

name: Golmud Airport
description: China’s Goldmud Airport gets its three-letter code from the city it serves: *Go*lmud of *Q*inghai province.

name: Göteborg Landvetter Airport
description: Originally opened in 1977, Göteborg Landvetter Airport is Sweden’s second-largest airport and gets its airport code from the city it serves: *Got*henburg.

name: Gove Airport
description: Built during World War II as RAAF Base Gove, Gove Airport serves the city of Nhulunbuy and several Aboriginal communities. It gets its name and airport code from its home on the *Gov*e Peninsula.

name: Seymour Airport
description: Also known as Galapagos Ecological Airport, this airport gets its name from its home in the *G*ala*P*ago*S* Islands on the island of Baltra.

name: Gulfport–Biloxi International Airport
description: Built in 1942 and named Gulfport Army Airfield, Gulfport–Biloxi International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *G*ulf*p*or*t*.

name: Austin Straubel International Airport
description: Austin Straubel International is named after U.S. Army Air Corps Lt. Col. Austin Straubel, the first Brown County aviator to die while in service. Its code comes from the city of *Gr*een *B*ay.

name: Killeen–Fort Hood Regional Airport
description: Killeen–Fort Hood Regional shares its location and airport code with Robert *Gr*ay Army Airfield and serves the city of *K*illeen.

name: Aeropuerto de Girona-Costa Brava
description: Built in 1965 and located near the village of Vilobí d'Onyar, Girona–Costa Brava Airport gets its code from the city of *G*i*ro*na.

name: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
description: In December of 1999, Kent County International Airport was renamed to honor former President Gerald R. Ford. Its airport code honors its home in *Gr*and *R*apids.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Guarulhos–Governador André Franco Montoro
nameEnglish: Guarulhos–Governador André Franco Montoro International Airport
description: The São Paulo Airport’s name honors former governor André Franco Montoro, but its airport code honors its home in *G*ua*ru*lhos.

name: Aeroporto de Graciosa
description: Inaugurated in 1980, Graciosa Airport is located near Santa Cruz on the island of *Gr*aciosa. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*W*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Aeropuerto Federico García Lorca Granada-Jaén
description: Named after Spanish poet Federico García Lorca, Granada Airport is located near Chauchina and serves *Gr*anada. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Flughafen Graz
description: Originally constructed in 1913, Graz Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of *Gr*a*z*, Austria.

name: Piedmont Triad International Airport
description: Often called PTI, Piedmont Triad International dates back to the late 1920s and serves the Piedmont Triad area of North Carolina including the cities of *G*reen*s*bor*o*, High Point, and Winston-Salem.

name: Greenville–Spartanburg International Airport
description: Located in Greer and often called Roger Milliken Field, Greenville–Spartanburg International’s code comes from *G*reenville and *Sp*artanburg, the two cities it serves.

name: Gustavus Airport
description: There are no roads to the small city of *G*u*ST*avus, so the only way in is by plane or boat.

name: Golden Triangle Regional Airport
description: Golden Triangle Regional Airport serves the *G*olden *Tr*iangle region of Mississippi, made by the three cities of Columbus, Starkville, and West Point.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional La Aurora
description: La Aurora International was developed as *Gua*temala City Air Base by the U.S. Army Air Forces during World War II. In 1949, the base was closed and handed over to Guatemala. Today it is the primary airport in Guatemala.

name: Gunnison–Crested Butte Regional Airport
description: Gunnison–Crested Butte Regional Airport is a county-owned public airport that serves the *Gu*nnison *C*ounty valley and nearby Crested Butte ski resort in Colorado.

name: Antonio B. Won Pat International Airport
description: Originally built in 1943 by the Japanese Navy, Antonio B. Won Pat International gets its airport code from its home on the island of *Gu*a*m*.

name: Gurney Airport
description: Originally built by the U.S. Army during World War II, Gurney Airport was named after RAAF Squadron Leader C.R. *Gur*ney and now serves the city of Alotau.

name: ATMA Atyrau Airport
description: Atyrau Airport is the lowest commercial aiport in the world at 22m below sea level. Its three-letter code comes from the city’s former name of *Gu*ryev, with a ‘*W*’ replacing the letter ‘V’.

name: Aéroport international de Genève
description: Started in 1919, Geneva International is partially located in both the municipalities of Meyrin and Le Grand-Saconnex. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, *G*ene*va*.

name: Heydar Aliyev International Airport
description: In 2004, Baku’s airport was renamed and changed its airport code from BAK to GYD in honor of former Azerbaijan President Heydar Aliyev, sometimes spelled *G*a*yd*ar Aliev.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional José Joaquín de Olmedo
description: José Joaquín de Olmedo International is named after former President José Joaquín de Olmedo. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *G*ua*y*aquil, *E*cuador.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Santa Genoveva
description: Inaugurated in 1955, Santa Genoveva International is named after Genoveva Torres Morales and its code comes from *G*oiâ*n*ia. The ‘*Y*’ could come from Go*y*az, Goiás state’s former name, but it is likely a filler letter.

name: Yasser Arafat International Airport
description: Opened in 1998, Yasser Arafat International was closed and abandoned in 2000 after its radar station and control tower were bombed. Its airport code comes from its home in the *G*a*za* Strip.

name: Prince Said Ibrahim International Airport
description: Prince Said Ibrahim International is named after the former President of Comoros and serves the capital city of Moroni. Its airport code comes from the village of *Hah*aya where it’s located.

name: Flughafen Hannover-Langenhagen
description: Located in the town of Langenhagen, Hannover Airport’s code combines its home in *Ha*nnover and German aviator Karl *J*atho, who also lends his name to one of the terminals.

name: Haikou Meilan International Airport
description: Haikou Meilan International is the airport serving *Ha*i*k*ou, the capital of Hainan Province, China.

name: Flughafen Hamburg Helmut Schmidt
description: Hamburg Airport was opened in January of 1911 and serves Germany’s second-largest city, *Ham*burg.

name: Nội Bài International Airport
description: Opened in 1978, Noi Bai International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *Han*oi.

name: Hanimaadhoo International Airport
description: Upgraded to an international airport in 2012, Hanimaadhoo Airport is located in Haa Dhaalu Atoll. Its airport code comes from the island of *Ha*nimaadhoo, plus a helpful ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Aeropuerto José Martí
description: Originally Rancho-Boyeros Airport, José Martí International is named after Cuban national hero and poet, José Martí. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Hav*ana.

name: Hat Yai International Airport
description: Hat Yai International is an airport in southern Thailand near the city of Hat Yai. Its code comes from an alternate spelling, *H*aa*d* *Y*ai.

name: Helsinki-Vantaan lentoasema
description: Located in the city of Vantaa, Finland’s busiest airport was originally built for the 1952 Summer Olympics in *Hel*sinki.

name: Heraklion International Airport, Nikos Kazantzakis
description: Often referred to as Nikos Kazantzakis Airport, *Her*aklion International is Greece’s second largest airport and serves the island of Crete.

name: Hammerfest lufthavn
description: Opened in 1974, Hammerfest Airport is Norway’s third-busiest regional airport and serves *H*ammer*f*es*t*.

name: Hargeisa Egal International Airport
description: Hargeisa Egal International is named after Muhammad Haji Ibrahim Egal, former Prime Minister of Somalia. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *H*ar*g*eis*a*.

name: Hangzhou Xiaoshan International Airport
description: Originally opened in 2000 and replacing Hangzhou Jianqiao Airport, Hangzhou Xiaoshan International gets its airport code from its home in *H*an*g*z*h*ou.

name: Flughafen Helgoland-Düne
description: The *H*eli*g*o*l*and Airport is situated on the small island Düne near the main island Heligoland. It serves mainly small tourist flights towards Bremerhaven and Büsum.

name: Flughafen Frankfurt-Hahn
description: Originally Hahn Air Base, Frankfurt–Hahn Airport gets its name and airport code from the nearby village of *H*a*hn* in Rhineland-Palatinate.

name: Honiara International Airport
description: Formerly known as Henderson Field after U.S. Marine Corps Major Lofton R. Henderson, Honiara International gets its airport code from the city of *H*on*i*a*r*a.

name: Hakodate Airport
description: Opened in 1961, Hakodate Airport gets its airport code from its home in the city of *H*a*k*o*d*ate.

name: Hong Kong International Airport
description: Hong Kong International is located on the island of Chek Lap Kok and is often called Chek Lap Kok Airport. Its three-letter airport code stands for *H*ong *K*on*g*.

name: Phuket International Airport
description: Phuket International is an important gateway to Thailand for tourists visiting P*h*u*k*e*t* Island. It is Thailand’s third busiest airport.

name: Bandar Udara Halim Perdanakusuma
description: Halim Perdanakusuma International is Jakarta’s primary airport for military, private, and government flights. It is named after Air Vice-Marshal and national hero Abdul *H*a*l*im *P*erdanakusuma for his service in World War II.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional General Ignacio Pesqueira García
nameEnglish: General Ignacio Pesqueira García International Airport
description: Often called just Hermosillo Airport, General Ignacio Pesqueira García International is named after Ignacio Pesqueira, 19th century Mexican army general. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *H*er*mo*sillo.

name: Tokyo International Airport
description: Up until 1952, the Tokyo Airport was officially named after Haneda, the former fishing town where it is now located. Many still call it the *H*a*n*e*d*a Airport.

name: Daniel K. Inouye International Airport
description: Honolulu International was recently renamed to honor Daniel K. Inouye, U.S. Senator and Medal of Honor recipient. Its airport code honors its home in *H*o*n*o*l*ulu.

name: Hana Airport
description: Hana Airport is a single runway located near the town of *H*a*n*a, on the east shore of *M*aui.

name: Al-Ahsa International Airport
description: Al-Ahsa International is a single runway airport that serves the city of Al-Ahsa, also known as *Hof*uf.

name: Frank País Airport
description: Originally a postal airport which opened in 1943, Frank País Airport is now home to the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces Eastern Command. The airport gets its code from *Ho*l*g*uín, the city in which it’s located.

name: Aeroporto Internacional da Horta
description: Inaugurated in 1971 and rennovated in 2001, Horta International is located in Castelo Branco on Faial Island and serves the city of *Hor*ta.

name: Memorial Field Airport
description: Memorial Field Airport gets its three-letter airport code from the city of *Hot* Springs and serves the nearby Hot Springs National Park.

name: William P. Hobby Airport
description: Once named after aviator Howard Hughes, *Hou*ston’s oldest commercial airport was renamed in 1967 to honor former Texas governor William P. Hobby.

name: Ørsta–Volda lufthavn, Hovden
description: Ørsta–Volda Airport is located between the cities of Ørsta and Volda, but gets its three-letter code from the nearby villge of *Hov*den.

name: Sân bay Quốc tế Cát Bi
description: Undergoing rennovations in 2015, Cat Bi International gets its airport code from its home in *H*ai *Ph*ong.

name: Westchester County Airport
description: Built during World War II for the Air National Guard, Westchester County Airport gets its airport code from three Westchester towns: *H*arrison, *P*urchase, and *N*orth Castle.

name: Bowerman Airport
description: Originally built during World War II, Bowerman Airport is named after Lt. Robert C. Bowerman, U.S. Air Force pilot. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *H*o*q*uia*m*.

name: Harare International Airport
description: Opened in 1957 as Salisbury Airport, Harare International serves the city of *H*ara*re* in Zimbabwe.

name: Hurghada International Airport
description: Hurghada International is the second busiest airport in Egypt and gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *H*u*rg*hada.

name: Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport
description: Mattala Rajapaksa International is named after the Rajapaksas, a prominent political family. Its airport codes comes from its location near *H*ambantota, S*ri* Lanka.

name: Valley International Airport
description: Formerly Harlingen Air Force Base, Valley International is now the second busiest airport in the Rio Grande Valley. Its three-letter code honors its home in *H*a*rl*ingen.

name: Huntsville International Airport
description: Opened in 1967, Huntsville International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *H*unt*sv*ille.

name: Terre Haute International Airport
description: Before it was renamed, Terre Haute International was known as *Hu*lman *F*ield, named after Anton “Tony” Hulman, Jr. who donated the land for the airport’s construction.

name: Huahine – Fare Airport
description: Huahine – Fare Airport is located in the commune of Fare and serves the city of *Hu*a*h*ine in French Polynesia.

name: Aeropuerto Alférez FAP David Figueroa Fernandini
nameEnglish: Alférez FAP David Figueroa Fernandini Airport
description: Serving primarily private and charter flights, David Figueroa Fernandini Airport get its three-letter code from the city of *Hu*án*u*co.

name: Humberside Airport
description: Humberside Airport is an international airport situated in the east of England. Previously Kirmington Airport, it was renamed in 1964 to *Hu*mberside. With the code HUM already taken, it borrows a ‘*Y*’ from its region of Yorkshire.

name: Barnstable Municipal Airport
description: Founded in 1928, Barnstable Municipal is also called Boardman/Polando Field, named after aviators Russell Boardman and John Polando. It serves Cape Cod and is located in the village of *Hya*nnis in Barnstable.

name: Rajiv Gandhi International Airport
description: Rajiv Gandhi International was named to honor the former Indian prime minister. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Hyd*erabad.

name: Dulles International Airport
description: *D*ulles *I*nternational *A*irport’s three-letter code was once DIA. When hand-written, it was often misread as DCA, another Washington airport. It was reversed to IAD to avoid confusion.

name: George Bush Intercontinental Airport
description: In 1997 the airport was renamed after former President George H.W. Bush, but was previously known as *I*ntercontinental *A*irport *H*ouston.

name: Aeropuerto de Ibiza
description: First established as a military airfield during the Spanish Civil War, Ibiza Airport is located in *Ib*i*z*a and serves the Balearic Islands.

name: Incheon International Airport
description: The airport that serves the Seoul Metro Area is actually located on a man-made piece of land between Yeongjong and Yongyu islands, west of *I*n*c*heo*n*’s city center.

name: Dwight D. Eisenhower National Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Formerly named Mid-Continent Airport, W*ic*hi*t*a opted for ICT.

name: Idaho Falls Regional Airport
description: Owned by the city of *Ida*ho Falls and formerly known as Fanning Field, Idaho Falls Regional’s current terminal was built in 1959 and has been remodeled several times since.

name: Devi Ahilyabai Holkar Airport
description: Devi Ahilyabai Holkar is named after Maharani Ahilya Bai Holkar, Holkar Queen of the Maratha Empire. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *I*n*d*o*r*e.

name: Kyiv International Airport
description: Started in 1923 as a military airfield, Kyiv International’s terminal building wasn’t built until 1949. Located in the neighborhood of Zhuliany, its airport code comes from the capital city of K*iev*.

name: Laughlin/Bullhead International Airport
description: Laughlin/Bullhead International is located in Bullhead City, Arizona, but also serves Laughlin, Nevada. The airport claims its three-letter code stands for *I*nternational *F*un *P*lace.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Foz do Iguaçu/Cataratas
description: Foz do Iguaçu International is named after Iguazu Falls (Cataratas do Iguaçu) and gets its airport code from the city of Foz do *Igu*açu.

name: Wright Brothers Field
description: In April 2021, NASA’s Ingenuity Mars Helicopter took the first powered, controlled flight on another planet. The location was named after the Wright Brothers, with a code for *I*n*g*enuit*y*.

name: Tehran Imam Khomeini International Airport
description: Located in Ahmadabad and serving the city of Tehran, *I*mam *K*homeini *A*irport is named after Ruhollah Khomeini, leader of the 1979 Iranian Revolution.

name: Aeroport Lleida-Alguaire
description: Opened in 2010, Lleida-Alguaire Airport is located in Alguaire and serves Lleida. With airport code LLE already taken, it uses ILD which comes from the city’s historic name of *Il*er*d*a.

name: Indianapolis International Airport
description: Before being renamed in 1976, Indianapolis International was called Weir-Cook Municipal, honoring World War I flying ace Colonel Harvey Weir-Cook. Its airport code honors its home in *Ind*ianapolis.

name: Flughafen Innsbruck
description: Opened in 1925, Innsbruck airport (often called Kranebitten Airport) serves Western Austria and the city of *Inn*sbruck. It is very popular in winter for skiers visiting St. Anton in the Tyrol region.

name: Nauru International Airport
description: Built during World War II under Japanese occupation, Nauru International is the only airport on the *I*sland of *N*aur*u*.

name: Port-adhair Inbhir Nis
description: Originally built in 1940 as a Royal Air Force station, Inverness Airport is located in Dalcross, Highland and serves the city of *Inv*erness.

name: Isle of Man Airport
description: Started as an airfield in 1928, *I*sle *o*f *M*an Airport is located in Ronaldsway and is often referred to as Ronaldsway Airport.

name: Mataveri International Airport
description: The most remote airport in the world, Mataveri International serves as the main entry point for people visiting or living on Easter Island. Its airport code comes from the Spanish name for Easter Island, *I*sla de *P*as*c*ua.

name: Sultan Azlan Shah Airport
description: Sultan Azlan Shah Airport serves *Ip*o*h*, a city in the state of Perak, Malaysia.

name: Aeroporto da Usiminas
description: Usiminas Airport is owned by and named after Usiminas, a Brazilian steel manufacturer. Located in Santana do Paraíso, its airport code comes from the city it serves, *Ip*ati*n*ga.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Diego Aracena
description: Sharing a runway with Los Cóndores Air Base, Diego Aracena International gets its airport code from its home city of *Iq*ui*q*ue.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Coronel FAP Francisco Secada Vignetta
description: Coronel FAP Francisco Secada Vignetta International is one of the main gateways to the Peruvian Amazon Rainforest. Its airport code comes from the city of *Iq*ui*t*os.

name: Benazir Bhutto International Airport
description: Renamed in 2008, Benazir Bhutto International honors the former prime minister of Pakistan. Its airport code honors its home in the twin cities of Rawalpindi and *Is*lama*b*ad.

name: St Mary’s Airport
description: Previously High Cross Farm and officially opened in 1939, St Mary’s Airport is located in St Mary’s in the *I*sles of *Sc*illy near Cornwall.

name: Istanbul Atatürk Havalimanı
description: In 2019, *Is*tanbu*l* Atatürk Airport’s code was changed from IST to ISL and no longer serves commercial passenger flights.

name: Long Island MacArthur Airport
description: Long Island Airport got its start in the 1940s and is named after U.S. Army General Douglas MacArthur. Its airport code comes from its original name of *Is*li*p* Airport.

name: Istanbul Airport
description: In 2019, all commercial flights were transfered from Istanbul Atatürk Airport to the newly running *Ist*anbul Airport.

name: Osaka International Airport
description: Formerly Itami Airport, Osaka International was renamed following its return to Japanese control in 1959. While it serves Osaka, it is actually located in the city of *It*a*m*i.

name: Hilo International Airport
description: One theory about ITO says it was named after an early station manager, Mr. Ito. Though with HIL and ILO already taken, Hilo International likely took its three-letter code from the nickname H*i*lo *To*wn.

name: Ivanovo Yuzhny Airport
description: Ivanovo Yuzhny Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *I*v*a*novo. Unable to use the ‘V’, it swapped in a helpful filler ‘*W*’.

name: Agartala Airport
description: Agartala Airport is named after the capital of Tripura state in India. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, plus the city of *A*gartala.

name: Bagdogra Airport
description: Located in the town of Siliguri, Bagdogra Airport serves the Darjeeling district of West Bengal. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, plus the city of *B*agdogra.

name: Chandigarh International Airport
description: Chandigarh International is named after the union territory in northern India, also known as “The City Beautiful.” Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, plus the city of *C*handigarh.

name: Madurai Airport
description: Madurai Airport was established in 1957, after serving as a military airfield. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, plus the city of *M*adurai.

name: Veer Savarkar International Airport
description: Veer Savarkar International is named after the Indian freedom activist Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. Its airport code comes from the new code series for India issued by IATA, *IX*, with the letter *Z* as filler.

name: Jackson Hole Airport
description: Wyoming’s busiest airport, the only commercial airport located inside a U.S. national park, gets its airport code from the nearby town of *Jac*kson.

name: Jaipur International Airport
description: Jaipur International is the only international airport in the state of Rajasthan. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Jai*pur.

name: Aeropuerto Francisco Carlé
description: Francisco Carlé Airport serves the city of *Jau*ja and its surrounding cities. Its airport code honors its home city.

name: Jacksonville International Airport
description: Jacksonville International’s three-letter code is *JAX*, a commonly used abbreviation for the city of Jacksonville, used by residents, local businesses, and services.

name: King Abdulaziz International Airport
description: King Abdulaziz International is named after the first monarch of Saudi Arabia, and because of its proximity to Makkah, is best known for its spacious Hajj terminal. Its airport code honors the city of *Jed*dah.

name: Jersey Airport
description: Opened by The States of Jersey in 1937, Jersey Airport serves the Bailiwick of *Jer*sey in the Channel Islands. It serves about 1.4 million passengers annually.

name: John F. Kennedy International Airport
description: In 1963, Idlewild Airport was renamed in dedication to *J*ohn *F*. *K*ennedy. Unlike many other airports, it also changed its three-letter airport code from IDL to JFK.

name: Kapalua Airport
description: Kapalua Airport serves the Kapalua Resort area and the nearby town of Lahaina. Its airport code comes from *J*ohn *H*enry *M*agoon, the president of Hawaiian Airlines when the airport was being developed.

name: Aéroport international de Djibouti–Ambouli
description: Opened in 1948, Djibouti–Ambouli International is located in the town of Ambouli and serves D*jib*outi City.

name: Quanzhou Jinjiang International Airport
description: Quanzhou Jinjiang International is a dual-use military and public airport located in *J*in*j*ia*n*g that serves the larger city of Quanzhou in Fujian, China.

name: O. R. Tambo International Airport
description: Previously *J*oha*n*nes*b*urg International, O. R. Tambo International was renamed in 2006 to honor Oliver Tambo, former African National Congress President.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Adisucipto
description: Adisucipto International serves the Yogyakarta (previously anglicized *Jog*jakarta) metro area, and honors Agustinus Adisucipto, national hero and early figure in the Indonesian Air Force.

name: Aeroporto de Joinville-Lauro Carneiro de Loyola
description: Lauro Carneiro de Loyola Airport is named after Lauro Falcão Carneiro, local entrepreneur and politician. Its three-letter code comes from the city of *Joi*nville.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Presidente Castro Pinto
description: Presidente Castro Pinto International is named after the former Governor of Paraíba. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *J*oão *P*esso*a*.

name: Kilimanjaro International Airport
description: Opened in 1971, Kiliman*j*a*ro* International is often called the “Gateway to Africa’s Wildlife Heritage” and serves those visiting Mount Kilimanjaro National Park. Originally it was named just Kilimanjaro Airport.

name: Skiathos Airport, Alexandros Papadiamantis
description: Skiathos Airport is popular for its close take-offs and landings due to its short runway, similar to SXM. The ‘*SI*’ in its code comes from *S*k*i*athos, while the ‘*J*’ is likely a filler letter. JSI is one of nine Greek airports whose code begins with J.

name: Juba International Airport
description: Juba International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital of South Sudan, *Jub*a.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Inca Manco Cápac
description: Named after Manco Cápac, the “royal founder” of the Inca civilization in Cusco, Inca Manco Cápac International gets its three-letter code from its home in *Jul*iaca.

name: Mallam Aminu Kano International Airport
description: The oldest airport in Nigeria, Mallam Aminu International is named after 20th century political leader, Aminu Kano. Its three-letter code honors its home in the city of *Kan*o.

name: Hamid Karzai International Airport
description: Built in the 1960s and renamed in 2014, Hamid Karzai International is named after the former Afghan President. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *K*a*b*u*l*.

name: Boryspil International Airport
description: Originally opened in 1959 and then reorganized in 1993, Boryspil International serves the capital of Ukraine, *K*iev, from the city of *B*orys*p*il.

name: Lapangan Terbang Sultan Ismail Petra
description: Sultan Ismail Petra Airport is named after the thirteenth Sultan of Kelantan. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of *K*ota *B*ha*r*u.

name: Krabi International Airport
description: *K*ra*b*i International serves the province of Krabi in Thailand. The ‘*V*’ in its airport code is a filler letter.

name: Kuching International Airport
description: Kuching International is located just south of *K*u*ch*ing city center and serves the entire southwestern region of Sarawak, Malaysia.

name: Keflavíkurflugvöllur
description: Also known as Reykjavík-Keflavík Airport, Iceland’s largest airport is located near the town of *Kef*lavík and 50 km south of the capital city of Reykjavík.

name: Kerman International Airport
description: Kerman International gets its airport code from its home in the city and province of *Ker*man.

name: Kigali International Airport
description: Located in the suburb of Kanombe, Kigali International gets its airport code from the capital city of *K*i*g*a*l*i.

name: Kaohsiung International Airport
description: Built in 1938 as a Japanese Navy air base, Kaohsiung International serves the city of *K*ao*h*siung. Its code is completed by a second letter ‘*H*’, used as a filler letter.

name: Jinnah International Airport
description: Jinnah International is named after Muhammad Ali Jinnah, founder of Pakistan. Its airport code comes from its former name and home in the city of *K*arac*hi*.

name: Kish International Airport
description: A popular tourist gateway, Kish International gets its three-letter code from its home on *Ki*s*h* Island.

name: Norman Manley International Airport
description: The nation’s gateway, Norman Manley International is situated less than twenty minutes from *Kin*gston, Jamaica’s capital city and the commercial center of the Caribbean.

name: Chișinău International Airport
description: Flights to Chișinău began as early as 1926. Chișinău International get its airport code from the historic English spelling of Chișinău, *Ki*shine*v*.

name: Kansai International Airport
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Fully built on an artificial island, Kansai Airport gets its code from the *K*ansa*i* region, plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Kalibo International Airport
description: Kalibo International serves the general area of *K*a*l*ib*o* and is one of two airports serving the small island of Boracay.

name: Airport Klagenfurt
description: Airport *Kl*agenf*u*rt is Austria’s southernmost international airport. Initially a military airport, it now serves as a year-round tourist gate to Carinthia in southern Austria.

name: Kunming Changshui International Airport
description: With construction completing in 2011, Kunming Changshui International was originally to be called Zheng He Airport. It serves the city of *K*un*m*in*g*.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Kualanamu
description: Kualanamu International is the busiest airport in Sumatra, built to replace the Polonia Airport and opened in 2013. It serves the Kuala Namu region (sometimes spelled Kuala Nemu, or *K*uala *N*am*o*).

name: Kona International Airport
description: Opened in 1970 and originally known as Ke-āhole Airport, Kona International serves Kailua-Kona, usually referred to as just *Ko*n*a*.

name: Kokshetau Airport
description: Located in the city of Kokshetau in Kazakhstan, Kokshetau Airport gets its three-letter code from its former name, *Ko*kcheta*v* Trofimovka Airport.

name: Kraków Airport im. Jana Pawła II
description: Opened in 1964, Kraków–Balice Airport was renamed in 1995 to honor Pope John Paul II who before the Papacy had served as Archbishop for the city of *Kr*a*k*ów.

name: Kiruna flygplats
description: Kiruna Airport is the homebase for the Spaceport Sweden project, a venture in space and air travel. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *K*i*r*u*n*a.

name: Krasnodar International Airport
description: Krasnodar International, also known as Pashkovsky Airport, serves the southern *Kr*asnoda*r* region of Russia.

name: Kristiansand lufthavn, Kjevik
description: Originally opened in 1939, Kristiansand Airport is located in Kjevik and gets its three-letter code from the city of *Kr*istian*s*and.

name: Khartoum International Airport
description: Khartoum International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital of Sudan, *K*ha*rt*oum.

name: Kosrae International Airport
description: Kosrae International is located on an artificial island in eastern Micronesia. It serves the state of *K*o*s*r*a*e.

name: Shahid Ashrafi Esfahani Airport
description: Shahid Ashrafi Esfahani Airport is named after Ashrafi Esfahani, Iranian religious leader. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of *K*erman*sh*ah.

name: Kostanay International Airport
description: Kostanay International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *K*o*s*ta*n*ay.

name: Tribhuvan International Airport
description: Opened as an airfield in 1949, Tribhuvan International is named after Tribhuwan Bir Bikram Shah, former King of Nepal. Its airport code comes from its home city of *K*a*t*h*m*andu.

name: Kittilän lentoasema
description: Kittilä Airport is a general aviation and commercial airport located in the city of *K*i*tt*ilä, inside the Arctic Circle, and serves Northern Finland.

name: Międzynarodowy Port Lotniczy Katowice
description: An international airport, Katowice Airport is the fourth busiest in Poland. Actually located in the village of Pyrzowice, its three-letter code comes from the city it serves: *K*a*t*o*w*ice.

name: Sultan Haji Ahmad Shah Airport
description: Sultan Ahmad Shah Airport serves *Kua*ntan, a city in the state of Pahang, Malaysia.

name: Kushiro Airport
description: Kushiro Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Ku*s*h*iro.

name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Kuala Lumpur
description: Upon completion, Kuala Lumpur International replaced Subang Airport as *Ku*ala *L*umpur’s primary passenger airport. At the same time, it took the KUL code and Subang received a new code of SZB.

name: Kauno tarptautinis oro uostas
description: *K*a*un*as International is the second-busiest civil airport in Lithuania and the fourth-busiest in the Baltic states.

name: Kuopion lentoasema
description: Opened in 1940, Kuopio Airport is actually located in the city of Siilinjärvi, but serves the city of *Kuo*pio.

name: Guiyang Longdongbao International Airport
description: Opened in 1997, Guiyang Longdongbao International gets airport code from the city’s former English name: *Kwe*iyang.

name: Kuwait International Airport
description: Located in Farwaniyah, Kuwait International is headquarters for the Kuwait Air Force at Al Mubarak Air Base. Its airport code honors its home in *K*u*w*a*i*t.

name: Kazan International Airport
description: Completed in 1979, Kazan International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *K*a*z*a*n*.

name: Kyzylorda Airport
description: Kyzylorda Airport gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name of *Kz*yl-*O*rda.

name: Aeroporto Internacional 4 de Fevereiro
description: Quatro de Fevereiro International translates to February 4, an important national holiday in Angola. Its airport code honors the capital city of *L*u*a*n*d*a.

name: Purdue University Airport
description: Purdue University Airport was the first university-owned airport in the U.S. and is the second busiest in Indiana. It is located in West Lafayette and serves its sister city of *Laf*ayette.

name: Capital Region International Airport
description: Capital Region International started passenger service in 1929. Located in DeWitt Township, it serves the capital city of *Lan*sing.

name: McCarran International Airport
description: Formerly called Alamo Field, McCarron Airport was renamed in 1948 after Pat McCarran, a senator and author of the Civil Aeronautics Act. Its airport code honors its home in *Las* Vegas.

name: Los Angeles International Airport
description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. LA (*L*os *A*ngeles) became LAX.

name: Leeds Bradford International Airport
description: Opened in 1931 as Yeadon Aerodrome, *L*eeds *B*radford *A*irport serves the cities of Leeds and Bradford, along with the Yorkshire region.

name: Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport
description: Opened in 1937 and originally named South Plains Airport, Lubbock International is now named after Preston E. Smith, former Texas governor. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *L*u*bb*ock.

name: Flughafen Lübeck
description: Sometimes called “Hamburg Lübeck”, *L*ü*b*e*c*k Airport was originally built as an airbase during World War I.

name: North Platte Regional Airport
description: Built in 1921, North Platte was the first lighted airfield in the Unitd States. In 1941 it was renamed *L*ee *B*ird *F*ield to honor a local pilot who was killed in training during World War I.

name: Bandar Udara Komodo
description: Komodo Airport is located on the island of Flores and serves visitors to Komodo National Park, home of the Komodo dragon. Its three-letter code comes from the nearby town of *L*abuan *B*a*j*o.

name: Lapangan Terbang Labuan
description: Labuan Airport serves the country of Malaysia and gets its airport code from the territory of *L*a*bu*an.

name: Aéroport De Libreville au Gabon
description: Libreville International is officially named after Leon M’ba, the first Prime Minister and President of Gabon. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *L*i*b*re*v*ille.

name: Larnaca International Airport
description: Larnaca Airport was developed in 1974 after Turkey invaded Cyprus and Nicosia International subsequently closed. It now serves the city of *L*arna*ca*.

name: Aeroporto da Coruña-Alvedro
description: Formerly known as Alvedro Airport, A Coruña Airport was inaugurated in 1963. Its airport code comes from the Spanish city of *L*a *C*oruña, *G*alicia.

name: Rickenbacker International Airport
description: Opened in 1942, Rickenbacker International is now named after World War I pilot Eddie Rickenbacker. It was originally known as Lockbourne Army Airfield for the nearby town of *L*o*ck*bourne.

name: London City Airport
description: Located in the Royal Docks and near London’s financial district, *L*ondon *C*it*y* Airport primarily serves business travelers. Recently though, it has started serving more leisure destinations.

name: City of Derry Airport
description: Originally built during World War II, City of Derry Airport was renamed in 1994. Its previous name was *L*ondon*d*err*y* Eglinton Airport.

name: Aeroport Pulkovo
description: Pulkovo Airport opened in the city of *Le*ningra*d* in 1932. In 1991, the city returned to its original name of Saint Petersburg and kept the airport code, now associated with LED lights for many visitors.

name: Aeropuerto de Almería
description: Almería Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of A*l*m*e*r*í*a.

name: Flughafen Leipzig/Halle
description: Opened in 1986, Leipzig/Halle Airport gets its airport code from the city of *Le*ipzig. The ‘*J*’ is a phonetic replacement for the ‘G’ in Leipzig.

name: Aeropuerto de León
description: Used as an aviation school during the 1940s, León Airport opened commercially in 1964 serving the city of *Le*ó*n*.

name: Aeropuerto de La Seu d'Urgell
description: Andorra is one of five countries without an airport. Opened in 1982, *L*a S*eu* d'Urgell Airport in Spain serves passengers traveling to Andorra and the nearby areas.

name: Blue Grass Airport
description: Located in the Horse Capital of the World, Blue Grass Airport opened in 1946. Its airport code honors its home in *Lex*ington, Kentucky.

name: Lafayette Regional Airport
description: Opened in 1930, Lafayette Regional gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *L*a*f*aye*t*te.

name: Lomé–Tokoin Airport
description: Lomé–Tokoin Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *L*omé and the former federation of *F*rench *W*est Africa.

name: LaGuardia Airport
description: LaGuardia has had many names and the land it sits on was once an amusement park. Its current name comes from Fiorello *L*a *G*uardi*a*, former mayor of New York who championed its construction.

name: Long Beach Airport
description: Formerly named Daugherty Field after barnstormer Earl S. Daugherty, *L*on*g* *B*each Airport was once the site for one of the world’s first flying schools.

name: Liège Airport
description: Often called Liège-Bierset, Liège Airport is located in Grâce-Hollogne and serves the city of *L*iè*g*e, Bel*g*ium.

name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Langkawi
description: Located in the town of Padang Matsirat, Langkawi International serves the *L*an*gk*awi islands in Malaysia. It hosts an international maritime and aerospace exhibition every two years.

name: Gatwick Airport
description: Close to *L*ondon, *G*at*w*ick Airport is the second-largest airport in Britain. It’s the world’s busiest single-use runway and is named after Gatwick manor house that used to stand on the site.

name: Allama Iqbal International Airport
description: Renamed in 2003, Allama Iqbal International honors Muhammad Iqbal, poet-philosopher and advocate for the Pakistan Movement. Its airport code honors its former name and home in *L*a*h*or*e*.

name: London Heathrow Airport
description: *L*ondon *H*eath*r*ow takes its name from Heathrow, a hamlet north-west of where the (then) small airfield was started in 1929.

name: Lihue Airport
description: Opened in 1949, Lihue Airport is the primary airport on the Hawaiian island of Kauai. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Lih*ue.

name: Aéroport de Lille
description: Also known as Lesquin Airport, Lille Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of *Lil*le.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Jorge Chávez
description: Originally named *Lim*a-Callao Airport, Jorge Chávez International was renamed in 1965 to honor the Peruvian aviator.

name: Aeroporto di Milano-Linate
description: Milan Linate Airport is officially named Airport Enrico Forlanini after the Italian inventor. Its airport code comes from the village of *Lin*ate in the town of Peschiera Borromeo.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Daniel Oduber Quirós
description: Daniel Oduber Quirós International is named after the former President of Costa Rica and serves the city of *Li*be*r*ia.

name: Aeroporto da Portela
description: Portugal’s busiest airport is named for its neighboring parish, Portela, but its airport code comes from the capital city of *Lis*bon.

name: Bill and Hillary Clinton National Airport
description: Still referred to as Adams Field, Arkansas’ largest airport is now named after former U.S. President Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary. Its aiport code honors its home in *Lit*tle Rock.

name: Letališče Jožeta Pučnika Ljubljana
description: In 2007, Ljubljana Jože Pučnik Airport was renamed to honor Jože Pučnik, considered one of the fathers of Slovenian independence. Its airport code honors its home in *Lju*bljana.

name: Chaudhary Charan Singh International Airport
description: Chaudhary Charan Singh International is named after India’s sixth Prime Minister. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *L*uc*k*n*o*w.

name: Lilongwe International Airport
description: Sometimes referred to as Kamuzu Airport, Lilongwe International gets its three-letter code from the capital city of Malawi, *L*i*l*ong*w*e.

name: Lapangan Terbang Limbang
description: Opened in 2004, Limbang Airport replaced the Limbang airfield built in the 1960s. Its three-letter code comes from its home in the city of *L*i*m*ba*n*g.

name: Crater Lake - Klamath Regional Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. Crater Lake - Klamath Regional, with origins dating back to 1928, chose other letters from K*l*a*m*a*t*h Falls.

name: Lincoln Airport
description: Used during World War II as Lincoln Army Air Field, Lincoln Airport’s code gets its first two letters from the city of *L*i*n*coln. The ‘*K*’ works phonetically and as a filler letter.

name: Linz Airport
description: Linz Airport serves as gateway to the third largest city in Austria, which northern and southern parts are divided by the Danube river, similar to Austria’s capital – Vienna. Its airport code is just one letter short of the city’s full name – *L*i*nz*

name: Lombok International Airport
description: Built to replace the Selaparang Airport and opened in 2011, Lombok International Airport serves the city of Mataram, the capital of the province of West Nusa Tenggara.  It receives its code from the district on the island where it is located, *LO*mbok *P*raya

name: Murtala Muhammed International Airport
description: Formerly Lagos International, Murtala Muhammed International was renamed to honor assassinated head of state, General Murtala Ramat Muhammed. Its airport code honors its home in *L*ag*os*.

name: Aeropuerto de Gran Canaria
description: Located on the island of Gran Canaria on the Bay of Gando, Gran Canaria Airport is sometimes (incorrectly) called *L*as *P*almas *A*irport.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional El Alto
description: The highest international airport in the world, at 13,325 ft (4061 m), El Alto’s airport code honors the nearby city of *L*a *P*az, *B*olivia.

name: Liverpool John Lennon Airport
description: Opened in 1930 and known locally as Speke Airport, Liverpool John Lennon Airport is named after late musician John Lennon of the Beatles. Its airport code honors its home in *L*iver*p*oo*l*.

name: Luang Prabang International Airport
description: Luang Prabang International is one of few international airports in the country of Laos. Its three-letter code comes from *L*uang *P*rabang, plus a helpful ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Laredo International Airport
description: Previously known as Laredo Army Airfield during World War II, Laredo International now serves the city of *L*a*r*e*d*o, Texas.

name: Aéroport de La Rochelle – Ile de Ré
description: La Rochelle Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *L*a *R*oc*h*elle. It also serves the nearby Île de Ré.

name: La Crosse Regional Airport
description: Located near U.S. Army Fort McCoy military base, *L*a Cros*se* Regional serves passengers traveling to west-central Wisconsin, southeastern Minnesota, and northeastern Iowa.

name: London Luton Airport
description: Previously Luton International, London Luton Airport was renamed in 1990 to emphasize its proximity to London. The airport itself is located in the town of *L*u*t*o*n*.

name: Cincinnati Municipal Airport
description: Cincinnati Municipal is also known as Lunken Field, named after Eshelby *Lu*n*k*en and the Lunken family who donated the land where the airport now sits.

name: Kenneth Kaunda International Airport
description: Renamed in 2011 in honor of Zambia’s first president, Kenneth Kaunda International is located in *Lu*saka, formerly the capital of *N*orthern Rhodesia.

name: Aéroport de Luxembourg
description: Located in the town of Findel, Luxembourg’s only international airport gets its airport code from its home country of *Lux*embourg.

name: Harry Mwanga Nkumbula International Airport
description: Harry Mwanga Nkumbula International is named after the nationalist leader who fought for Northern Rhodesian independence. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *L*i*vi*ngstone.

name: Greenbrier Valley Airport
description: Greenbrier Valley Airport is located in Greenbrier County and gets its three-letter airport code from the nearby city of *L*e*w*is*b*urg.

name: Lviv Danylo Halytskyi International Airport
description: Lviv Danylo Halytskyi International is named after 13th century King Daniel of Galicia. Its airport code comes from the Polish spelling of Lviv: *Lwó*w.

name: Luxor International Airport
description: Luxor International serves the many tourists who visit the Nile River and the Valley of the Kings. Its three-letter code comes from its home in *L*u*x*o*r*, Egypt.

name: Svalbard lufthavn, Longyear
description: Svalbard Airport gets its name from the city it serves. Its airport code comes from the nearby town of *L*ong*y*ea*r*byen.

name: Aéroport Lyon-Saint-Exupéry
description: In 2000, Lyon’s airport was renamed to honor French aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. Its airport code comes from its original name, *Ly*on *S*atolas Airport.

name: Chennai International Airport
description: Chennai International is located in Tirusulam, a suburb of Chennai, but gets its three-letter code from the city’s former name, *Ma*dr*a*s, changed in 1996.

name: Aeropuerto Adolfo Suárez Madrid-Barajas
description: Spain’s largest airport honors former Prime Minister Adolfo Suárez, but its airport code honors its home in the capital city of *Mad*rid.

name: Midland International Air and Space Port
description: Midland International is located between the cities of Midland and Odessa. Its airport code comes from its time as a training base during World War II, named *M*idland Army *A*ir*f*ield.

name: Aeropuerto de Menorca
description: Opened in 1969, Menorca Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *Mah*ón on the island of Menorca.

name: Marshall Islands International Airport
description: Built during World War II, Marshall Islands International is sometimes referred to as Amata Kabua Airport. Its airport code comes from the city and atoll named *Maj*uro.

name: Manchester Airport
description: Once called Ringway Airport because of its location in the parish of Ringway, the UK’s third busiest airport serves the city of *Man*chester.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Brigadeiro Eduardo Gomes
description: Brigadeiro Eduardo Gomes International is named after Brazilian Air Marshall Eduardo Gomes. Its airport code comes from an alternate spelling of Manaus, *Ma*ná*o*s.

name: Moi International Airport
description: Named after Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi, Moi International serves the city of *M*om*b*as*a*.

name: Sangster International Airport
description: Sangster International is named in honor of former Jamaican Prime Minister Sir Donald Sangster. Its airport code honors its home in *M*ontego *B*ay, *J*amaica.

name: MBS International Airport
description: Formerly known as Freeland Tri-City Airport, MBS International is the third busiest airport in Michigan. Its airport code honors the three communities it serves: *M*idland, *B*ay City, and *S*aginaw.

name: Kansas City International Airport
description: Before changing its name in 1972, Kansas City International was originally known as *M*id-*C*ontinent *I*nternational Airport.

name: Orlando International Airport
description: Renamed in 1976, Orlando’s airport was originally a military airfield known as *M*c*Co*y Airforce Base, honoring Colonel Michael Norman Wright McCoy.

name: Muscat International Airport
description: Opened in 1973 and originally named Seeb International, the largest airport in Oman is located in the city of *M*us*c*a*t*.

name: Mason City Municipal Airport
description: Founded in 1927, Mason City Municipal gets its three-letter code from the two organizations that founded it, *M*ason City Chamber of Commerce and the *C*lausen-*W*orden Post of the American Legion.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Maceió/Zumbi dos Palmares
description: Renamed in 1999, *M*a*c*eió/*Z*umbi dos Palmares International is named after Zumbi dos Palmares, 17th century hero and freedom fighter.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sam Ratulangi
description: Often called Manado Airport, Sam Ratulangi International is named after the Minahasan independence hero Sam Ratulangi. Its airport code comes from nearby *M*ana*d*o *C*ity.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional José María Córdova
description: Opened in 1985, José María Córdova International is named after a General of the Colombian army. Actually located in the city of Rionegro, it gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, *M*e*de*llín.

name: Mandalay International Airport
description: Mandalay International is one of three airports in Myanmar. Its three-letter code honors its home in *M*an*d*a*l*ay.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Mar del Plata “Ástor Piazzolla”
description: Named after an Argentine musician, Astor Piazzolla International is located in *M*ar *d*el Plata. With MDP already taken, its code uses the letter ‘*Q*’ in place of the ‘P’.

name: Harrisburg International Airport
description: Often called HIA incorrectly, Harrisburg International’s airport code comes from *M*i*d*dle*t*own, a nearby Harrisburg suburb.

name: Midway International Airport
description: Once called Chicago Air Park and later Chicago Municipal, Midway International was renamed in 1949 to honor World War II’s Battle of *M*i*dw*ay.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Gobernador Francisco Gabrielli
description: Named after the former Mendoza governor, Francisco Gabrielli International gets its three-letter code from the city of *M*en*d*o*z*a.

name: Prince Mohammad bin Abdulaziz International Airport
description: Opened in 1950, Prince Mohammad bin Abdulaziz Internationali is named after the former Crown Prince. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Med*ina.

name: Melbourne Airport
description: Located in the suburb of Tullamarine, Melbourne Airport is often called “Tullamarine Airport” or just “Tulla.” Its airport code comes from the city of *Mel*bourne.

name: Memphis International Airport
description: In 1969, Memphis Municipal Airport changed its name to “International”, presenting *Mem*phis as a hub for international travel and cargo.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Benito Juárez
description: Once called Central Airport and most commonly referred to as *Mex*ico City International, Mexico’s busiest airport is named in honor of 19th century president, Benito Juárez.

name: Mansfield Lahm Regional Airport
description: Mansfield Lahm Regional is home to Mansfield Lahm Air National Guard Base and hosts Mansfield Airport Day each year. Its airport code honors the city of *M*ans*f*iel*d*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Augusto C. Sandino
description: Nicaragua’s busiest airport is named after Augusto César Sandino, national hero and revolutionary. Its three-letter airport code comes from the capital city of *M*ana*g*u*a*.

name: Flughafen Düsseldorf Mönchengladbach
description: Founded in 1955 as a small airstrip, Düsseldorf Mönchengladbach Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *M*önchen*gl*adbach.

name: Montgomery Regional Airport
description: Previously known as Dannelly Field, Montgomery Regional is located in and serves the city of *M*ont*g*o*m*ery.

name: Shahid Hashemi Nejad Airport
description: Shahid Hashemi Nejad Airport is the second busiest airport in Iran and gets its three-letter code from its home in *M*ash*h*a*d*.

name: Manchester–Boston Regional Airport
description: Manchester Airport added “-Boston Regional” to its name in 2005 to serve as another option for Boston travelers. Its airport code still honors its home in *M*anc*h*es*t*er.

name: Miami International Airport
description: Once known as the 36th Street Airport, the three-letter code MIA stands for *Mia*mi and not the popular initialism for “missing in action.”

name: Aeropuerto de Murcia-San Javier
description: Started as a military air base, *M*urcia-San *J*a*v*ier airport is located in San Javier and serves the cities of Murcia and Cartagena.

name: Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport
description: Charles B. Wheeler Downtown Airport in *M*issouri was originally *K*ansas *C*ity’s main airport, until the FAA called it “the most dangerous major airport in the country” and it was replaced with Kansas City International in 1972.

name: General Mitchell International Airport
description: General Mitchell International honors U.S. Army Air Service General Billy Mitchell, but its airport code honors its home in *M*ilwau*ke*e.

name: Muskegon County Airport
description: Located in Norton Shores, construction on Muskegon County Airport began in 1931. Its airport codes honors its home in *M*us*k*e*g*on County, Michigan.

name: Ajruport Internazzjonali ta 'Malta
description: Located between the villages of Luqa and Gudja near the capital city of Valletta, Malta International is the only airport serving the nation of *M*a*l*t*a*.

name: Melbourne International Airport
description: Melbourne International dates back to the late 1920s and gets its airport code from its home in the city of *M*e*lb*ourne, Florida.

name: Ibrahim Nasir International Airport
description: Ibrahim Nasir International is named after the first president of the Maldives. It is located on Hulhule Island, near the capital island of *M*a*le*.

name: EuroAirport Basel–Mulhouse–Freiburg
description: EuroAirport Basel-*M*u*lh*ouse-Freiburg has two IATA codes (BSL is the other one). It is located in Saint-Louis, France but is one of only a few airports in the world operated jointly by two countries, in this case France and Switzerland.

name: Quad City International Airport
description: The QCIA serves the Quad City Metro area spanning the border of Iowa and Illinois. Its airport code comes from the city it resides in, *M*o*LI*ne.

name: Aeropuerto de Melilla
description: Opened in 1969, Melilla Airport serves the city of *M*e*l*illa, a Spanish enclave in Africa, and the nearby city of *N*ador, Morocco.

name: Monroe Regional Airport
description: Monroe Regional was previously named Selman Army Airfield after U.S. Navy pilot, Lieutenant Augustus J. Selman. Its three-letter code comes from its home in *M*onroe, *L*o*u*isiana.

name: Durham Tees Valley Airport
description: Commonly still called Teesside International, Durham Tees Valley started as RAF *M*iddl*e*ton St. George in 1941. Some say its code comes from *M*iddleton *M*ilitary *E*stablishment, but the airport itself has said the second ‘M’ is a filler letter.

name: Mammoth Yosemite Airport
description: Primarily used for general aviation, Mammoth Yosemite Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *M*a*m*mot*h* Lakes.

name: Malmö flygplats
description: Built in 1972 and formerly known as Sturup Airport, Malmö Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *M*al*m*ö, plus a helpful ‘*X*’ as a filler letter.

name: Paliparang Pandaigdig ng Ninoy Aquino
description: Originally named Manila International, Ninoy Aquino Airport was renamed in 1987 to honor assassinated Senator Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino, Jr. Its airport code honors the city it serves: *M*a*n*i*l*a.

name: Mobile Regional Airport
description: Fully self-funded and home to a U.S. Coast Guard aviation training center, Mobile Regional serves *Mob*ile, Alabama.

name: Moomba Airport
description: Moomba Airport gets its fun three-letter code from its home in the city of *Moo*mba in South Australia.

name: Maputo International Airport
description: Sometimes still called Lourenço Marques Airport, Maputo International get its airport code from its location in the capital city of *M*a*p*uto, *M*ozambique.

name: Aéroport de Miquelon
description: Miquelon Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its location in the *M*i*q*uelon-Langlade *c*ommune in Saint Pierre and Miquelon.

name: Mildura Airport
description: Called RAAF Base Mildura during World War II, Mildura Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of *M*i*l*dura, plus a helpful ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Aéroport de Marseille Provence
description: Marseille Provence Airport is located in the commune of Marignane and was previously known as Marseille–Marignane Airport. Its airport code comes from the city it serves,  *M*a*rs*eille.

name: Sir Seewoosagur Ramgoolam International Airport
description: Officially opened in 1945, Plaisance Airport was later renamed to honor former Prime Minister Seewoosagur Ramgoolam. It is located in the southernmost part of *M*au*r*iti*u*s.

name: Monterey Regional Airport
description: Opened in 1936 and previously named Monterey Peninsula Airport, Monterey Regional was renamed in 2011 and serves the city of *M*onte*r*e*y*, California.

name: Dane County Regional Airport
description: Formerly Truax Field, named after U.S. Army Air Forces Lieutenant Thomas L. Truax, Dane County Regional’s code honors its home in the city of *M*adi*s*o*n*.

name: Missoula International Airport
description: Previously known as Johnson-Bell Field, Missoula International opened in 1941 and serves the city of *M*is*so*ula, Montana.

name: Minneapolis–Saint Paul International Airport
description: Formerly known as Speedway Field and Wold–Chamberlain Field, MSP is now named after Minnesota’s twin cities, *M*inneapolis and *S*aint *P*aul.

name: Minsk National Airport
description: Minsk National, formerly known as Minsk-2 (yes, there is a Minsk-1), is the primary airport in Belarus. Its code comes from the city of *M*in*s*k. The ‘*Q*’ works phonetically, but is used as a filler letter.

name: Maastricht Aachen Airport
description: Located in the town of Beek and previously known as Beek Airfield, Maastricht Aachen Airport serves the cities of *M*aa*st*richt, Netherlands and Aachen, Germany.

name: Moshoeshoe I International Airport
description: Moshoeshoe I International is named after the founder of the Basotho nation, eventually to become Lesotho. Located in Mazenod, it serves the city of *M*a*s*er*u*.

name: Louis Armstrong International Airport
description: In 2001, the airport was named after jazz legend Louis Armstrong, but was previously called Moisant Field, after aviator John Moisant. Its airport code came from the nearby *M*oisant *S*tock *Y*ards.

name: Montrose Regional Airport
description: Dedicated in 1988, Montrose Regional is a non-towered, seasonal airport. Its code gets its first two letters from *M*on*t*rose. Some say the ‘J’ comes from *J*et Airport, but it is likely a filler letter.

name: Matsapha Airport
description: In 2014, most air traffic to Swaziland was moved from Matsapha Airport to King Mswati III International. It originally served the city of Manzini, but is located in the town of *M*a*ts*apha.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Mariano Escobedo
description: Located in Apodaca, *M*on*t*erre*y* International is named after Mariano Escobedo, a Mexican Army general and former Governor of Nuevo León.

name: Flughafen München Franz Josef Strauß
description: Rarely called by its full name, Munich Airport is named after German politician Franz Josef Strauss. Its airport code honors its home near the city of *Mu*ni*c*h.

name: Multan International Airport
description: With military flights using the area as early as 1919, Multan International gets its three-letter airport code from the city of *Mu*ltan, plus a helpful filler ‘*X*’.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Carrasco/General Cesáreo L. Berisso
nameEnglish: Carrasco/General Cesáreo L. Berisso International Airport
description: Carrasco International is named after aviation pioneer General Cesáreo L. Berisso. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *M*onte*v*i*d*eo.

name: Martha’s Vineyard Airport
description: Built in 1942 as a naval training facility, Martha’s Vineyard Airport is located near the community of Vineyard Haven on the island of *M*artha’s *V*ine*y*ard.

name: Laurinburg–Maxton Airport
description: A former U.S. Army air base during World War II, Laurinburg–Maxton Airport is known today primarily as an airliner graveyard. Its code comes in part from *M*a*x*ton, but the ‘*E*’ is more of a mystery and is likely a filler letter.

name: Aeroporto di Milano-Malpensa
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Milan’s airport code comes from Cascina *M*al*p*ensa, where the airport got its start, plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Montgomery Field Airport
description: Originally opened in 1940 as Gibbs Field, *M*ontgomer*y* *F*ield Airport is now named after aviation pioneer John J. Montgomery.

name: Myrtle Beach International Airport
description: Formerly Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, Myrtle Beach Airport gained international status in 1996. Its airport code comes from its home in *Myr*tle Beach.

name: Myitkyina Airport
description: Myitkyina Airfield was captured by the Japanese Air Force during World War II. Now a passenger airport, it serves the city of *My*i*t*kyina in Myanmar.

name: Aeropuerto La Nubia
description: Due to a short runway, only turbopropeller aircrafts can land at La Nubia Airport. It gets its three-letter code from its city of *M*ani*z*a*l*es.

name: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar International Airport
description: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar International is named after the chief architect of the Indian Constitution. Its airport code comes from its home in city of *Nag*pur.

name: Nadi International Airport
description: Used as a U.S. military base during World War II, Nadi International was once called Naval Air Facility *Nan*di. “Nandi” was an English phonetic spelling used long after the airport’s name was officially changed.

name: Aeroporto Internazionale di Napoli
description: Originally Capodichino Airport, Naples International is located in the Capodichino district in the city of *Nap*les.

name: Lynden Pindling International Airport
description: In 2006, Lynden Pindling Airport changed its name from *Nas*sau International in honor of the former Prime Minister, Sir Lynden Oscar Pindling.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Augusto Severo
description: Augusto Severo International is named after Brazilian aviator Augusto Severo de Albuquerque Maranhão. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Nat*al.

name: Jomo Kenyatta International Airport
description: Jomo Kenyatta International is named after Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya’s first president and prime minister. Its airport code comes from a combination of letters from the capital city of *N*air*ob*i.

name: Aéroport Nice Côte d'Azur
description: France’s third busiest airport is named for the regions it serves: the city of *N*i*ce* and the Côte d'Azur (the French Riviera).

name: Newcastle International Airport
description: Opened in 1935, Newcastle International served 4.6 million passengers in 2014 making it one of the busiest in the United Kingdom. Its airport code honors its home in *N*ew*c*ast*l*e.

name: N’Djamena International Airport
description: N’Djamena Airport is the only international airport in Chad, serving both civilian and military traffic. Its three-letter code comes from the capital city of *N*’*Dj*amena.

name: N’Délé Airport
description: N’Délé Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *N*’*D*é*l*é in the Central African Republic.

name: Ningbo Lishe International Airport
description: Ningbo Lishe International is the principal airport serving *N*in*gb*o, a major city in the Yangtze River Delta region and the second largest city in Zhejiang Province, China.

name: Chūbu Centrair International Airport
description: Chūbu Centrair International serves the Chūbu (central) region of Japan. Located in the city of *N*a*go*ya, it replaced Nagoya Airport in 2005 and inherited its airport code too.

name: Nagasaki Airport
description: Opened as a military aerodome in 1923, Omura Airport began civilian use in 1955. It was later renamed to *N*a*g*a*s*aki Airport after the city it serves.

name: Nicosia International Airport
description: Nicosia International has been closed since the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974 and later became a United Nations controlled Buffer Zone. It previously served as a military and commercial airport for the city of *Nic*osia.

name: Diori Hamani International Airport
description: Diori Hamani International is named after the first President of the Republic of Niger. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Ni*a*m*ey.

name: Nouakchott International Airport
description: Nouakchott International gets its three-letter airport code from Mauritania’s capital city of *N*oua*kc*hott.

name: Nanjing Lukou International Airport
description: Nanjing Lukou International serves Nanjing and gets its airport code from the city’s former Romanization, *N*an*k*in*g*.

name: Nanning Wuxu International Airport
description: Nanning Wuxu International serves the city of *N*a*n*nin*g*, the capital of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in China.

name: Fascene Airport
description: One of the busiest airports in Madagascar, Fascene Airport gets its three-letter code from its home on the island of *Nos*y Be.

name: Newquay Cornwall Airport
description: Located in St Mawgan in Pydar, Newquay Cornwall Airport began as a civilian airfield in 1933. Its airport code comes from the town of *N*ew*q*ua*y* in Cornwall.

name: Flughafen Weeze
description: Weeze Airport’s three-letter code comes from its official name, Flughafen *N*iede*r*rhei*n*, with Niederrhein translating to the “Lower Rhine” that flows nearby.

name: Narita International Airport
description: Upon privitazation in 2004, New Tokyo International Airport was renamed in recognition of the city in which is located, *N*a*r*i*t*a.

name: Nelson Airport
description: Originally built in 1937, Nelson Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *N*el*s*o*n*.

name: Aéroport Nantes Atlantique
description: Originally a French military airfield, Nantes Atlantique is located southwest of Bouguenais and serves the city of *N*an*te*s.

name: Newcastle Airport
description: Newcastle Airport is 15 kilometres; 9.2 miles (8 NM) north of *N*ewcas*tl*e, New South Wales in Port Stephens. It is the 13th busiest airport in Australia, handling over 1.25 million passengers in the year ended 30 June 2017.

name: Flughafen Nürnberg
description: Inaugurated in 1955, Nuremberg Airport is the second-busiest airport in Bavaria. It is christened after German artist Albrecht Dürer and serves the city of *Nu*remb*e*rg.

name: Norwich International Airport
description: Norwich International was opened during World War II as RAF Horsham St Faith and is located in the city of *N*or*wi*ch in Norfolk.

name: Stockholm Skavsta flygplats
description: Stockholm Skavsta Airport served as a military airbase until 1980 and now serves the city of Stockholm. Its airport code comes from the town of *Ny*k*ö*ping, where it’s located.

name: Oakland International Airport
description: Oakland International was the departure site for Amelia Earhart’s final flight in 1937. It now serves the eastern part of the San Francisco Bay Area (the East Bay) and the city of *Oak*land.

name: Oban Airport
description: Located near the village of North Connel, Scotland’s Oban Airport gets its three-letter code from the town it serves, *Ob*a*n*.

name: Odessa International Airport
description: Originally built in 1961, Odessa International serves Ukraine’s third largest city of *Od*e*s*sa.

name: Kahului Airport
description: Kahului Airport is named after its home city, but its airport code honors Hawaiian-born pilot Bertram J. H*ogg*.

name: Aerodrom Ohrid “Sv. Apostol Pavle”
description: Ohrid Airport is named after Saint Paul the Apostle and serves the city of *Oh*ri*d* in Macedonia.

name: Worcester Regional Airport
description: The FCC restricted U.S. airport codes from beginning with the letters ‘W’ and ‘K’, reserving them for radio station designations. With ORC (and other OR- codes) already taken, W*or*cester opted for ORH.

name: Naha Airport
description: Opened in 1933 as Oroku Aerodrome, Naha Airport gets its airport code from its home in Naha, *Ok*inaw*a*.

name: Will Rogers World Airport
description: It may sound like an amusement park, but Will Rogers World Airport honors legendary cowboy and entertainer, Will Rogers. Its airport code honors its home in *Ok*lahoma *C*ity.

name: Eppley Airfield
description: Eppley Airfield is Nebraska’s largest airport and honors hotel mogul Eugene C. Eppley. Its aiport code honors its home in *Oma*ha.

name: Nome Airport
description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. Nome Airport then used the next few letters in its home city of N*ome* to get OME.

name: Mostar International Airport
description: Opened in 1965, Mostar International gets its airport code from its home in the village of *O*rtiješ in *Mo*star, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Omsk Tsentralny Airport
description: Omsk Tsentralny Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *Oms*k Oblast.

name: LA/Ontario International Airport
description: Established in 1929, Ontario Municipal was renamed “International” in 1946. In 2006, the “LA” was added to avoid confusion with the Canadian province that shares the name *Ont*ario.

name: Gold Coast Airport
description: Gold Coast Airport is located in the suburb of Bilinga on the Gold Coast. Its airport code comes from its former name of C*ool*angatta Airport, an Aboriginal word meaning “Place of Good View.”

name: Aeroporto Francisco Sá Carneiro
description: Portugal’s second busiest airport is named after former Prime Minister Francisco de Sá Carneiro. Its airport code comes from its home in Porto and its alternate English spelling: *Opo*rto.

name: Örebro flygplats
description: Originally opened in 1979, Örebro Airport is located 10km from the city of *Ör*e*b*ro in Sweden.

name: O’Hare International Airport
description: Before the airport was renamed after Medal of Honor recipient Edward O’Hare in 1949, it was known as *Or*char*d* Field Airport.

name: Norfolk International Airport
description: When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. N*orf*olk, then, used the next letters in its name to make ORF.

name: Cork Airport
description: Located in the village of Ballygarvan, Cork Airport is one of the three primary airports in Ireland. Its airport code comes from the city of C*ork*.

name: Aéroport de Paris-Orly
description: Once named Villeneuve-Orly Airport, France’s second busiest airport is partially located in both Paris communes Villeneuve-le-Roi and *Or*l*y*.

name: Oslo lufthavn
description: Norway’s busiest airport is actually located in Gardermoen, but its airport code honors the capital city of *Osl*o.

name: Internationale Luchthaven Oostende-Brugge
description: Ostend-Bruges International serves mainly as a cargo and charter airport. Its airport code honors its coastal home city of *OST*end.

name: Aeroportul Internațional Henri Coandă
description: Bucharest’s airport honors Henri Coandă, inventor of the first jet engine and discoverer of the Coandă effect in fluid dynamics. Its airport code comes from the nearby city of *Ot*o*p*eni.

name: Ouagadougou International Airport
description: Built in the 1960s, Ouagadougou International gets its three-letter airport code from the capital of Burkina Faso, *Oua*gadougou.

name: Oulun lentoasema
description: Oulu Airport is Finland’s second busiest airport and its airport code reflects its home in the city of *Oul*u.

name: Novosibirsk Tolmachevo Airport
description: Opened in 1957, Novosibirsk Tolmachevo Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of N*ov*osi*b*irsk.

name: Aeropuerto de Asturias
description: Opened in 1968, Asturias Airport serves the principality of Asturias and gets its three-letter code from its capital city of *Ov*ie*d*o.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Osvaldo Vieira
description: Guinea-Bissau’s only international airport gets its three-letter code from its name, *O*svaldo Viera International, plus the city of *B*issau, plus a filler ‘*X*’ in between.

name: London Oxford Airport
description: Established in 1935, London Oxford Airport was renamed in 2009 to highlight its “proximity” to London (though located 59 miles away). It is located near Kidlington and serves the city of *Oxf*ord.

name: Snohomish County Airport
description: Also known as *Pa*in*e* Field, the airport is adjacent to the Boeing assembly plant that churns out 747s, 777s, and DreamLiners.

name: Aéroport International Toussaint L'Ouverture
description: Started as an airfield in the 1940s, Toussaint L'Ouverture Airport has had many names, but is currently named after the leader of the Haitian Revolution. Located in the town of Tabarre, it serves the capital city of *P*ort-*a*u-*P*rince.

name: Plattsburgh International Airport
description: Located at the former Plattsburgh Air Force Base, Plattsburgh International took over traffice from Clinton County Airport in 2007. Its airport code comes from the city of *P*latts*b*ur*g*h.

name: Paro International Airport
description: Originally built in 1968 to serve the Indian Armed Forces, Paro Airport is the only international airport in the country. Its airport code comes from the district of *P*aro, *Bh*utan.

name: Palm Beach International Airport
description: Originally opened in 1936 and named Morrison Field, *P*alm *B*each *I*nternational was renamed in 1948, with a stint as Palm Beach Air Force Base from 1951-1962.

name: Johan Adolf Pengel International Airport
description: Johan Adolf Pengel International is named after the former Suriname Prime Minister. While located in the village of Zanderij, its airport code uses rearranged letters from the capitl city of *P*ara*m*ari*b*o.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP David Abensur Rengifo
description: Serving the Ucayali Region of Peru, David Abensur Rengifo International gets its three-letter code from its home city of *P*u*c*a*l*lpa.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Minangkabau
description: Minangkabau International is named after the Minangkabau, the indigenous people of West Sumatra. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *P*a*d*an*g*.

name: Aeroporto João Paulo II
description: Inaugurated in 1969, João Paulo II Airport was renamed in 1995 to honor the 1991 visit of Pope John Paul II to the Azores. Located on the island of São Miguel, its airport code honors the city of *P*onta *D*e*l*gada.
