name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán de Corbeta Carlos A. Curbelo
description: Commonly called Laguna del Sauce Airport, Carlos A. Curbelo International serves the city of *P*unta *d*el Este and is located in *P*iriápolis.

name: Letishte Plovdiv
description: Often called Krumovo Airport, *P*lov*d*i*v* Airport primarily serves visitors to the ski resort towns of Bansko and Pamporovo.

name: Portland International Airport
description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. PD (*P*ortlan*d*) became PDX.

name: Perm International Airport
description: Located in the village of Bolshoye Savino, Perm International gets its airport code from an alternate English spelling of Perm, *Pe*r*e*m.

name: Beijing Capital International Airport
description: Boasting the second largest terminal in the world, Beijing’s Capital Airport is near the city’s center. Its airport code comes from an older English spelling of Beijing: *Pek*ing.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Padre Aldamiz
description: Padre Aldamiz International primarily serves tourists visiting Peru’s national jungle reserves, like the nearby Tambopata-Candamo. Its three-letter code comes from its home in *P*u*e*rto *M*aldonado.

name: Lapangan Terbang Antarabangsa Pulau Pinang
description: Formerly named Bayan Lepas International, Penang International is located in the Bayan Lepas district in *Pen*ang, Malaysia.

name: Perth Airport
description: Known as RAAF Station Guildford during World War II, Perth Airport is now the fourth busiest in Australia and serves the city of *Per*th.

name: Bacha Khan International Airport
description: Renamed in 2012 to honor political and spiritual leader, Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, Bacha Khan International gets its airport code from its home in the city of *Pe*sha*w*ar.

name: Aeroporto Lauro Kurtz
description: Lauro Kurtz Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of *P*asso *F*undo in *B*razil.

name: Paphos International Airport
description: Paphos International is the second largest airport in Cyprus and a popular gateway for tourists. Its airport code honors its home in the city of Paphos, alternately spelled *P*a*fo*s.

name: Port Harcourt International Airport
description: Port Harcourt International is located in the suburb of Omagwa and serves the city of *P*ort *H*ar*c*ourt, Nigeria.

name: Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport
description: Renamed in 1990, Newport News/Williamsburg International was originally named Patrick Henry Airport after Camp Patrick Henry, a former army base. Its code represents *P*atrick *H*enry *F*ield.

name: Palm Beach County Glades Airport
description: Palm Beach County Glades Airport has one runway, but no control tower. Its airport code comes from its home city of *P*a*h*o*k*ee.

name: Philadelphia International Airport
description: During World War II, Philadelphia Municipal Airport served as an Air Force training field. Since 1945, it has been serving *Ph*i*l*adelphia and the Delaware Valley.

name: Sky Harbor International Airport
description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. *Ph*oeni*x* is one where the ‘X’ makes perfect sense.

name: St. Pete–Clearwater International Airport
description: St. Pete–Clearwater International is named for the two cities it serves. Previously called Pinellas International Airport, but with PIA already taken, it took its code from *Pi*n*e*llas County.

name: Glasgow Prestwick Airport
description: Started as a training airfield in 1934, Glasgow Prestwick Airport claims to be the only place in the U.K. Elvis Presley ever set foot. Its airport code comes from its home in *P*restw*i*c*k*.

name: Aeropuerto Capitán FAP Renán Elías Olivera
description: Primarily used by the Peruvian Army, Renán Elías Olivera Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of *Pi*sc*o*.

name: Pittsburgh International Airport
description: Opened in 1952, the “Greater Pitt” Airport serves and honors the city of *Pit*tsburgh.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP Guillermo Concha Iberico
nameEnglish: Capitán FAP Guillermo Concha Iberico International Airport
description: Guillermo Concha Iberico International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Piu*ra.

name: Aeroporto do Pico
description: Inaugurated in 1982, Pico Airport is located near Madalena on the island of *Pi*co. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Sultan Syarif Kasim II International Airport
description: Often referred to as SSK II and named after the last sultan of Siak, Sultan Syarif Kasim II International serves the city of *P*e*k*anbar*u*, Riau, Indonesia.

name: Beijing Daxing International Airport
description: Beijing’s second international airport follows their first airport (PEK), using the older English name for Beijing: *P*e*k*ing. The ‘*X*’ may represent nearby *X*iong'an New Area or Da*x*ing, but is likely a filler letter.

name: Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin II International Airport
description: Named after the last Sultan of Palembang, Sultan Mahmud Badaruddin II Airport serves the city of *P*a*l*e*m*bang, South Sumatra, and surrounding areas.

name: Tarptautinis Palangos oro uostas
description: Palanga International serves the Lithuanian Baltic sea resorts of *P*a*l*anga, the city of Klaipėda, and parts of Samogitia and western Latvia. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Aeroporto Carlos Drummond de Andrade
description: Named after Carlos Drummond de Andrade, 20th century Brazilian poet, Belo Horizonte Airport’s three-letter code is made of letters from the neighborhood of *P*amp*ul*ha.

name: Aeropuerto de Palma de Mallorca
description: Commonly called Son Sant Joan Airport, Palma de Mallorca Airport gets its airport code from its location in *P*alma on *M*allorca *I*sland.

name: Aeroporto de Palmas-Brigadeiro Lysias Rodrigues
description: Inaugurated in 2001, *P*al*m*as Airport is named after Lysias Rodrigues of the Brazilian Air Force. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*W*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Aeropuerto de Pamplona
description: Located between Noáin and Esquiroz, Pamplona Airport gets its three-letter code from the famous city of *P*amplo*na*.

name: Phnom Penh International Airport
description: Formerly known as Pochentong Airport, Phnom Penh International is the largest airport in Cambodia. Its three-letter code comes from its home city of *P*hnom Pe*nh*.

name: Pohnpei International Airport
description: Serving primarily island hopping residents and tourists, Pohnpei International gets its airport code from its home on *P*oh*n*pe*i* Island.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Supadio
description: Originally built in the 1940s and named Durian River Airport, Supadio International serves the city of *P*ontia*n*a*k* in West Kalimantan.

name: Pune Airport
description: Pune airport is named after its home in the city of *P*u*n*e. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Pensacola International Airport
description: In 2011, Pensacola Gulf Coast Regional was renamed to Pensacola International, still serving the city of *P*e*ns*acola and its surrounding areas.

name: Aeroporto de Petrolina–Senador Nilo Coelho
description: Petrolina Airport is named after former Senator Nilo de Sousa Coelho. Its three-letter code comes from the cities it serves: *P*etroli*n*a and Jua*z*eiro.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Salgado Filho
description: Originally São João Federal Airport, Salgado Filho International was renamed in 1951 in honor of Senator and Minister Joaquim Pedro Salgado Filho. Its airport code comes from the city of *P*ort*o* *A*legre.

name: Jacksons International Airport
description: Jacksons International is the busiest airport in Papua New Guinea. It is located just outside the city of *Po*rt *M*oresby and is often referred to as Port Moresby Airport.

name: Aeroporto Poços de Caldas
description: Poços de Caldas Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the city of *Po*ç*o*s de Caldas.

name: Piarco International Airport
description: Opened in 1931, Piarco International is located in the town of Piarco, but serves the capital city of *P*ort *o*f *S*pain.

name: Pago Pago International Airport
description: Also known as Tafuna Airport, *P*ago *P*a*g*o is the largest of the three airports of American Samoa, a small unincorporated territory of the United States located in the south Pacific Ocean.

name: Fa'a'ā International Airport
description: Fa'a'ā International serves the island of Tahiti in French Polynesia. It is located in the commune of Fa'a'ā in the city of *P*a*p*e'e*t*e.

name: Sân bay quốc tế Phú Quôc
description: Phu Quoc International opened in 2012 and replaced the previous Phu Quoc Airport. Its three-letter code honors its home on the island of *P*hu *Q*uo*c*.

name: Letiště Václava Havla Praha
description: In 2012, Prague Ruzyně International was renamed to honor Václav Havel, the Czech Republic’s first president. Its airport code honors its home in the capital city of *Pr*a*g*ue.

name: Pristina International Airport Adem Jashari
description: Opened in 1965, Pristina International is named after Adem Jashari, leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Pr*isti*n*a.

name: Aeroporto Internazionale di Pisa
description: Pisa International was formerly named Galileo Galilei Airport in honor of the Italian astronomer. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *P*i*sa*.

name: Tri-Cities Airport
description: The US Navy built Naval Air Station *P*a*sc*o during World War II. After the war, the Navy sold the field to the city of Pasco and it was redeveloped into Tri-Cities Airport.

name: Aeropuerto Mercedita
description: Built in 1939, Mercedita Airport gets its name from Hacienda Mercedita, the sugar plantation where it was located. Its airport code comes from the city of *P*onc*e*, with the ‘*S*’ as a phonetic substitute for the ‘C’.

name: Palm Springs International Airport
description: Well known for its Sonny Bono Concourse named after the late entertainer, *P*alm *Sp*rings International has been called one of America’s “Most Stress-Free Airports.”

name: Oakland County International Airport
description: Oakland County International serves Oakland County from Waterford Township. Its airport code comes from a previous name, *P*on*t*iac-Oa*k*land Airport.

name: Aérodrome de Pointe-à-Pitre Le Raizet
description: Located in Abymes, Pointe-à-Pitre Le Raizet Airport serves the city of *P*oin*t*e-à-*P*itre on the island of Grande-Terre in Guadeloupe, France.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Tocumen
description: Inaugurated in 1947, Tocumen International gets its name from the nearby Tocumen River. Its airport code comes from its home in *P*anama Ci*ty*.

name: Aéroport Pau Pyrénées
description: Located in the commune of Uzein and named after the Pyrenees Mountains, Pau Pyrénées Airport gets its three-letter code from the commune of *P*a*u*, *F*rance.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Presidente Carlos Ibáñez
description: Named after two-time Chilean President, Carlos Ibáñez International is located in the city of *Pu*nta Arenas. Its code is completed by the letter ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Gimhae International Airport
description: Opened in 1976, Gimhae International (formerly Kimhae) serves the city of Busan. Its three-letter code comes from the city’s former English spelling, *Pus*an.

name: Theodore Francis Green Memorial State Airport
description: T.F. Green Airport, as it’s called for short, honors former Rhode Island governor Theodore F. Green. Actually located in the nearby city of Warwick, its airport code reflects the major city it serves: *P*ro*v*i*d*ence.

name: Shanghai Pudong International Airport
description: Shanghai Pudong International opened in 1999. Its airport code comes from the Shanghai district of *P*udon*g* with a filler ‘*V*’ replacing the ‘U’ to get PVG.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Lic. Gustavo Díaz Ordaz
nameEnglish: Lic. Gustavo Díaz Ordaz International Airport
description: PVR is named after Mexican president Gustavo Díaz Ordaz and serves the city of *P*uerto *V*alla*r*ta.

name: Provo Municipal Airport
description: The second busiest airport in the state, Provo Municipal serves passengers to three other airports: PHX, OAK, and LAX. Its airport code comes from its home city of *P*ro*v*o, *U*tah.

name: Chicago Executive Airport
description: Chicago Executive Airport was formerly called *P*al*w*au*k*ee Municipal Airport, for its location near the intersection of *Pal*atine Road and Mil*waukee* Avenue. Located in the northwest suburbs of Chicago, it is the fourth-busiest airport in Illinois.

name: Portland International Jetport
description: The airport serving the original Portland (in Maine) started as small Stroudwater Field, later renamed to *P*ortland-*W*estbrook *M*unicipal Airport.

name: Aeroporto de Porto Santo
description: Built in 1959, Porto Santo Airport was the first airport in the Madeira Islands. Its airport code comes from its home in *P*orto Sant*o*, plus a helpful ‘*X*’ as a filler letter.

name: Sân bay Pleiku
description: Previously a military air base and developed into a civilian airport in 1975, Pleiku Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *P*leik*u*. Its code is completed by an ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Manuel Carlos Piar Guayana International Airport
description: Ciudad Guayana’s airport is named after Manuel Piar, general during the Venezuelan War of Independence. Its airport code is a mix of letters from its home in the city of *P*uerto *O*rda*z*.

name: Aeropuerto Intercontinental de Querétaro
description: Querétaro Intercontinental replaced Ing. Fernando Espinoza Gutiérrez International Airport in 2004. Its airport code comes from the city of *Q*ueréta*ro*.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Nelson Mandela
description: Opened in 2005 and renamed in 2012, Nelson Mandela International gets its airport code from its home in the capital city of P*rai*a.

name: Marrakesh Menara Airport
description: Marrakesh Menara Airport gets part of its name from the nearby Menara Gardens and the other part from its home in the capital city of Mar*rak*esh.

name: Rabat–Salé Airport
description: While actually located in Salé, Rabat–Salé Airport gets its airport code from the Moroccan capital city of *R*a*ba*t.

name: Dallas Executive Airport
description: Dallas Executive Airport serves the city of Dallas for general aviation and is a reliever airport for Dallas Love Field. Its airport code comes from its former name, *R*ed*b*ir*d* Airport.

name: Redding Municipal Airport
description: Originally Redding Army Airfield, Redding Municipal was a favorite for military airshows because of the nearby Shasta Lake. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *R*e*dd*ing.

name: Raleigh–Durham International Airport
description: Opened in 1943, Raleigh-Durham International is located in Wake County in between the cities of *R*aleigh and *Du*rham.

name: Aeroporto Internacional do Recife/Guararapes–Gilberto Freyre
description: Recife International’s full name honors the Battle of Guararapes during the Dutch-Portuguese War and Brazilian sociologist Gilberto Freyre. Its airport code honors its home in *Rec*ife.

name: Siem Reap International Airport
description: With a new terminal inaugurated in 2006, Siem Reap International gets its airport code from its home in the city of Siem *Re*a*p*, Cambodia.

name: Chicago Rockford International Airport
description: Started in 1917 as Camp Grant, Chicago Rockford International achieved international status in 2004. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *R*ock*f*or*d*.

name: Rangiroa Airport
description: Built in 1965, Rangiroa Airport serves the atoll of *R*an*gi*roa and French Polynesia.

name: Yangon International Airport
description: Located in the township of Mingaladon, Myanmar’s primary international airport serves the city of Yangon. Its airport code comes from an English spelling of Yangon: *R*an*g*oo*n*.

name: Richmond International Airport
description: Originally dedicated in 1927 as Richard Evelyn Byrd Flying Field, *Ric*hmond International Airport is the busiest airport in central Virginia.

name: March Air Reserve Base
description: Established as Alessandro Flying Training Field in 1918, March Air Reserve Base is named after aviator Peyton C. March, Jr. Its three-letter code honors its home near the city of *Riv*erside.

name: Riverton Regional Airport
description: With the airport code RIV already taken by March Air Force Base in Riverside, California, Riverton Regional took its code from *Ri*verton and switched a ‘*W*‘ for the ‘V’.

name: Starptautiskā lidosta “Rīga”
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Riga International was built relatively recently in 1973, so its airport code comes from *Ri*ga plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Aeropuerto de Logroño-Agoncillo
description: Built in 2003, Logroño-Agoncillo Airport is located in the city of Logroño. Its airport code comes from the nearby village of *R*eca*j*o in *L*a Rioja.

name: Flughafen Rostock–Laage
description: Rostock–Laage Airport was built in the late 1970s and was originally a National People’s Army facility. Its airport code honors the city of *R*ostock and the town of *L*aa*g*e.

name: Ramstein Air Base
description: Ramstein Air Base is a United States Air Force Base located near the city of Kaiserslautern and gets its airport code from the town of *R*a*ms*tein-Miesenbach.

name: Reno–Tahoe International Airport
description: Built in 1929 as Hubbard Field, Reno–Tahoe International get its three-letter airport code from its home in *R*e*no*, Nevada.

name: Aéroport de Rennes - Saint-Jacques
description: Originally opened in 1933, Rennes–Saint-Jacques Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *R*e*n*ne*s*.

name: Renton Municipal Airport
description: On the shore of Lake Washington, *R*e*nt*on has been the departure point for every brand new Boeing 737 ever made.

name: Roanoke–Blacksburg Regional Airport
description: Roanoke-Blacksburg Regional is also known as Woodrum Field after former U.S. Representative Clifton A. Woodrum. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Roa*noke.

name: Greater Rochester International Airport
description: Starting out as Britton Field in 1927, Greater *Roc*hester International Airport serves the city it is named after and its surrounding counties.

name: Roman Tmetuchl International Airport
description: Formerly Palau International, Roman Tmetuchl Airport is now named after political leader Roman Tmetuchl. While it serves Melekeok, it is actually located closer to Ko*ror*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Rosario Islas Malvinas
description: Rosario – Islas Malvinas International’s name reflects Argentina’s claim of sovereignty over the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas). Its airport code reflects its home in the city of *Ros*ario.

name: Aeroport Rostov-na-Donu
description: Originally built in 1925, Rostov-on-Don Airport became an international hub in 1986. Its airport code honors its home near the city of *Ro*sto*v*-on-Don.

name: Roswell International Air Center
description: Previously named Walker Air Force Base after Medal of Honor winner General Kenneth Walker, Roswell Air Center serves the city of *Ro*s*w*ell and is near the location of the 1947 Roswell crash.

name: Swami Vivekananda International Airport
description: Formerly known as Mana Airport, Swami Vivekananda International was renamed in 2012 to honor the well-known Indian saint. Its airport code honors the city it serves: *R*ai*p*u*r*.

name: Sir Gaëtan Duval Airport
description: Inaugurated as Plaine Corail Airport in 1972, it was renamed in 2007 in honor of Sir Charles Gaëtan Duval for his economic contributions. The only daily flights are between the islands of Mauritius and *R*od*r*i*g*ues.

name: Rochester International Airport
description: The original Rochester Airport was built in 1928 by the Mayo Foundation. Later renamed to Lobb Field, the airport was closed in 1961 and replaced by the current *R*oche*st*er International.

name: Southwest Florida International Airport
description: Renamed “International” in 1993, Fort Myers’ airport was originally regional only. It takes its airport code from *R*egional *S*outh*w*est.

name: Rotterdam The Hague Airport
description: Opened in 1956, Rotterdam Airport was the Netherlands’ second national airport and was built in part to replace Waalhaven Airport, destroyed during World War II. Its code comes from the city of *R*o*t*terda*m*.

name: King Khalid International Airport
description: King Khalid International is named after the former Saudi Arabian king who ruled from 1975 to 1982. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *R*iyad*h*, with a ‘*U*’ as a filler letter.

name: Aéroport de la Réunion Roland Garros
description: Roland Garros Airport is named after Roland Garros, French aviator and World War I pilot. It serves Saint-Denis, but gets its airport code from the French island of *R*é*u*nio*n*.

name: Rovaniemen lentoasema
description: *R*o*v*a*n*iemi airport, the official airport of Santa Claus, is the third busiest airport in Finland.

name: Moss lufthavn, Rygge
description: Opened in 2007, Moss Airport, Rygge is actually located in the town of Moss, but gets its three-letter code from the nearby city of *Ryg*ge.

name: Shaikh Zayed International Airport
description: Shaikh Zayed International is named after Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan who helped finance the airport’s construction. Its three-letter code honors its home city of *R*ahim *Y*ar *K*han.

name: Port Lotniczy Rzeszów-Jasionka
description: Rzeszów–Jasionka Airport is located in southeastern Poland. Although situated in the village of Jasionka, its airport code comes from the nearby city it serves: *Rze*szów.

name: Juancho E. Yrausquin Airport
description: The only airport on the Caribbean island of *Sab*a, Juancho E. Yrausquin Airport has the shortest commercial runway in the world at only 396 meters.

name: Santa Fe Municipal Airport
description: Santa Fe Municipal features three runways and serves the city of *S*ant*a* *F*e, New Mexico.

name: Sana'a International Airport
description: Sana'a International is currently closed due to severe damage sustained by its only runway. Its airport code comes from two of its aliases, *Sa*na'a International and El Ra*h*aba Airport.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Monseñor Óscar Arnulfo Romero
nameEnglish: Monseñor Óscar Arnulfo Romero International Airport
description: Renamed in 2014, Monseñor Óscar Arnulfo Romero International honors Óscar Romero, the fourth Archbishop of San *Sal*vador. It was previously named and is still called Comalapa Airport.

name: Lindbergh Field
description: Following Charles Lindbergh’s historic flight, the city where his plane was built capitalized on public support to build its own airport. Its airport code comes from the city it serves, *San* Diego.

name: San Antonio International Airport
description: The gateway for south central Texas, San Antonio International was originally known as Alamo Field. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *S*an *A*ntonio, *T*exas.

name: Savannah/Hilton Head International Airport
description: Despite having “International” in its name, Savannah/Hilton Head airport has no scheduled commercial flights outside the U.S. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Sav*annah.

name: Sabiha Gökçen Uluslararası Havalimanı
description: Sabiha Gökçen International is named after the first woman combat pilot in Turkey. Its airport code comes from *Sa*biha’s name, plus a letter ‘*W*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Santa Barbara Municipal Airport
description: Built on a former cow pasture, Santa Barbara Municipal gets its airport code from its home in the *S*anta *Ba*rbara/Goleta metropolitan area.

name: San Bernardino International Airport
description: San Bernardino International is located on the former site of Norton Air Force Base and serves the city of *S*an *B*ernar*d*ino.

name: South Bend International Airport
description: Opened in 1933 as Bendix Field, South Bend International was once called Michiana Regional (a combination of Michigan and Indiana). Its airport code honors its home in *S*outh *B*e*n*d.

name: San Luis Obispo County Regional Airport
description: Opened in 1939 by Earl Thomson, San Luis Obispo County Regional gets its airport code from its home in *S*an Luis O*b*is*p*o.

name: University Park Airport
description: Built in the 1950s, University Park Airport is now owned by Penn State University. Its airport code comes from its home near the town of *S*tate *C*olleg*e*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez
nameEnglish: Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez International Airport
description: Often called “Pudahuel Airport”, Comodoro Arturo Merino Benítez International honors the founder of the Chilean Air Force. Its airport code honors its home in *S*antiago, *C*hi*l*e.

name: International Airport Aktau
description: Aktau Airport began operations in 1993 and now serves the city of Aktau. Its three-letter code comes from Aktau’s former name, *S*hev*c*henk*o*. The airport was previously named Shevchenko-Central.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Santiago de Compostela
description: Santiago de Compostela Airport’s first flight took off in 1937. Its airport code comes from its home near *S*antiago de *C*ompostela, plus a ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Socotra Airport
description: Socotra Airport is Yemen’s most remote airport, serving the city of Hadibu on the island of *S*o*c*o*t*ra.

name: Louisville International Airport
description: Before being renamed in 1995, Louisville International was known as *S*tan*d*i*f*ord Field, honoring former state senator Elisha David Standiford.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Las Américas
description: Opened in 1959, Las Américas International is located in Punta Caucedo. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *S*anto *D*omingo, plus a helpful ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Aeropuerto Seve Ballesteros - Santander
description: Started as an airfield in 1953, Santander Airport is named after professional golfer Seve Ballesteros and serves the community of *S*antan*d*e*r*.

name: Aeroporto Santos Dumont
description: Originally known as Calabouço Airport, Santos Dumont Airport was inaugurated in 1936 and was named after Brazilian aviator Alberto *S*antos-*Du*mont.

name: Seattle–Tacoma International Airport
description: “Sea-Tac” was once renamed after U.S. Senator Henry M. Jackson for a short while, but *Sea*ttle and Tacoma residents voted to keep their cities in the airport’s name.

name: London Southend Airport
description: Serving London and its surrounding areas, London Southend Airport is situated between the towns of *S*outh*en*d and Rochford.

name: Sembach Kaserne
description: Sembach Kaserne is a United States Army installation in Sembach, Germany. Its airport code comes from its former name as *Se*mbach Anne*x*.

name: Aéroport International de Sfax-Thyna
description: Used as a military airfield during World War II, Sfax-Thyna International gets its airport code from the nearby city of *Sfa*x.

name: Søndre Strømfjord Lufthavn
description: Kangerlussuaq Airport is a former U.S. military base and today serves as the international gateway for the majority of travel to and from Greenland. Its former name was *S*ondrestrom*fj*ord Air Base.

name: Aeropuerto de Santa Fe - Sauce Viejo
description: Sauce Viejo Airport gets its airport code from rearranged letters from the city name of *S*a*n*ta *F*e.

name: San Francisco International Airport
description: Before the 1930’s, airports had two-letter codes. When codes switched to three letters, many added the letter ‘X’ to the end. *S*an *F*rancisc*o* instead used its last letter ‘O’.

name: Surgut International Airport
description: Surgut International, also known as Surgut North, gets its three-letter airport code from its home in *S*ur*g*ut *C*ity.

name: Springfield–Branson National Airport
description: Opened as Springfield–Greene County Airport in July 1945, *S*prin*gf*ield–Branson National is a public airport and has non-stop service to twelve U.S. cities.

name: Sân bay Quốc tế Tân Sơn Nhất
description: Tan Son Nhat International is named for the township in which it’s located, but serves Ho Chi Minh City. Its airport code comes from Ho Chi Minh City’s former name: *S*ai*g*o*n*.

name: St. George Regional Airport
description: Opened in 2011, St. George Regional replaced the landlocked St. George Municipal Airport. Its three-letter code honors the city of *S*t. *G*eorge, *U*tah.

name: Skagway Airport
description: Skagway, originally Skagua in Tlingit for “windy place”, was the largest city in Alaska by 1898 because of the Yukon gold rush. Its airport’s code honors its home in *S*ka*g*wa*y*.

name: Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport
description: Shanghai Hongqiao International was the first airport built in Shanghai. Its airport code makes sense as *S*hanghai *H*ongqiao *A*irport, but comes from the city of *SHA*nghai.

name: Shenandoah Valley Regional Airport
description: Located in Weyers Cave near the city of Staunton, *Sh*enan*d*oah Valley Regional is a general aviation airport and serves one commercial airliner.

name: Shenyang Taoxian International Airport
description: Shenyang Taoxian International serves *She*nyang, capital of Liaoning province.

name: Shreveport Regional Airport
description: Operational since 1931, Shreveport Regional Airport’s code honors its home in the city of *Sh*re*v*eport.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Amílcar Cabral
description: Built in 1939, Amílcar Cabral International is named after a Cape Verdean revoluntionary leader. It serves the city of Espargos, but gets its airport code from its home on *S*al *I*slan*d*.

name: Lapangan Terbang Changi Singapura
description: Often called just Changi Airport, *Sin*gapore’s main airport was named Skytrax “Best Airport in the World” three years in a row.

name: Simferopol International Airport
description: Since the annexation of Crimea by Russia, the *Si*mfero*p*ol International Airport only operates Russian domestic flights, despite the name. Under Russian control, it has been renovated, two new terminals were opened, and passenger traffic has seen substantial increase.

name: Aéroport de Sion
description: Sion Airport gets its three-letter airport code from its home city of *Si*on and the *R*hone Valley where it’s located.

name: Norman Y. Mineta San Jose International Airport
description: In 2001, San Jose International was renamed to honor former mayor Norman Mineta. Its airport code honors its home in *S*an *J*ose, *C*alifornia.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Los Cabos
description: Los Cabos International is most known for serving the resort city of Cabo San Lucas, but gets its airport code from its home in the city of *S*an *J*osé *d*el Cabo.

name: Sarajevo International Airport
description: Opened in 1969, Sarajevo International is located in the suburb of Butmir and is often called Butmir Airport. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *S*ara*j*evo, with a second ‘*J*’ as a filler letter.

name: Aeroporto de São José dos Campos-Professor Urbano Ernesto Stumpf
nameEnglish: São José dos Campos-Professor Urbano Ernesto Stumpf Airport
description: Named after Urbano Ernesto Stumpf, aviator and innovator, São José dos Campos Airport gets its airport code from the city of *S*ão *J*osé dos Campos. The ‘*K*’ is a phonetic replacement for the ‘C’ in Campos.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Juan Santamaría
description: Juan Santamaría International honors Juan Santamaría, national hero of Costa Rica who was killed in the Second Battle of Rivas in 1856. Its code comes from the city it serves, *S*an *JO*sé

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Luis Muñoz Marín
description: Luis Muñoz Marín International is named for Puerto Rico’s first democratically elected governor. Although actually located in Carolina, its airport code reflects the capital city of *S*an *Ju*an.

name: Aérodromo de São Jorge
description: São Jorge Airport is located in the town of Velas on the island of *S*ão *J*orge. The ‘Z’ in its code could be from A*z*ores, but is likely a filler letter.

name: Robert L. Bradshaw International Airport
description: Robert L. Bradshaw International is named after the first Premier of Saint Kitts and Nevis. Its airport code comes from its location on the island of *S*aint *K*itts in the city of *B*asseterre.

name: Thessaloniki International Airport, Macedonia
description: Opened in 1930, Thessaloniki International is often called Macedonia Airport. Its three-letter code comes from an alternate name for the city of Thessaloniki: *S*aloni*k*a, *G*reece.

name: Aerodrom Skopje
description: Skopje Airport is located in the village of Petrovec and serves the capital city of *Sk*o*p*je.

name: Sukkur Airport
description: Sukkur Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *S*u*k*kur. It is completed by a ‘*Z*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Salt Lake City International Airport
description: Originally named Woodward Field after local aviator John P. Woodward, Utah’s busiest airport now gets its name and airport code from state capital *S*alt *L*ake *C*ity.

name: Adirondack Regional Airport
description: Built during the 1940’s, Adirondack Regional was previously named *S*aranac *L*a*k*e Airport and serves travelers to the Adirondack Mountains.

name: Aeropuerto de Salamanca-Matacán
description: Often called just Matacán Airport, this airport in Castile and León gets its three-letter code from its home in the province of *S*a*l*a*m*anca.

name: Salina Regional Airport
description: Salina Regional is located at the continental center of the United States, earning it the nickname “America’s Fuel Stop.” Its airport code honors its home in *S*a*l*i*n*a.

name: George F. L. Charles Airport
description: George F. L. Charles Airport is named after the country’s former Chief Minister. Serving the city of Castries, it gets its airport code from *S*aint *Lu*cia.

name: Aeroporto Internacional Marechal Cunha Machado
description: Formerly named Tirirical Airport, Marechal Cunha Machado International gets its airport code from its home in the city of *S*ão *L*uís, Bra*z*il.

name: Aeroporto de Santa Maria
description: Inaugurated in 1945, *S*anta *M*aria *A*irport is located on the island of Santa Maria and serves the city of Vila do Porto.

name: Sacramento International Airport
description: When Sacramento International was built, the airport code SAC was already taken by (then named) Sacramento Municipal Airport. So it took its code from its original name, *S*acramento *M*etropolitan *F*ield.

name: John Wayne International Airport
description: In 1979, Orange County Airport was renamed to honor John Wayne, legendary actor and resident of nearby Newport Beach. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *S*a*n*ta *A*na.

name: Shannon Airport
description: After World War II, Shannon Airport became the primary gateway for transatlantic flights to and from the U.S. Its airport code honors its home in the town of *S*ha*nn*on.

name: Hévíz-Balaton Repülőtér
description: Publicly opened in 1991, Hévíz-Balaton Airport is located on the fields of Zalavár and Sármellék and neighbors Lake Balaton. Its airport code stands for *S*ármellék *o*n *B*alaton.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Adisumarmo
description: Adisumarmo International honors Adisumarmo Wiryokusumo, national hero and pioneer of the Indonesian Air Force. It serves the city of Surakarta, also known as *So*lo *C*ity.

name: Letishte Sofiya
description: Often called Sofia-Vrazhdebna Airport, Bulgaria’s primary airport gets its three-letter code from its home in *Sof*ia.

name: Bandar Udara Domine Edward Osok
description: Often called simply Sorong Airport, Domine Edward Osok Airport replaced Jefman Airport, a former World War II airfield. Its airport code comes from the city of *So*rong plus a ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Southampton Airport
description: Located in the Borough of Eastleigh, Southampton Airport was the site for the first Supermarine Spitfire test flight in 1936. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Sou*thampton.

name: Stronsay Airport
description: Scotland’s Stronsay Airport gets its three-letter code from its home on *S*tr*o*nsa*y* in the Orkney Islands.

name: Albert Whitted Airport
description: Opened in 1928, the airport is named after Navy Lieutenant James Albert Whitted, one of the first 250 Naval Aviators. Its airport code honors its home city, *S*aint *P*etersbur*g*.

name: Zračna luka Split
description: Formerly Resnik Airport, Split Airport gets its first two letters from the city it serves, *Sp*lit. The ‘U’ isn’t as clear, but could come from “*S*alonae *P*alati*u*m”, long-believed (erroneously) to be the origin of the city’s name.

name: San Carlos Airport
description: Opened during World War I and originally named San Carlos Flying Field, SQL is often misattributed as a reference to the nearby database company, Oracle. It actually stands for *S*an Car*l*os plus a helpful filler ‘*Q*’.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Juana Azurduy de Padilla
nameEnglish: Juana Azurduy de Padilla International Airport
description: Juana Azurduy de Padilla International is named after the 19th century guerrilla military leader. Its airport code comes from its home city of *S*uc*re*.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Ahmad Yani
description: Once a military airbase for the Armed Forces of Indonesia, Ahmad Yani International serves *S*ema*r*an*g* and its surrounding areas. It honors General Ahmad Yani, a major figure in the Indonesian National Revolution.

name: Sarasota–Bradenton International Airport
description: Sarasota–Bradenton Airport’s first three-letter code was SSO for *S*ara*so*ta. Because it could easily be confused for the distress signal SOS, the IATA assigned *S*a*r*asota SRQ, with the ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Salvador-Deputado Luís Eduardo Magalhães
description: Named after Brazilian politician Luís Eduardo Magalhães, Salvador Aiport gets its three-letter code from the city of Salvador’s former name of *S*ão *Sa*lvador.

name: Stinson Municipal Airport
description: Stinson Municipal was established in 1915 by aviators and teachers Katherine, Eddie, and Marjorie Stinson. Its airport code comes from its original name and purpose as *S*tinson *S*chool of *F*lying.

name: Aeropuerto de Malabo
description: Formerly Saint Isabel Airport, Malabo Airport is one of three paved airports in the country. Its three-letter code comes from Equatorial Guinea’s former history as the colony of *S*pani*s*h *G*uinea.

name: Sharm el-Sheikh International Airport
description: Originally opened in 1968 as an Israeli Air Force Base, Sharm el-Sheikh International gets its airport code from its home city of *S*harm el-*Sh*eikh.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional del Cibao
description: Inaugurated in 2002, Cibao International serves the Cibao region of Dominican Republic. Its airport code comes from its home city of *S*an*ti*ago de los Caballeros.

name: Lambert–St. Louis International Airport
description: Lambert-St. Louis International is named after Albert Bond Lambert, Olympic golfer and the first to receive a pilot’s license in the city of *St*. *L*ouis.

name: London Stansted Airport
description: Started as an airfield during World War II, London *St*a*n*sted Airport opened its first commercial terminal building in 1969 and is a base for many major European low-cost carriers.

name: St. Paul Downtown Airport
description: Built in 1927, Holman Field was named after airline and stunt pilot Charles W. Holman. Today, the airport is known as the *St*. *P*aul Downtown Airport.

name: Flughafen Stuttgart - Manfred Rommel Flughafen
description: Stuttgart Airport was renamed in 2014 to honor former mayor Manfred Rommel. It is the sixth busiest airport in Germany and serves the city of *St*uttga*r*t.

name: Charles M. Schulz - Sonoma County Airport
description: In 2000, Charles M. Schulz Airport was renamed to honor the famed “Peanuts” cartoonist, a longtime resident of Sonoma County. The airport’s code recognizes the city in which it is located, *S*an*t*a Ro*s*a.

name: Cyril E. King Airport
description: Previously named after Harry S. Truman, Cyril E. King Airport was renamed in 1984 to honor the former governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands. Its airport code comes from its home on the island of *St*. *T*homas.

name: Henry E. Rohlsen Airport
description: Henry E. Rohlsen Airport is named after Henry E. Rohlsen, a Tuskegee Airman during World War II. Its three-letter code honors its home on the island of *St*. Croi*x*.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Juanda
description: Juanda International is the second-busiest airport in Indonesia. It is named after the last Indonesian Prime Minister, Djuanda Kartawidjaja, but gets its airport code from the city it serves: *Su*ra*b*aya.

name: Friedman Memorial Airport
description: Friedman Memorial is named after the Friedman family who donated the land to the city of Hailey in 1931. Its airport code comes from the nearby resort community it serves: *Sun* Valley.

name: Nausori International Airport
description: Nausori International is located in the town of Nausori on the island of Viti Levu. Its airport code comes from the capital city of Fiji, *Suv*a.

name: Sioux Gateway Airport
description: *S*io*ux* City petitioned twice to have its airport code SUX changed. With no great alternatives, they stuck with it and now use the slogan “Fly SUX.”

name: E. T. Joshua Airport
description: E. T. Joshua Airport is named after Ebenezer Theodore Joshua, the first chief minister of Saint Vincent. Formerly known as Arnos Vale Airport, its three-letter code comes from its location on *S*aint *V*incent Islan*d*.

name: Stavanger lufthavn, Sola
description: Opened in 1937, Stavanger Airport is the second oldest in Norway. Located in Sola, it gets its airport code from the nearby city of *S*ta*v*an*g*er.

name: Sheremetyevo International Airport
description: Opened in 1959, *S*heremetye*vo* International is located in the city of Khimki, but was named after the nearby village of Sheremetyevsky.

name: Aeropuerto de Sevilla
description: Seville Airport, also known as San Pablo Airport, began commercial flights in 1919. Its airport code comes from the city of *S*e*v*ille, plus a ‘*Q*’ as a filler letter.

name: Koltsovo International Airport
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Koltsovo International serves Yekaterinburg, industrial and cultural center of the Ural region. It was previously named *Sv*erdlovsk, plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Stewart International Airport
description: Founded in the 1930s, Stewart International gets its name from the Stewart family who donated the land for the future airport. It was previously the location for *S*te*w*art Dairy *F*arm.

name: Aéroport International de Strasbourg
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Actually located in the village of Entzheim, this airport gets its code from the town of *S*tras*b*ourg plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Flughafen Berlin-Schönefeld
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. This Berlin airport get its code from its home in the town of *S*chöne*f*eld plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Princess Juliana International Airport
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. Princess Juliana International was named after the crowned princess (at the time) of the Netherlands. Its airport code stands for *S*aint *M*artin, plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Srinagar International Airport
description: Srinagar International is located in the city of *S*rinaga*r* in Jammu and Kashmir and is known for serving pilgrimage charters to Jeddah. Its airport code is completed with an ‘*X*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport
description: Kingsford Smith Airport is named in honor of Sir Charles Kingsford Smith, Australian aviator. Its airport code honors its home in *Syd*ney.

name: Syracuse Hancock International Airport
description: Syracuse Hancock International opened for passenger travel in 1949 and honors Clarence E. Hancock, former New York congressman. Its airport codes honors the city of *Syr*acuse.

name: Sanya Phoenix International Airport
description: Opened in 1994, Sanya Phoenix International gets its name and airport code from its home in the city of *S*an*y*a and nearby Phoeni*x* Mountain.

name: Shiraz International Airport
description: Renovated in 2005, Shiraz International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *S*hira*z*. It is completed with a ‘*Y*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Lapangan Terbang Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah
description: Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah Airport gave its airport code KUL to Kuala Lumpur International in 1998. Its new code comes from its current and former names: *S*ultan Abdul A*z*iz Shah / Su*b*ang Airport.

name: Salzburg Airport W. A. Mozart
description: Austria’s second largest airport is named after classical composer Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, but its airport code honors its home in *S*al*z*bur*g*.

name: Shenzhen Bao'an International Airport
description: Shenzhen Bao'an International (formerly Shenzhen Huangtian Airport) gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, *S*hen*z*hen, and its location in Bao'an District, historically called *X*in'an County.

name: A.N.R. Robinson International Airport
description: Renamed in 2011, A.N.R. Robinson International honors Arthur Napoleon Raymond Robinson, the third Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago. Its three-letter code rearranges letters from its home on the island of *T*o*ba*go.

name: Takamatsu Airport
description: Takamatsu Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Tak*amatsu.

name: Qingdao Liuting International Airport
description: Qingdao Liuting Airport will soon be replaced by Qingdao Jiaodong International. Its airport code comes from an older English spelling of Qingdao: Tsing*tao*.

name: Toshkent Xalqaro Aeroporti
description: Tashkent International is the largest airport in Uzbekistan. Its airport code comes from its home in the city of *Tas*hkent.

name: Sân bay Đông Tác
description: Dong Tac Airport’s code gets its first letter from its home city of *T*uy Hoa. The other two letters come from “*B*ãi *b*iển”, which translates to “the beach” and represents its close proximity to Vietnam’s coast.

name: Aeropuerto Capitán FAP Pedro Canga Rodríguez
nameEnglish: Capitán FAP Pedro Canga Rodríguez Airport
description: Pedro Canga Rodríguez Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *T*um*b*es, *P*eru.

name: Tbilisi International Airport
description: Formerly named Novo Alexeyevka International, Georgia’s largest airport is located in the capital city of *Tb*ili*s*i.

name: Tabriz International Airport
description: Serving both military and civilian traffic, Tabriz International gets its three-letter code from its home in *T*a*b*ri*z*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Coronel FAP Carlos Ciriani Santa Rosa
nameEnglish: Coronel FAP Carlos Ciriani Santa Rosa International Airport
description: Carlos Ciriani Santa Rosa International Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *T*a*c*na. It is completed by a ‘*Q*’, often used as a filler letter.

name: Base Aérea das Lajes
description: Lajes Field (or Lajes Air Base) is a multi-use airfield, serving primarily military aircrafts. Its airport code honors its home on the island of *Ter*ceira.

name: Aeropuerto de Tenerife Norte
description: Formerly known as Los Rodeos Airport, *T*eneri*f*e *N*orth Airport serves the island of Tenerife. Along with Tenerife South, it brings the most passenger traffic of all the Canary Islands.

name: Aeropuerto de Tenerife Sur Reina Sofía
description: *T*eneri*f*e *S*outh Airport was built to accommodate heavy tourist traffic and to relieve Tenerife North which was often covered in trade winds. It opened in 1978 and was dedicated to Queen Sofía of Spain.

name: Podgorica Airport
description: The city of Podgorica was known as *T*ito*g*ra*d* from 1946 to 1992, after the Yugoslav leader Josip Broz Tito.

name: Aeropuerto Tingo María
description: Tingo María Airport’s three-letter code is made of rearranged letters from its home city of *Ti*n*g*o María.

name: Aeroportul Transilvania Târgu Mureș
description: Opened in 1936, Transilvania Târgu Mureș Airport, often called just Transilvania Airport, is located in the village of Vidrasău and serves the city of *T*âr*g*u *M*ureș.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Toncontín
description: A notoriously difficult airport for landing, Toncontín opened in 1933 and gets its three-letter code from the city in which it is located, *T*e*gu*cigalpa, the capital of Honduras.

name: Mehrabad International Airport
description: Originally opened as an airfield in 1938, Mehrabad International was the primary airport for the city of *T*e*hr*an until 2007.

name: Tirana International Airport Nënë Tereza
description: Often called Rinas International, Albania’s only international airport is named after Mother Teresa. Its airport code honors the nearby city of *Ti*ran*a*.

name: Ta'if Regional Airport
description: Despite its name, Ta'if Regional does serve international flights. Its airport code honors its home in *Ta*'i*f*.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Tijuana
description: Opened in 1951 and sometimes referred to as General Abelardo L. Rodríguez International, its airport code comes from the city of *Tij*uana.

name: Tripoli International Airport
description: Formerly Castel Benito airport, *T*r*ip*oli International was mostly destroyed during the 2014 Libyan Civil War. Traffic has since been diverted to Mitiga International.

name: Roshchino International Airport
description: Built in 1968 and reconstructed in 1998, Roshchino International gets its airport code from its home city of *T*yu*m*en. The ‘J’ comes from the pronunciation of Tyumen, which sounds like *Tj*u*m*en.

name: Chuuk International Airport
description: Chuuk International is located on the island of Weno, but gets its airport code from the state of Chuuk, formerly known as *T*ru*k*. The code is completed by another ‘*K*’ as a filler letter.

name: Lennart Meri Tallinna lennujaam
description: Lennart Meri Airport is named after the second Estonian President, Lennart Meri. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *T*a*ll*inn.

name: Aéroport de Toulouse–Blagnac
description: Toulouse–Blagnac Airport is located in the suburb of Blagnac and gets it airport code from the city of *T*ou*l*ou*s*e.

name: Ben Gurion Airport
description: Renamed in 1973 to honor Israel’s first prime minister, Ben Gurion Airport is often called by its Hebrew acronym, “Natbag.” Its airport code comes from its proximity to the city of *T*e*l* Avi*v*.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de São Tomé
description: São Tomé International is a single runway airport and gets its airport code from its home in São *T*o*m*é, *S*ão Tomé and Príncipe.

name: Jinan Yaoqiang International Airport
description: Jinan Yaoqiang International is the airport serving Jinan (formerly Romanized as *T*si*na*n), the capital of Shandong Province, China.

name: Tangier Ibn Battouta Airport
description: Tangier Ibn Battouta Airport is named after Ibn Battouta, Moroccan explorer and scholar. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *T*a*ng*ier.

name: Aeropuerto Teniente Rodolfo Marsh
description: Sometimes called Villa Las Estrellas Airport, *T*e*n*iente R. *M*arsh Airport is the only airport in Antarctica with an IATA designation.

name: Ivato International Airport
description: Ivato International gets its three-letter airport code from its home in the capital city of An*t*a*n*ana*r*ivo.

name: Dade-Collier Training and Transition Airport
description: Originally planned as the largest airport in the world with six runways servicing supersonic jets, Everglades Jetport’s construction was stopped due to environmental concerns. Its name was changed to Dade-Collier *T*raining a*n*d *T*ransition Airport.

name: Toledo Express Airport
description: First opened in 1955, Toledo Express Airport is located in the townships of Swanton and Monclova. Its airport code honors the city it serves: *Tol*edo.

name: Tromsø lufthavn, Langnes
description: Opened in 1964, *T*r*o*m*s*ø Airport is located on the western shore of the island of Tromsøya.

name: Tampa International Airport
description: Renamed in 1950, Tampa International was once Drew Field Municipal, named after land developer John H. Drew. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *T*am*pa*.

name: Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport
description: Previously named Chiang Kai-shek International after the former president, Taiwan’s largest airport is actually located in Taoyuan City. Its airport code honors the city it serves, *T*ai*pe*i.

name: Aeropuerto Cadete FAP Guillermo del Castillo Paredes
nameEnglish: Cadete FAP Guillermo del Castillo Paredes Airport
description: Guillermo del Castillo Paredes Airport gets its three-letter code from its home city of *T*ara*p*oto, *P*eru.

name: Trondheim lufthavn, Værnes
description: Located in the town of Værnes, Trondheim Airport gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, *Tr*on*d*heim.

name: Port-adhair Thirioah
description: Tiree Airport is located just outside of Balemartine and gets its airport code from the island of *T*i*r*e*e*.

name: Sandefjord lufthavn, Torp
description: Opened in 1956, Sandefjord Airport is located in Torp and is often called *T*o*r*p *F*lyplass.

name: Tri-Cities Regional Airport
description: Tri-Cities Regional’s airport code honors the *Tri*-Cities area of NE Tennessee and SW Virginia, including the cities of Bristol, Kingsport, and Johnson City.

name: Aeroporto di Torino Sandro Pertini
description: Built in 1953 at the site of a former World War II base, Turin Airport is now named after former Italian President Sandro Pertini. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *T*u*r*i*n*.

name: Aeroporto di Trieste–Friuli Venezia Giulia
description: Originally Ronchi dei Legionari Airfield in the 1930s, Trieste – Friuli Venezia Giulia Airport serves the city of *Tr*ie*s*te.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Capitán FAP Carlos Martínez de Pinillos
nameEnglish: Capitán FAP Carlos Martínez de Pinillos International Airport
description: Carlos Martínez de Pinillos International serves the beachtown community of Huanchaco and Peru’s third largest city, *Tru*jillo.

name: Trivandrum International Airport
description: Trivandrum International was upgraded to an international airport in 1991. Located in Thiruvananthapuram, its name and code comes from the city’s short name, *Tr*i*v*andrum.

name: Bonriki International Airport
description: Built in 1943 by the U.S. Navy as Mullinix Field, Bonriki International gets its three-letter airport code from its location in the atoll of *T*a*r*a*w*a.

name: Taipei Songshan Airport
description: Built in 1936, *T*aipei *S*ongshan *A*irport was originally named Matsuyama Airdrome and served as a Japanese military airbase.

name: Astana International Airport
description: Astana International is located in Astana, which became the capital city of Kazakhstan in 1997. In 1963 when the airport opened, Astana was named *Tse*linograd.

name: Tianjin Binhai International Airport
description: Tianjin Binhai International is located in Dongli District, Tianjin (alternately Romanized as *T*ient*s*i*n*). It is one of the major air cargo centers in the People’s Republic of China.

name: Trenton–Mercer Airport
description: Previously known as Mercer County Airport, it was renamed in 1995 to Trenton–Mercer Airport to promote its location in the capital city of *T*ren*t*o*n*.

name: Tulsa International Airport
description: Renamed ‘International’ in 1963, *Tul*sa Municipal Airport opened in 1928 and just two years later was the busiest airport in the world, outpacing London, Berlin, and Paris.

name: Tunis–Carthage International Airport
description: Tunis–Carthage International is named after the nearby historic city of Carthage and the city it serves, *Tun*is.

name: Tucson International Airport
description: Tucson International is the second busiest airport in Arizona. Its airport code honors its home in the city of *Tu*c*s*on.

name: Flughafen Berlin-Tegel “Otto Lilienthal”
description: Many airports use the letter ‘X’ to fill in when the desired letters are already taken. This Berlin airport get its code from its home in the borough of *T*ege*l* plus that helpful ‘*X*’.

name: Aeropuerto Capitán FAP Víctor Montes Arias
description: Used by the United States Army Air Forces during World War II, Víctor Montes Arias Airport gets its three-letter code from the city of *T*a*l*ara. It is completed with a ‘*Y*’, used as a filler letter.

name: McGhee Tyson Airport
description: Located in the city of Alcoa, south of Knoxville, McGhee Tyson Airport is named after U.S. Navy pilot Charles McGhee *Tys*on who was lost in action during World War I.

name: Tuzla International Airport
description: Previously a military airport, Tuzla International reopened in 1998 as a civilian airport. Its three-letter code honors its home in *T*u*zl*a.

name: Ufa International Airport
description: Ufa International is the primary airport serving *Ufa*, the capital of the Republic of Bashkortostan in Russia. It is one of the few airport codes that matches the full name of the city it serves.

name: Sân bay Phù Cát
description: Phù Cát Airport is located in Phu Cat District, but gets its three-letter code from the city it serves, Q*ui* N*h*on.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Mariscal Sucre
description: Mariscal Sucre International is named after Antonio José de Sucre who fought for the independence of Quito, in what is now Ecuador. Because the FCC reserved codes starting with ‘Q’, it opted for other letters from its home city of Q*ui*t*o*.

name: Chinggis Khaan International Airport
description: Opened in 1957 as Buyant-Ukhaa Airport, Chinggis Khaan International was renamed in 2005 after Genghis Khan and in honor of the Mongolian state’s 800th anniversary. Its airport code comes from its home city of *Ul*aa*n*baatar.

name: Bandar Udara Internasional Sultan Hasanuddin
description: Sultan Hasanuddin International is the busiest airport in South Sulawesi and serves the city of Makassar. Its airport code comes from the city’s former name: *U*jung *P*andan*g*.

name: Oral Ak Zhol Airport
description: Oral Ak Zhol Airport is located in the city of Oral, also called Uralsk in Russian. The airport was formerly named *Ura*lsk Ak Zhol.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Ushuaia Malvinas Argentinas
description: Ushuaia International’s full name reflects Argentina’s claim of sovereignty over the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas). Its airport code reflects its home in the city of *Ush*uaia.

name: Samui International Airport
description: Samui International opened in 1989 and, except for its gift shop, is entirely outdoors. Its airport code USM is a combination of letters from the island of Ko *S*a*mu*i where it’s located.

name: Udon Thani International Airport
description: Used as Udorn Royal Thai Air Force Base during the Vietnam War, Udon Thani International gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *U*don *Th*ani.

name: Baikal International Airport
description: Now named after Lake Baikal, Baikal International was once named after its home in the city of *U*lan-*Ud*e.

name: Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk Airport
description: Started in 1945 as a military airfield, Yuzhno-Sakhalinsk Airport serves the city of Y*u*zhno-*S*akhalinsk. Its code is completed by a second letter ‘*U*’, used as a filler letter.

name: Hewanorra International Airport
description: Formerly Beane Army Airfield, Hewanorra International bears the island’s former name of Hewanorra. Two of its code’s letters come from the city of *V*ieux *F*ort. The ‘*U*’ could come from Saint L*u*cia, but is likely a filler letter.

name: Villa International Airport Maamigili
description: Developed by Maldivian businessman Qasim Ibrahim, Maamigili’s international airport gets its airport code from its full name: *V*illa International *A*irport *M*aamigili.

name: Letishte Varna
description: Built in 1946 to replace the small Tihina Airport, *Var*na Airport is located near the town of Aksakovo.

name: Vava’u International Airport
description: Also known as Lupepau’u  Airport, Vava’u International is a main tourist hub for Tonga, especially during whale migration season. Its three-letter code comes from the city name of *Vav*a’u.

name: Sân bay Quốc tế Cần Thơ
description: Built by the U.S. Air Force during the Vietnam War and previously called Tra Noc Airport, Can Tho International opened commercially in 2008. It gets its airport code from its country and city of *V*ietnam, *Ca*n Tho.

name: Aeroporto di Venezia Marco Polo
description: Marco Polo Airport shares its name with the famous Venetian merchant traveler. Its airport code comes from its home city of *V*eni*ce*.

name: Sân bay Chu Lai
description: Built by the U.S. Navy during the Vietnam War, Chu Lai Airport opened commercially in 2005. It serves Tam Ky, but gets its airport code from its country and city of *V*ietnam, *C*hu *L*ai.

name: Aeroporto Internacional de Viracopos/Campinas
description: *V*ira*c*o*p*os/Campinas International Airport is sometimes referred to as São Paulo/Campinas, and is named after the neighborhood where it is located.

name: Sân bay Côn Đảo
description: Con Dao Airport is located in the archipelago of Con Dao, but gets its three-letter code from its country and island of *V*ietnam, *C*on *S*on Island.

name: Aeropuerto de El Hierro
description: Inaugurated in 1972, El Hierro Airport is located on the island of El Hierro and gets its three-letter code from the nearby city of *V*alver*de*.

name: Sân bay Đồng Hới
description: Dong Hoi Airport gets its three-letter code from its home country and city of *V*ietnam, *D*ong *H*oi.

name: Aeropuerto de Vigo
description: Opened in 1954, Vigo Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *V*i*go*.

name: North Las Vegas Airport
description: Originally Sky Haven Airport, North Las Vegas Airport opened December 7, 1941, the same day as the attack on Peark Harbor. In 1968, It was renamed North Las *V*e*g*as Air *T*erminal.

name: Flughafen Wien-Schwechat
description: Austria’s largest airport is actually located in the town of Schwechat, but gets its airport code from the nearby capital city of *Vie*nna.

name: Sân bay Vinh
description: Vinh Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *Vi*nh. The second ‘*I*’ is a filler letter, but will soon stand for ‘International’ when the airport begins international traffic in 2030.

name: Aeroporto de Vitória-Eurico de Aguiar Salles
description: Formerly Goiabeiras Airport, Vitória Airport is named after Eurico de Aguiar Salles, a local politician. Its airport code comes from the city of *Vi*tória. The ‘*X*’ is a filler letter for ‘C’ from the previously spelled Victória.

name: Sân bay Rạch Giá
description: Rach Gia Airport gets its three-letter code from its country and province of *V*ietnam, *K*ien *G*iang.

name: Vnukovo International Airport
description: Vnukovo International is Moscow’s oldest operating airport, originally opened in 1941. It received its name and airport code from the small nearby village of *V*nu*ko*vo.

name: Aeropuerto de Valencia
description: Spain’s 8th busiest airport is located in the town of Manises, but serves the city of *V*a*l*en*c*ia.

name: Bauerfield International Airport
description: Built during World War II, Bauerfield Airport gets its name from Lt-Col. Harold W. Bauer, a U.S. Marine Corps pilot. Its airport code comes from its alternate name, Port *V*i*l*a *I*nternational.

name: Aeropuerto de Valladolid
description: Opened in 1938, Valladolid International is located in the town of Villanubla and serves the city of *V*a*ll*adolid.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Arturo Michelena
description: Named after the Venezuelan painter, Arturo Michelena International serves the city of *V*a*l*e*n*cia. It is not to be confused with VLC, located in Valencia, Spain.

name: Tarptautinis Vilniaus oro uostas
description: Opened in 1932, Vilnius International is the largest airport in Lithuania. The city of Vilnius has had many different spellings in various languages including Wilno, Vilna, and *V*il*no*.

name: Lal Bahadur Shastri International Airport
description: Formerly Varanasi International, Lal Bahadur Shastri International was renamed in 2005 to honor India’s second Prime Minister. Its airport code honors one of the holiest of the seven sacred cities, *V*ara*n*a*s*i.

name: Van Nuys Airport
description: Van Nuys Airport serves Los Angeles, located in the *V*an *N*u*y*s neighborhood of the San Fernando Valley.

name: Volgograd International Airport
description: Previously named Gumrak Airport, Volgograd International gets its three-letter code from its home near the city of *Vo*l*g*ograd.

name: Voronezh-Chertovitskoye International Airport
description: Voronezh-Chertovitskoye International gets its three-letter code from the primary city it serves, *Vo*rone*z*h, located 11km south of the airport.

name: Destin–Fort Walton Beach Airport
description: Located within Eglin Air Force Base, Destin–Fort Walton Beach Airport gets its code from the nearby city of *V*al*p*arai*s*o, Florida.

name: Aeroporto di Verona-Villafranca
description: Verona Villafranca Airport was originally a military airport during World War I. Today, it serves travelers to and from *V*e*r*o*n*a, the city of Romeo and Juliet.

name: Wattay International Airport
description: Wattay International is an international airport in the country of Laos. Its airport code comes from the capital city of *V*ien*t*ian*e* where it’s located.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Viru Viru
description: *V*iru *Vi*ru International opened in 1983 and replaced El Trompillo Airport. Its name is derived from the word “Birubiru”, which refers to a now dry nearby river.

name: Lotnisko Chopina w Warszawie
description: Formerly named Okecie International, Warsaw Chopin Airport honors Polish composer Frédéric Chopin. Its airport code honors its home in *Wa*rsa*w*.

name: Hosea Kutako International Airport
description: Formerly J.G. Strijdom Airport, Namibia’s primary international airport is now named after Hosea Kutako, political leader and national hero. Its airport code comes from its home in *W*in*dh*oek.

name: Bandar Udara Umbu Mehang Kunda
description: Renamed in 2009, Umbu Mehang Kunda Airport gets its three-letter code from its home in the city of *W*ain*g*a*p*u on the island of Sumba.

name: Wellington International Airport
description: Located in the suburb of Rongotai, New Zealand’s third busiest airport serves its capital city of *W*e*l*lin*g*ton.

name: Mazowiecki Port Lotniczy
description: Opened in 2012, *W*arsaw–*M*odl*i*n Mazovia Airport is located in the town of Nowy Dwór Mazowiecki and serves the city of Warsaw.

name: Port Lotniczy Wrocław im. Mikołaja Kopernika
description: Wroclaw–Copernicus Airport was renamed in 2005 after the famous astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus. Its airpot code honors its home in the city if *Wro*claw.

name: Sunan Shuofang International Airport
description: Sunan Shuofang International serves the cities of *Wux*i and Suzhou in Jiangsu Province, China (Sunan means ‘Southern Jiangsu’).

name: Christmas Island Airport
description: Christmas Island Airport gets its three-letter code from its home on *Ch*ristmas Island, a territory of Australia. The ‘*X*’ is likely a filler letter, but is also a common short-hand for Christ (*X*-mas).

name: Xi'an Xianyang International Airport
description: Opened in 1991, Xi'an Xianyang International serves the city of Xi'an, and is located in the Weicheng District of *Xi*an*y*ang.

name: Xiamen Gaoqi International Airport
description: Xiamen Gaoqi International is the eighth busiest airport in China and is located on the north side of *X*ia*m*e*n* Island.

name: Northwest Arkansas Regional Airport
description: The letter ‘*X*’ is often used as a filler letter. When airport codes switched from two letters to three, the U.S. Navy reserved all codes starting with ‘N’. So *N*orthwest *A*rkansas Regional opted to use the ‘X’ as its first letter.

name: Xining Caojiabao Airport
description: Opened in 1991, Xining Caojiabao Airport is located in Qinghai, China. Its airport code comes from the city of *X*i*n*i*n*ng.

name: Aeropuerto de Jerez
description: Jerez Airport serves the city of Jerez, famous for the fortified wine, sherry. Its airport code likely comes from a combination of an alternate spelling of Jerez, *X*e*r*es, and the English spelling, Sherr*y*.

name: Sault Ste. Marie Airport
description: With a few exceptions, codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. It‘s not confirmed, but some claim the ‘AM’ stands for *A*irport *M*arie.

name: Yap International Airport
description: Yap International is one of the few airports whose code is the same as the name of the area it serves, *Yap* Island.

name: Tofino/Long Beach Airport
description: With a few exceptions, codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Built to protect the coast during World War II, Tofino Airport can be the start or end of the country. Its code, then, is made of the first and last letters of the alphabet, ‘*AZ*’.

name: Nanaimo Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Nanaimo Airport is actually located in the city of *C*assi*d*y where it gets the other two letters of its name.

name: Boundary Bay Airport
description: With a few exceptions, codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Opened in 1983, Boundary Bay Airport serves the Vancouver area and is located in the town of *D*el*t*a.

name: Edmonton International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Edmonton International’s code reflects the city’s military history and comes from the nearby Canadian Forces Base, also called *E*dmonton *G*arrison.

name: Iqaluit Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘FB’ comes from *F*robisher *B*ay, the region Iqaluit rests on.

name: Gods Lake Narrows Airport
description: Airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. This Manitoba airport gets its other two letters from its home in the city of *Go*ds Lake Narrows.

name: Gjoa Haven Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The other letters likely come from Gjoa *H*aven and *K*itikmeot Region, where the airport is located.

name: John C. Munro Hamilton International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. ‘HM’ comes from this airport’s home in the city of *H*a*M*ilton.

name: Halifax Stanfield International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Named after former Premier Robert Stanfield, Halifax International’s code is completed by *H*alifax and a helpful filler letter ‘*Z*’.

name: Willow Run Airport
description: Until 1958, Willow Run was Detroit’s primary airport. Its three-letter code represents the nearby town of *Y*psilanti and its nickname’s pronunciation of “*Ip*-see.”

name: Samjiyŏn Airport
description: Samjiyŏn Airport is a military airport and only receives flights from Pyongyang Sunan International. Its three-letter code of YJS comes from rearranged letters from the city of *S*am*j*i*y*ŏn.

name: Alert Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The northernmost airport in the world gets its other two code letters from its home in the city of A*l*er*t*.

name: Kelowna International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘LW’ comes from the city’s name: Ke*l*o*w*na. The phrase ‘*Y*our *L*ink to the *W*orld’ (a backronym) has been used in the YLW branding to make the code more memorable.

name: Fort McMurray International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The other letters for YMM come from its home city of Fort *M*c*M*urray.

name: Aéroport international Montréal–Mirabel
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘Y’ designate Canadian airports. Mirabel Airport is primarily a cargo airport near *M*ontreal. The ‘*X*’ in its code is a filler letter.

name: Prince Abdul Mohsin bin Abdulaziz Airport
description: Expanded in 2009, Prince Abdul Moshin bin Abdulaziz Airport is located in the city of *Y*a*nb*u' Al Bahr in Saudi Arabia.

name: Youngstown–Warren Regional Airport
description: Originally opened in 1940, Youngstown–Warren Regional is home to Youngstown–Warren Air Reserve Station. It serves the nearby cities of *Y*ou*ng*stown and Warren, Ohio.

name: Yongphulla Airport
description: Reopened in 2013 after resurfacing its runway, Yongphulla Airport serves the city of Trashigang. Its airport code comes from its name and the nearby village of *Yon*gphulla.

name: Oshawa Executive Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. ‘OO’ comes from this airport’s home in the city of *O*shawa, *O*ntario.

name: Ottawa Macdonald–Cartier International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Named after two Fathers of Confederation, Macdonald-Cartier International gets its other two letters from its home in *O*tta*w*a.

name: Aéoport international Jean-Lesage de Québec
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports.  The next two letters come from its home in *Q*ué*b*ec.

name: Greater Moncton International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘*Q*’ is a filler letter and the ‘M’ comes from the city it serves: *M*oncton (though it’s actually located in Dieppe).

name: Regina International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The other two letters in Regina International’s code come from its home in “The *Q*ueen City” of *R*egina.

name: Thunder Bay International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘*Q*’ is a filler letter and the ‘T’ comes from its home in the city of *T*hunder Bay.

name: Gander International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Formerly named Newfoundland Airport, Gander International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Sydney/J.A. Douglas McCurdy Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. J.A. Douglas McCurdy Airport in Sydney has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Sudbury Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Sudbury Airport serves Greater *S*ud*b*ury in Ontario.

name: Aéroport de Saint John
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Saint John Airport’s code is completed with letters from its home city of *S*aint *J*ohn.

name: Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘*TZ*’ isn’t as clear, but it’s been said it represents the radio call of the airport’s weather station.

name: Aéroport international Pierre-Elliott-Trudeau de Montréal
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘*UL*’ isn’t as clear, but may be due to a nearby radio beacon which has continuously broadcast those letters since before the airport’s establishment in 1941.

name: Yuma International Airport
description: Yuma International’s aviation history began in 1911 when Robert Fowler set a world record for endurance and distance. Its three-letter code honors its home in the city of *Yum*a, Arizona.

name: Vancouver International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Vancouver International is actually located in the city of Richmond, but gets its other two letters from the major port city it serves, *V*ancouve*r*.

name: James Armstrong Richardson International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. James Armstrong Richardson International honors the Canadian aviator, but its airport code honors its home in *W*innipe*g*.

name: Saskatoon John G. Diefenbaker International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Saskatoon International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Medicine Hat Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Medicine Hat Airport has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: London International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. London International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Abbotsford International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Abbotsford International in British Columbia has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Erik Nielsen Whitehorse International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘*XY*’ isn’t as clear. The ‘*Y*’ likely stands for Yukon, and it’s said the ‘*X*’ is a filler letter.

name: Calgary International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The second ‘*Y*’ is a filler letter and the ‘C’ comes from its home in the city of *C*algary.

name: Smithers Regional Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Smithers Regional in British Columbia has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Victoria International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Formerly called Patricia Bay Airport, Victoria International has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: St. John’s International Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The second ‘*Y*’ is a filler letter and the ‘T’ comes from its former name, *T*orbay Airport. This helps differentiate it from the other Saint John Airport (YSJ).

name: Pearson International Airport
description: Most airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. The ‘*YZ*’ is said to be the old railway station code for Malton, an area west of Toronto where the airport is located. You may know YYZ from the song by Canadian rock band Rush.

name: Yellowknife Airport
description: With a few exceptions, airport codes starting with ‘*Y*’ designate Canadian airports. Yellowknife Airport has one of the mysterious codes in which the other two letters were randomly assigned.

name: Zračna luka Zadar/Zemunik
description: Zadar Airport formerly served as a Lufthansa flight school but now serves the city of *Zad*ar, Croatia.

name: Međunarodna zračna luka Zagreb
description: Located in the suburb of Pleso and often called Pleso Airport, Croatia’s main international airport gets its code from the capital city of *Zag*reb.

name: Aeropuerto de Zaragoza
description: Zaragoza Airport is home to the Spanish Air Force 15th Group and serves commercial traffic to the city of *Za*rago*z*a.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional General Leobardo C. Ruiz
description: The city of *Z*a*C*atecas is serviced by General *L*eobardo C. Ruiz International, hence the airport code ZCL.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional de Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo
description: Built in 1998, Ixtapa-Zihuatanejo International is a gateway for the many tourists of Mexico’s beaches and serves the Ixtapa-*Zih*uatanejo area.

name: Aeropuerto Internacional Playa de Oro
description: The busiest tourist airport in the Mexican state of Colima, Playa de Oro International gets its three-letter code from the city of Man*z*anil*lo*.

name: Queenstown Airport
description: Opened in 1961, Queenstown Airport is located in the suburb of Frankton. Its airport code comes from New *Z*ealand, *Q*ueenstow*n*.

name: Flughafen Zürich
description: Not surprisingly, Switzerland’s busiest airport is located in its largest city of *Z*ü*r*ic*h*.
